name: Computamatic Tennis
description:
While many of the electronic sports board games from EDC shared a common board and used overlays to portray different sports, Computamatic Tennis is a unique game. It relies on a large array of 24 light bulbs under a translucent board depicting a tennis court. The game is battery operated.

Players sit at opposite ends of the board where they have a series of buttons they use to enter actions. Each player's set of buttons is divided into four categories (each with four buttons): Receive Volley, Return Volley, Receive Serve, and Serve Left/Right. The combination of buttons pressed by the players serves to illuminate the lights under the board to show the result of the serve or volley. Tracking of games, sets, and matches is handled manually by the players using tracks on the board.

—user summary

name: Die Maus: Quizquartett Pferde
description:
This is based on a Quartett type card game but extended by a quiz.

Each player draws 4 cards from the stack.
The youngest player starts the game (active player) and asks any other player if he holds a card needed to complete a set of four. The enquiring player must always have at least one of the set in their hand before asking.

Unlike a normal Quartett game, the player asked does not automatically surrender the card in question he might hold, but has to ask one of the questions noted on the card. Only if the active player supplies the correct answer to the quiz question the card is surrendered. The player who was successful may continue to ask the one who has surrendered a card for a further card. The moment that player cannot supply the wanted card or any of his quiz questions isn't answered correctly, he becomes the one to ask any player for a card. Whenever a quiz question is answered wrong the asked player draws a card.

If a completed Four is obtained, the successful player should lay it on the table and that set is now safe. This continues round the table until all the sets are laid down and the player has tabled the largest number of four, wins.

—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational

name: Trivial Pursuit: Lindemans Enjoyment Edition
description:
A rare Trivial Pursuit Game Edition, published in collaboration with Lindemans Wine

Categories: Showbiz, Wining and Dining, Fun & Games, TV & Movies, Music, and Bizarre World

name: Zoo Station
description:
Every morning, the Zoo Station is overwhelmed by anxiously travellers looking for the train that take them to their destination. Compete with other players to get the most important passengers boarded on your trains and become the best train conductor of the Zoo Station. All aboard!

At the beginning of your turn roll the die. The colour result indicates the colour on the board, where you are allowed to take either a wagon or passenger from.

Take a Wagon: and place it at your own or any other player’s train.

Take a Passenger: and place it aboard one of your wagons or place it on waiting list.

The game ends when a player gets to board the 5th passenger. Then, all players will have one last turn, including the player who trigger the end of the game.

The final score will be the sum of the points per wagons with passengers aboard.
Player with the most points is the declared the best train conductor of the Zoo Station.
In case of tie, player with most wagons (with or without passengers) is the winner.
If tie remains, a rematch takes places.

—description from the designer

name: #DONTBUYIT
description:
A simple tabletop card game meant to bring couples closer together! (Results may vary.)

GAMEPLAY (in short):

Start with four KNOWLEDGE CARDS
Partners take turns asking each other their KNOWLEDGE CARDS
If your partner answers incorrectly, they draw an ACTION CARD
Complete the ACTION CARD, or take a STRIKE
Two strikes, YOU'RE OUT!


—description from the publisher

name: The Great Yacht Race
description:
A board game of chance and skill in which each player or skipper aims to get to his/her yacht to the finish first, by planning tacks and tactics along the course by switching Laylines (Port/Starboard), avoiding obstructions enroute, blocking their opponent’s progress, adhering to instructions printed on the boards and cards, and making moves in accordance with the rules of the game.

Game comes with board, 8 yachts, and 56 cards for the 6 legs of the course.

name: The Rugby League State of Origin Football game
description:
A board game played by two players or two teams of players each controlling 13 footballers, who may carry, pass or kick the ball and aim to score points based on the international rules of rugby league. The player or team scoring the greater number of points in the allotted time is the winner.

"You can actually kick a goal, tackle, pass and play just like the real game. Test your football skill and outmanoeuvre the opposition. Learn to play like the professionals! An excellent coaching aid for young professionals."--Box

Contains game board marked in a grid pattern representing playing area (1 metre = 1 square), plastic player tokens; plastic goal posts, plastic markers to denote movement on the board; playing token representing the ball; play cards; 2 cent coin (for coin toss).

Players use the plastic rugby player pieces to physically kick the ball tiddly-wink style. If it hits another playing piece, the ball is his, otherwise a general play card is drawn. Players may choose to run, pass or kick the ball.

The designers' names are misspelt on the outside of the box as S. Sofas and G.D. Makin.

name: The Len Evans Wine Options Game
description:
A blind testing game ‘developed for both enjoyment and learning about the wonderful world of wine.’ Competitors attempt to identify one or more bottles of wine in sessions taking as little as ten minutes or with more bottles during an entire meal. A winemaster opens the wine in secret and removes tell-tale caps or branded corks, masks the bottle with the black cloth bag, and asks the first of a series of questions, ‘What state does this wine come from?’ with cards indicating responses to be placed on a board. Players also bet on wine producing area, wine grower, grape variety and year of vintage, and the current winner and the person running last are awarded the coveted Golden Grape Award Medallion and the not so desirable Sour Grapes Award Medallion.

Contains: 1 Winemaster's Options Board; 1 Winemaster's Easy-find Index; 1 Winemaster's Bottle Mask; 8 Player's Playing Placemats; 6 State Cards; 23 Wine Producing Area Cards; 42 Grape Variety Cards; 175 Winegrower's Cards; 30 Vintage Cards; 10 Wild Cards; 38 Golden Grape Medallions; 41 Sour Grape Medallions; 2 Golden Grape Awards; 2 Sour Grape Awards; 10 $10 Tokens; 28 $5 Tokens; 41 $1 Tokens; 1 Set of Rules; 1 Scorepad.

name: Dollar Decisions
description:
A game based on a four week pay period, for 16-18 year olds, to teach the concepts of budgeting and money management. As players progress around the board they are faced with a variety of decision-making situations related to both income and factors influencing their spending. Players move along a time track using a spinner, choosing whether to make purchases on the squares they land on, or following mandatory instructions on cards drawn on certain square. The first player to get to the end of week 4 wins.

Contains board, 1 spinner, 6 coloured counters, 1 set of budget busters and Boosters cards, 1 winner's card and envelope, 2 sheets, multiple copies of score sheet, teacher's notes).

name: The Aussie Gold Rush Game
description:
A roll and move game from the 1980s, in which up to four players or prospectors advance around numbered squares on a board. The winner is the first player to complete the route around the track and strike gold. Players pass a number of Australian landmarks and wildlife along the way, and jump forward or back according to instructions on the board and 15 gold cards.

Contains game board (43.5 x 59.5 cm; folded to 22 x 30 cm); 15 gold cards; 4 prospector player tokens and spinner (to be constructed with a drawing pin); rule sheet with spinner base and place for stacking gold cards (41 x 22.4 cm).

A cheaply-produced game sold in showbags at Australian fairs and shows.

name: Kangaroo Checkers
description:
A game played on a modified checkers (chequers) or draughts board, which resembles the 8×8 board but lacks six squares in each corner. It uses two sets of 11 ordinary checkers plus 1 king for each side. The ordinary checkers may move orthogonally forwards or sideways into vacant squares, but not diagonally. Jumping is compulsory where possible. The winner is the first king to reach the two central opposite end squares.

Sold by the author for three years in South Australia and Victoria, and then subsequently under licence as "Criss Cross Checkers" in New Zealand

name: Kangaroo Creek
description:
A simple roll-and-move board game along a 100-space track, with bonuses and penalties based on eye safety. The winner is presumably the first to reach the final space, but the 'rules' consist of merely two sentences printed in the lower right of the board: "For 2-6 players. Throw the dice in turn and follow instructions."

The subtitle is "Can you SEE it safely through a day at Kangaroo Creek : throwing things, twirling things, sharp objects, eye injuries can cause blindness."

Bonuses include "You remember to use scissors without sharp points. Go ahead 6 spaces" and You throw a jellyfish in your friend's face. Go back 3 spaces."

Having no box or separate rules sheet, the game was probably produced for inclusion in showbags.
publishers: The Kangaroo Creek Gang company Pty. Ltd.

name: The Interregnum
description:
The Interregnum is a science fiction strategy board game set in a time of cold conflict between competing stellar kingdoms in a fallen Galactic Empire. The 2-to-6 players win by dominating the other kingdoms and earning the seat of Emperor, either by building a military hegemony or a powerful merchant empire. Both paths to success require careful planning, resource management and cunning strategy.

You will take the reins of one of the six Star Kingdoms that are part of the fallen Empire, ruled by the leaders that have the best claim to the throne after the late Emperor’s demise: The Duchess, The Princess, The Marquis, The Baron, The Caliph, and The Khan.

Your mission is to guide your people to the stars, secure vital resources to support your growth, make important decisions that will forge your Kingdom’s fate, and take back what’s rightfully yours – the title of Basileus, Emperor of Mankind.

The Interregnum is played on a modular map divided into hexagonal Sectors and Solar Systems. These are each further divided into 3 smaller tiles that allow for a better random distribution of Planets and Resources on the map and also keeping the scale Galactic yet detailed enough to be enjoyable.

The Interregnum gameplay is structured into Rounds that each represent a galactic standard year. Within one Round, all players have a Turn – meaning that a Round is further divided into 2 to 6 Turns.

Within a Turn, a player has 1 or 2 Actions (depending on their position on the ISC’s Turn/Dividend track). Actions are the following: Moving Fleets or Building. If a player has two actions he/she may move twice or move and build in the same turn.

During their Turn, a player may also do any of the following: trade once with the Galactic Market, repay their own debts, acquire loans, sell loans, buy a Technology card, use any number of cards, change their focus (but only when you are the Board Director). These are not considered Actions and can be done at any time during your turn after receiving your resource input.

While there is no actual combat in The Interregnum, players are required to use their Fleets in order to occupy Sectors and build structures inside them. Generally speaking, Fleets move on the between the Sectors – called Hyperlanes. They can also be “Parked” within a Sector (Deep space or Solar Orbit), but cannot move from Sector to Sector while Parked.

Building Fleets, Miner/Traders or Space Stations use up Resources (gained from Deep Space resource tiles or from inhabited planets) and Research points (gained from Citizen or Immigrant population)

The game ends when one of the players gathers 5 Reform Score (Mercantile or Hegemonic) through any means.

Once the end is triggered, your victory points are determined by your populations and assets. These are scored differently depending on which path you take when reforming your Star Kingdom into an Empire.

Hegemonic Empire path rewards military expansion while keeping the power in the hands of the few and alike. Citizen and Colonist Populations along with finished Space Stations add to your score, while Immigrants and Offworlders reduce your final score.
Merchant Empire path rewards population diversity and powerful Trader presence. Offworlders and Immigrants along with Trade Stations add to your score, and indeed Citizens and Colonists reduce your score.

-description from designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Commodity Speculation, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Stock Holding, Trading, Worker Placement

name: Tomaszow Mazowiecki 1939
description:
Game covers battle fought at the 6 September 1939 at Tomaszów Mazowiecki in the central Poland between Polish 13 Infantry Division and German 1st Armored Division. Polish positions near this town were the last major obstacle for the German armored units on their way to Warsaw. Thanks to the quick attack and diversion, Germans managed to break through the Polish defense in the one day, destroying most of the Polish units.

Game contains two scenarios: historical one and hypthetical one that includes some Polish units that didn't fought in the battle but could be used.

Game was published in the 34th issue of the "Taktyka i Strategia" magazine. It uses "B-35" battalion/company scale system.

name: Runerunners
description:
Runerunners is a loot-hunting skirmish board game set in a high fantasy world, with a twist. The game takes place in a 1920's "gangster" era where Prohibition is in full swing, making the use or trade of any item with magical properties against the law.

Players form small teams of heroic Runerunners to scour the streets of Sanctuary City, taking jobs to hunt down illegal artifacts, before rival teams can get them first. Teams are formed at random and each character will move about the board, exploring the town and looking for clues, but sometimes the easiest way to score an item is to steal from your enemies, or defeat them in battle and run off with all of their loot.

The game features large double-sided board tiles that can be arranged any way you wish, creating a different map every time you play. Your team of Heroes has taken a contract to search for contraband magical items. There will be a variety of different jobs or game modes, allowing you to have a regular battle game, or take an hold specific areas of the board, or search for clues to find special items. The rulebook will feature many different scenarios, and include instructions for how to create your own custom games as well.

Each board tile features a 9x9 grid for movement. Both players alternate activating one hero at a time, and each hero has a set number of actions where they can move, search for clues, and steal from or attack enemy heroes. Each Hero may only be activated once per game turn, and the game will typically last for 6 full turns. Whoever can score the most kills or gather the most loot before the game ends will win.

Runerunners is designed to be simple to learn, but also tactical and strategic, where each hero's unique skills can make or break a mission.

-description from designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Star Waves
description:
Star Waves is a tabletop card game that sends you on an awesome journey through space,
which requires basic resource management, strategy and dice luck. Beat your opponent
in completing a wild series of Quests and establish yourself as the most famous bounty hunter
in the solar system.



The game is portable, quick to set up and takes less than 5 minutes to learn.
Whip it out whenever you feel like exploring locations across the universe and experiencing
all sorts of amazing and mischievous events along the way.




• Choose a Quest Card. Each player gains their Starting Resources.




• Discover a new Location every turn. Then, roll a dice to find great treasure—or total disaster.
You never know what you encounter next and how it will play out.




• At the beginning of your turn, draw an Action Card.
Play them to sabotage your opponents, or accelerate your own progress.




• Win the game by completing all Quests, such as recovering Artifacts or earning Credits.


—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck

name: Beautiful Oblivion
description:
It's been 84 years since the great Kaiju Wars. Humanity has made many advancements and discoveries since that dark time. However no revelation was as ground breaking as the discovery of the islands. Beautiful Oblivion, one of three islands, was formed by the synthesis of earth's geography with the fallen enemy of our past and with it a treasure trove of new resources. Harvesting these resources changed our future and quite possibly sealed our fate. Because of our ignorance a new gate is now forming and it is only a matter of time before a breach occurs unleashing Kaijus hell bent on destroying us all.

In Beautiful Oblivion, a strategy board game for 2-5 players, you are the master engineer tasked with creating the next great mech (Krieger) to save us all. Your team of engineers are sent out to harvest the resources needed in order to construct such modern marvels. These new resources come with a cost though, as over harvesting only accelerates the end game.

During the course of play, you'll gain points by using those resources to build or upgrade your Krieger. Choose to follow a blueprint for additional points or shoot from the hip on your design. All the while, navigating world events that can help you or stop you dead in your tracks. The points you earn translate to the strength of your Krieger. Building bigger is stronger, but much slower to do. A light upgraded Krieger might do the trick but will it be strong enough. Either way you'll need to hurry, once the gate is inevitably opened, ending the game, only completed Kriegers will fight for glory against a variety of Kaijus for the possibility to gain bonus points. The player with the most points wins the game.

-description from designer

name: Rank & File
description:
A game played on a board bearing illustrations of 48 black and red playing cards (in a 6 × 8 grid), with Aces, then Kings at the top, down to 9s at the foot. There are numbered circles along each edge of the board, which is green / cream in colour.

It was published in England in the 1920s by Unicorn Products Ltd.

There is a copy in London's V&A (Victoria & Albert) Museum, as part of their Museum of Childhood collection.

Rules and other playing accessories are not known.

name: Villain Among Heroes
description:
With over 54 comic book cards featuring all original artwork, 38 powers to gain & allowing up to 8 players, there is plenty of fun to be had in Palm City. The game manual also features a Palm City History section you can fill out that keeps track of the winners and their game stats. So family and friends can forever remember your victory... Hero or Villain.


HOW TO PLAY



Players will roam the Palm City streets on this 8x8 grid gameboard, using powers they gain to complete city events. At the start of the game all players will be competing against one another as heroes. Frantically moving around the board trying to complete city events before other players beat them to it. Each of the 54 city events are original and will make this city feel alive. City events could be anything from saving a family in a burning home, stopping a meteor from crashing into Palm City, or helping the mayor's cat out of a tree. Each city event requires certain powers to complete though, so players will also be competing to obtain genetic mutations around the board that grant powers. Palm City is full of stuff happening where your help is always needed but you know what they say. Live long enough... and you'll find yourself the villain. At any point in the game, a player may attack another player. The moment a hero player causes damage to another hero player, they become a villain. There is no going back from this. At this point in the game, your only objective as a villain, is to eliminate all other players using the powers you've gained. Each power in the game has a unique ability and with 38 of them, make sure you build your character carefully. All of this happens within a player's turn and a turn consists of two phases.
Phase 1: Move
Phase 2: Complete Action

Actions that can be completed include: Completing a city event, gaining a genetic mutation, trading & discarding genetic mutations, applying powers, or attacking another player.

Win the game as a hero by completing city events found on comic book cards and getting your city respect to 100 before any other player.

Win the game as a villain by using your powers to bring the health of other players to zero, destroying them all, and taking over Palm City.

This is a large game featuring a lot of content. At first it might feel overwhelming, but the manual should easily guide you through the process of learning how to setup & play. Once you learn, you'll never want to leave Palm City.


GAME STORY



You and your neighbors notice something break apart in the sky outside the city. All of you gather and travel to the wreckage. You discover a glowing purple material. Something never before seen. It calls to you. It calls to each of you. One by one you all touch it. Everyone feels different. Everyone feels powerful. You realize each time you touch it, your genetics are mutating.
You're becoming stronger. You all decide it's best to keep this wreckage site a secret. The only question though, is what you'll do with your new powers. Will you become palm city's greatest hero... or its most feared villain?

Welcome to Palm City.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Player Elimination, Trading, Variable Player Powers

name: Bloody Big Balkan Battles!
description:
For almost 600 years, from the fabled shores of the Bosphorus, the Ottoman Sultans ruled over a vast land in Europe, stretching from the Mediterranean to the Danube. Sometimes enlightened, sometimes cruel, the rule of the Chalifs of Islam had steadily receded before the fury of national ideals and the rising might of European imperialism promoted by bayonet and capital. And yet it still survived, still stubbornly clinging to Balkan territories rich in history, industry and population. The “Great Patient” seemed to spite Greece, Bulgaria, Serbia and Montenegro; the states created by bloody struggle by those who once were termed the gavur rayahs of the Sultan. They saw with worry the growing appetite of aggressive great powers, all making claims to what they saw as their just inheritance. And then by coup and counter-coup, the fall of a Red Sultan, and the rise of a Committee, the rapaciousness of a young Great Power, and the entente of two old foes, the Balkan states saw danger and opportunity and struck. In the span of just a month of the greatest battles seen in Europe since 1871, the dream of Osman was shattered.

This scenario supplement for Bloody Big Battles! permits you to re-fight those great battles that saw the end of the Ottoman Empire in Europe and the formation of the basic modern borders in the Balkans. Nine scenarios cover some of the most important battles of the First Balkan War, covering the campaigns of Greece, Serbia and Bulgaria against the Ottoman Empire which would drive the Empire to the very gates of Istanbul/Constantinopole/Tsarigrad. Five scenarios then cover the Second Balkan War, the conflict between the successful allies which pitted Serbia, Montenegro and Greece against Bulgaria over the legacy of the Ottoman Empire.

Each scenario provides a distinct operational and tactical puzzle for war-gamers to resolve. From straightforward assaults against fortified positions like the First Battle of Chataldja, to complex double envelopments like the Battle of Lule Burgas, from the extensive broad fronts of the Battle of Bregalnitza, to the knife fight in close quarters of the Battle of Bizani. There are small scenarios easily played in one or two hours, like the Battle of Dioran (the actual First battle of Dioran), and more substantive scenarios like the Battle of Kumanovo, still playable in an evening. There are battles fought on rolling hills and plains, like the Battle of Kirkkilise, and battles fought in some of the worst ground people have ever thought of fighting each other in an organized manner, like the Battle of Kalimanchi.

You will see how these wars where similar and how they differed from The Great War. You will understand the crucial role of terrain as a military variable and grapple with key decisions of force to task distributions in an unforgiving strategic operational and tactical environment. You will see the last glory days of the bayonet charge, and the opening bloody howl of modern artillery. There is challenge to satisfy all types of war-gamers.

An included overview of the historical events and biographies of many of the commanders whose roles you reprise on the table-top will provide you with the background to give you an inkling of the vast stakes and human drama associated with these battles. An annotated bibliography provides you both with the sources used to build the scenarios and further reading to enrich your understanding and experience. A figure guide helps you find suitable ways to represent the armies in almost all scales of miniature war-gaming.

A struggle for a vast future awaits! Take command and see how history was forged!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: CatFish!
description:
CatFish is LIVE! https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/forsakengames/catfish-0...

CatFish is an Improvisational-Storytelling Party Game which takes place over the course of a ridiculous dinner date. In this Cat-Eat-Cat world, if you're not the predator, you're the prey.

A group of nefarious cons and cheats, known simply as The Catfish, have found their new target - a cute, little, naive internet dater - their perfect Patsy.

These cheats have all put on quite the charade in order to collar the Patsy's attention while chatting them up on their favorite dating site www.CatFishDating.com - Now they are all in the unenviable position of having to back up their outlandish claims in person. They must fight tooth-and-nail and summon every bit of charm, wit, and creativity they have in order to win the affection of The Patsy.

In CatFish! The Patsy will play as the moderator, judge and acting coach of the game, while the Catfish will play as improvisational actors.

In this dinner-date of fictitious personalities and backstories, the Catfish that attains the most Appeal Points over three-courses of unadulterated lies and manipulation, will be chosen as the winner
of the game!

They'll do so by masterfully Drafting the Claim Cards and Hobby Cards that they think they can weave into the most captivating backstory - and then whimsically acting out the character that they just created in order to impress the Patsy and match what they're Looking For in a mate.

It won't be easy, because both the Patsy and the other Catfish will relentlessly try to poke holes in their stories, and question their identities. Those Catfish that are best able to think on their feet
and Improvise the details of their backstory will go far.

Who will win the Patsy's heart, and who will be outed as a filthy stinkin' Catfish!?

name: Snotnose High
description:
Snotnose High is a co-op role-playing board game where 2-4 players take on the roles of typical high schoolers - the Jock, the Nerd, the Gamer, the Goth, the Black Guy, and the Dyke.
Their mission? Rescue the self-proclaimed-hottest-girl-at-school Britney Blonde who's recently been kidnapped by the evil Professor Blender.
Their mood? Pissed.
Their genitalia? Hardened (with the notable exception of the Dyke.)
Within his blender, Professor Blender has concocted a menagerie of unique monsters, different each time the game is played, to stop our heroes. Will he prevail?

Players will travel across Snotville, an island situated between the mystical lands of Atlantis, Middle Earth, and the People's Republic of Kuwait. Landmarks at Snotville consists of Snotnose High itself, the rival highschool Harvord High, the Suburbs where everyone lives, the Arcade where we can all play games within the game, and the History Hut, a bar frequented exclusively by prominent figures of history, like Albert Einstein, Charles Darwin, and John Cena.

Along the way, they will encounter, count, and account for countless Count Dracula-like creatures, all with a different head, body, and pair of legs, as blended in Professor Blender's blender.
But they'll have to hurry - the evil Professor intends to blend Britney herself!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Turn Order: Time Track, Variable Player Powers

name: Vexed
description:
Vexed is a turn-based dice game for 2 or more players. The object of the game is to become the first player to score 200 points by rolling dice that match those already in the central pool. After each successful roll the player must decide whether to collect their score so far or risk losing everything in the hope of scoring more.

As long as a player keeps matching with dice in the central pool they can keep rolling and accumulating points. However, if they push their luck too far and roll a die that doesn't match with anything they score zero and all of their previously matched dice are returned to the central pool, leaving a bumper scoring opportunity for the next player.

-description from publisher

name: Timo
description:
Three policemen try to catch 3 vagabonds. Figures are caught, if they are encircled, so that they are not able to move. Caught figures are eliminated from the game. Movement is on the black spaces of the game board, straight in any direction as much spaces as possible. First the 3 policemen are moved, then the 3 vagabonds.

The player with the last figure on the game plan wins the game.

—user summary

name: Ruthless 86
description:
Scorpion Supreme is dead and the Subcommanders in the Scorp Corps are staking their claim to the title.

In Ruthless 86, you take on the role of a brash, outrageous 80s cartoon villain, like steampunk pirate Molly Roger, the enigmatic and unknowable Sylence, or Tyrannoczar, a super soldier cloned from the DNA of history’s greatest rulers plus a T-Rex.
Prove to your rivals that you deserve to inherit the Scorpion Supreme title from your mysteriously departed leader. Win the loyalty of a legion of disposable Scorpion Soldiers and send them on Missions around the World. Expand and fortify your HexQuarters, your remote lair. Commandeer your evil organization’s Doomsday Devices. Stab backs, 86 your enemies, and, most of all, get Ruthless.

Ruthless 86 is a dice builder worker placement game. Recruit and deploy Troopers to battle stations in your remote HexQuarters, or combine six on a die to form a unit and deploy them on Missions across the World. Successful Missions expand your reach and Fortify your HexQuarters. When you feel you've built up a strong enough army, deploy to The Ranks and attempt to be the first to rise to the top and become the new Scorpion Supreme.

—description from the designer

name: Tuttiludi
description:
This is a compilation of games, played with a spinner or roulette.

1. Bilder-Roulette (Picture-Roulette)
The 32 picture cards (animals) are are dealt up among the players. After the spin of the roulette, the indicated card is dicarded of. The first player to discard all his cards wins the game.

2. Buchstaben-Roulette (Letter-Roulette)
Before playing, the players chose a number of topics (city, country, ...). To beginn the game the spinner is moved to select a letter. Then time runs. Every player has to find words for the chosen topics with the indicated letter.

3. Zahlen-Roulette (Numbers-Roulette)
The goal of the came can be to get the highest or lowest numbers or to get a connecting line on a grid of numbers.

4. Karten-Roulette (Card-Roulette)
This game is played with a standard deck of 32 playing cards. The players buy cards for one coin a card from the game master. Then he spins the roulette 5 times. On the first spin the winning card gets gets the player two coins. On the next spins the players win 4, 6, 8 and 10 coins.

5. Immer mit der Ruhe
This is a standard Pachisi game, played with a spinner insead of a die. In addition the spanner may be used to determine which color is to be moved, so the players dont get their turns in regular intervals.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Racing, Word Game
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Urbin-Spiel
description:
The journey begins and ends in Berlin. Movement is determined by a die. In some cities events hinder or help the players. The first player to return to Berlin wins the game.

This game was published as a promotional game for "Urbin" shoe polish between the first and second world war.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Depression
description:
Play through a day of life for someone suffering from depression. Work to complete a series of increasingly difficult tasks, all while fighting the lack of motivation that comes with depression.
The goal of Depression is to complete six goals of increasing difficulty.

On each turn, you will discard cards from your hand either to use special abilities, or to complete a Goal card. You will end your turn by refilling your hand to five cards.

Completed Goal cards offer you help in completing future Goals. If you draw a Depression card, you must place it on top of a completed Goal card. To clear a Depression card, you must discard three cards of different types, or five cards total from your hand.

You win the game if you complete all six Goal cards. You lose the game immediately if the Draw Deck runs out before you have completed six goals.

-description from designer

name: Butterfly Effect
description:
Butterfly Effect is a cooperative card game with the theme of butterfly effect.

Each player must cooperate with other players to tie themselves together with the items that were issued to the start and end given.

Please enjoy yourself with the very small opportunities that are normally thought to be negligible, but eventually become big things that can not be ignored.

name: Fast Factory
description:
Although Fast Factory , six cars will be shipped within the time limit, becoming a dwarf "Sashigoin" dripping somewhere.

If we do not ship 6 carriages within the time limit, everyone is game over.

In addition, "Sakigoin" are actually qualified and work at the factory. Let's ship more cars and parts than other dwarfs and win the Best Dodgers Award this month!

There are "tires", "bodies", "engines", "interior", "exterior", "options" on the card.

Among them, three types of cards, tires, body, and engine with color are called "key parts", and at minimum this card can be shipped as it will be a moving car if it is complete.

The upper three white cards can increase the added value of the car by installing it in the car being assembled.

There are two places to assemble cars, one for each "key parts", you can place any number of cards except key parts.

Players put out the cards in turn, and if all six key parts can be shipped and shipped, the game is clear.

The parts are the finest items (?) With which the dwarfs refer to various cars. Let's make fun cars with chaos that jumped over the genre!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Open Drafting, Take That, Turn Order: Time Track, Worker Placement

name: Scrimmage IV
description:
A hex-and-counter simulation of American football, focused on portraying only a portion of a full game. The "I go, you go" rules cover movement, collisions (resolved on a "CRT"), forward passes, and hand-offs. Each counter represents one football player defined by two factors: power and movement points. The simplified football rules do not cover fumbles or penalties.

Scrimmage IV was published in the first issue of JagdPanther magazine which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

—user summary

...a whole [football] game would take months [to play], but for a quick series or a key play, here is a fun way to waste an hour.

—description from the designer
publishers: (Web published), Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: The Battle of Cowpens
description:
On January 17, 1781, Banastre Tareltons' [sic] Brigade of Light Infantry broke cover shortly after dawn, and faced a low hill sloping to a crest about 1/2 a mile away. A few hundred yards away were the American Rangers, the three light infantry companies that formed the pickets of the American position. Behind them, about half way up the slop stood 300 American Militiamen, none of them eager to face the enemy. But at the crest stood the American line. Six hundred regulars, they were the heart of the American force. Wearing bright blue uniforms, they stood in straight lines measured carefully by their officers. At the crest of the hill stood Morgan, the swashbuckling American light infantry commander. The British had chased him for two weeks, and now they had him, for he could go no further.

This game is at best an experiment in muzzle-loading warfare. If it works out, and I feel it has, we shall produce a line of such games.

—description from the publisher

A game depicting the American Revolutionary War battle of Cowpens. The game does not define its time or unit scales.

American units, except for cavalry, are deployed on the map. Cavalry units being off-map but are allowed to enter at any time. British units enter the map on designated turns during the first nine turns of the game. The turn order starts with one side firing, moving, and then designating bayonet assaults. This is followed by a defensive fire phase, after which the bayonet assaults are resolved. The opponent then executes the same phases which constitutes a completed game turn.

A CRT is used for combat resolution. Unit rankings include an attack factor, defense factor, movement factor, and range. Victory conditions are based on points received for destruction of units, ranging from 3 points for destruction of a militia unit to 10 points for destruction of a cannon unit. You win by scoring 10 or more victory points than your opponent. A margin of less than 10 victory points results in a draw.

The Battle of Cowpens was published in the first issue of JagdPanther magazine. While the rules and counters for the game were re-released in a 2012 PDF reprint of the magazine, the game's map could not be located and the publisher has asked for a scan of the map from anyone who owns the original edition.

—user summary
publishers: (Web published), Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: PanzerBlitz Unlimited
description:
A set of expansion rules, units, and scenarios published in 1973 in the first issue of JagdPanther magazine. The expansion is currently available in PDF form as Amarillo Design Bureau has digitally rereleased all fifteen JagdPanther issues.

Rules revisions address the rules on fire and movement, close assault, smoke rounds, and artillery attacks (without spotters).

New units depict forces of Finland, Belgium, Norway, Poland, Italy, France, Britain, Japan, and the United States. Additional German and Russian units are also added to the game, along with units for Korean War scenarios. The new units are supplemented by research notes and tables of organization and equipment.

Finally, the expansion includes 35 scenarios set during World War II and the Korean War, with majority of these depicting conflicts in the European Theater. Hypothetical scenarios include a post-war conflict between Patton and Montgomery (!) and a 1955 "border skirmish" between British and Russian forces.

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
publishers: Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Hide & Seek
description:
Hide & Seek is a turn-based game.
Seek raises a question against one person's Hide and will chase it...

If you can locate and locate where you are, Seek Player wins. But Hide Player answers with lie only once to a question ...

Hide, Interwoven with bluff, run away. Seek out the other person and see through the truth.

Come and enjoy the strategy inference game to stimulate the brain cells.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Maze, Memory, Party Game
mechanics: Area Movement, Betting and Bluffing, Trick-taking

name: Foxbat & Phantom: Komet Und Meteor
description:
Note regarding capitalization in title: Although the word "und" in Komet Und Meteor is technically not supposed to be capitalized, that is how the word was used by the publisher.

This game imagines a catastrophe of sufficient scale (say, the failure of the Normandy Landings) to cause a massive shift of Ground and Naval Forces to the more successful Pacific theater. The Air Forces, finally granted independence from the US Army, carry the burden alone in Europe. The more familiar aircraft of 1943 are gone. Only the experimental Mustang and Spitfire fighters and the bombers are left. In the place of the P47s and Bf109s, Europe is criss-crossed by High-Altitude BV-155 and Jet powered F80's.

Komet Und Meteor is a variant to a favorite game of ours, Foxbat and Phantom. We recommend the use of a Spitfire [SPI] Counter set for the piston engine aircraft. K&M grew from the experimental Me262 Flight Chart given in JP#3. This chart can be, of course, used in this game.

—description from the publisher

This variant for SPI's Cold War tactical-jet-combat simulation Foxbat & Phantom was published in the fourth issue of JagdPanther magazine. Rules are added for piston-engined aircraft and rocket-powered fighters to allow players to recreate late-war World War II air battles.

Flight charts are included for a number German and Allied aircraft. The German aircraft portrayed in the variant include the Ta-152F-4 radar interceptor, Ba-349G rocket-powered interceptor, He-177A-5 heavy bomber, Ar-234C-3 jet bomber, BV-155C-6 high altitude interceptor, Me-163C-1A rocket-powered interceptor, and the He-162-A2 jet fighter. Allied aircraft include the Meteor, F-80C-3, F-84B-2, and P59C jet fighters; B17-H, B24-N, A26-E, and B29-E piston-engined bombers; P-51F and Spitfire X piston-engined fighters; and the Soviet B2b rocket-powered interceptor. Six scenarios are included. These cover situations such as intercepting bombers, high altitude recon, and fighter duels.

Komet Und Meteor is currently available in PDF format as Amarillo Design Bureau has digitally rereleased all issues of JagdPanther magazine.

—user summary
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II
publishers: (Web published), Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Geisterstunde
description:
The aim of the game is to be the first to discard all his cards.
For this purpose, 6 ghost cards are distributed to each player from the mixed deck of cards and the remaining cards face down (as a draw pile) placed in the middle of the table. The top card is drawn and placed face up on the table. It forms the "Start" card. Now, players must try to discard their cards by placing one of their 6 cards (which has at least one more colored ghost on it than the "Start" card) on the "Start" card. If this is possible, it is the turn of the next player, who now tries to place one of his cards on the new top card. If you do not have a matching card, you must draw a card from the draw pile and, if possible, place it. If this is not possible, the next player's turn. When the draw pile is used up, the cards laid out (except for the top card) are shuffled and placed on the table as a new draw pile.

—user summary

name: TANKS: The Modern Age – West German Marder Tank Expansion
description:
Marder Tank
Marders are a great light weapon platform. Rapid Fire (5) gives it a good Anti-Air gun built in giving it a roll in most West German Platoons, especially if you know your opponent has Hinds in their collection. You also have the ability to mount a Milan missile to it using the Mounted Milan card. This is a interesting upgrade because it gives you a good Anti-Tank Attack when you need it and if you already have that covered in your platoon, you can choose not to add it and save yourself 2 points. On top of all that the Marder has Scout, an ability that lets it double the Defence bonus it normally would get from Cover.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Jumble Poker
description:
This self-published game is a deck of 52 letter cards plus an instructions card. Its play is similar to draw poker without any bidding: 5 cards per person are dealt; each may discard any number of cards and draw to replace them; the one who forms the longest word wins the hand.

—user summary

name: Nate's Word Poker
description:
The 52 cards in this game each have a letter and a point value, with rarer letters having more points. This game plays like draw poker without betting: each player is dealt a hand of 5 cards and may discard and replace up to 4 of them. Players score for the points on the cards making up the word they spell from their hand; longest word gets a 3-point bonus, with 3 more for using all their cards. The first player to reach a total of 100 points (or other agreed total) wins the game.

—user summary

name: LocoMotive
description: Your train ride home from work takes an unexpected turn when suddenly a fork in the tracks appears out of thin air, your train makes an unexpected turn on these new tracks and you find yourself extremely disoriented. Everything begins rapidly changing colors right before your eyes, you quickly realize the train is going in circles around this psychedelic new railway. Every lap you see the one path home slowly fading away. Hurry to the front of the train to turn back toward reality before the path home disappears forever.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Take That

name: Storage Auction Showdown
description:
A streamlined open bidding auction game with unique player powers and hidden information.

Can you best manage your cash, buy the right items, and play to your unique strengths to become master of the storage auction?

In Storage Auction Showdown, players are competing in a storage auction. The auction consists of a series of storage units being sold off, one after the other. Storage units have a randomized variety of items inside. Items come in 8 different types, including several special unique items. Each item scores you points and/or utilizes an ability. Some items will be hidden from you during an auction, so you’ll need to decide how much of your cash you want to risk bidding on the unknown. The player willing to pay the most for a storage unit gets all its items, whether those are treasures or trash. At the end of the game, the player with the most points wins!

Storage Auction Showdown features unique player powers and hidden information, is quick to learn and play, and has high replayability. It also has a significant amount of luck, is family friendly, no player elimination, and minimal downtime.

-description from designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Cryptid Clash
description:
Cryptid Clash! is a fast-paced, two-player card game that features clean, simple rules and uncomplicated game mechanics. Each player plays groups of Cryptids from their hand that battle in one of three different environments. Winners keep defeated Cryptids as Victory Points. The winner is determined after several rounds of play.

—description from the publisher

name: Bezzerwizzer Bricks: Rock
description:
A small 60 card quiz game about rock music.
Also has a category tile to make this an expansion for the big Bezzerwizzer games.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: The Crazy Horse Game
description:
This game can be played in 5 minutes. You will need a die and a PanzerBlitz or Blitzkrieg board or a blank hex sheet. It simulates an Indian boy on a pony hunting a Buffaloe. [sic]

—description from the publisher

This simple hex-and-counter game has only two counters, the Indian and the "Buffaloe." The Indian player wins by killing the buffalo. The buffalo player wins by goring the Indian boy or his pony. There are three different types of buffalo (calf, cow, and bull) distinguished by a Power Factor number, which also represents how much damage the buffalo can sustain. Terrain types include trees, slopes, and ditches.

Published in issue #2 of JagdPanther magazine which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

—user summary
publishers: Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: PanzerBlitz: MGB – The Game of Amphibious Warfare
description:
An expansion that adds amphibious warfare to PanzerBlitz. MGB features: six scenarios covering both the Pacific and European theaters; eight maps featuring coastlines or islands; two counter sheets with new units for the German, Japanese, Italian, British, and American forces (including U.S. Marines and British Commandos); rules covering ship movement, naval gunfire, and torpedoes.

Published in issue #3 of JagdPanther magazine which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

—user summary
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Nautical, Wargame, World War II
publishers: (Web published), Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: RN: Naval Superiority Game of World War II
description:
This Game attempts to simulate the conflict between the Royal Navy and the Kriegsmarine during WWII. Also included are the ships projected in Admiral Raeder's "Z" plan before the War.

—description from the publisher

A ship-to-ship miniatures game of surface combat using written orders for movement and firing. There are four scenarios. Statistics are included for over 30 classes of ships.

Published in issue #5 of JagdPanther magazine which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau.

—user summary
categories: Miniatures, Nautical, Wargame, World War II
publishers: (Web published), Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Once Upon A Time: The Source
description:
Promotional card.
Based on the Comics and Games store "The Source" in Roseville, MN.
Type: Place, Interrupt.

An interrupt that adds Comic & Game store, The Source, to the story.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Party Game, Real-time

name: Beat The Bookie
description:
Beat The Bookie is the highly entertaining, sociable and strategic board and card game depiction of a day at the races.

Celebrating a race days three main characters; the Bookie, the Punter and the Horse Owner, players can purchase and sell horses, win prize money and gamble on the Bookie's odds on each of the eight races at the race meet.

The aim of the game is to collect the highest value combination of trophies from the eight races. Trophies are awarded to the player who makes the most profit from each race, either through prizemoney, bet winnings, payouts from players' cards or through horse sales.

There are three types of trophies on offer. Races 1-3 are known as Maiden Races, and are the least valuable. Trophies awarded for these races are bronze in colour and worth only 1 point each.
Prize money for winning owners in the three maiden races are 1x the Profits (100k for a win, 75k for second place and 50k for third).

Races 4-6 are known as Handicap races, and are more valuable. Trophies awarded for each of these three races are silver in colour and worth 2 points each. Winning horse owners get 2 x the profits if their horses finish top 3 (200k for a win, 150k for second and 100k for third).

Finally, races 7 and 8 are known as the Feature Races and are the most valuable, worth three points. Prizemoney is tripled for these two races (300k for a win, 225k for second place and 150k for third). The trophies awarded for these two races are gold in colour.

Beat The Bookie can be played with 2-8 players. At the beginning of a race meet, a player is nominated to act as the Bookie. The Bookie is a banker of sorts, and is responsible for auctioning the horses, collecting money, calling the horses, laying the horse cards on the track and settling any successful or unsuccessful bets. The Bookie also assigns the trophies are the end of each of the 8 races, but counting up the winnings of each player. The Bookie can also play as a player, but must keep their cash wallet and assets separate from that of the main 'bank'.

Once a Bookie has been assigned, each player is provided with 300k of Beat The Bookie currency. This is to form each players 'cash wallet'. Player are also given six Bet Slip cards, which depict the names and pictures of each of the horses in the field. These cards are used to place the players' bets.

The Bookie then conducts the pre-meet auction, and auctions off each of the six horses in the race, with a reserve price of 100k. Players may or may not bid on the horses, with the successful/highest bidder awarded an ownership card for the particular horse bought. The new owner must keep the ownership card until he/she elects to sell the horse to another player or back to the Bookie.

Once the pre-meet auction has concluded, all players must draw a players card from the left hand panel of the game board. If a player owns a horse, they must draw an Owners Card, which features any fees due or payable to/from the Bookie for their horse. Even if a player owns multiple horses, they need only draw one Owners Card. If a player does not own any horses, they must draw a Punters Card, which offers a special or exotic for the upcoming race. Finally, the Bookie must draw a Bookies Card, which features the odds for the upcoming race. Players can then bet on the odds provided by the Bookies Card, by overturning their Bet Slip Card to reveal the name of the horse they intend to bet on, and placing their chosen bet amount on top of the Bet Slip Card.

Once all bets are placed and accepted by the Bookie, the Bookie then shuffles the Horse Card deck. There are six cards for each of the six different horses. The Bookie then lays the cards out in order of the Horse, with each horse advancing once space down the game board each time it is drawn. The Bookie draws all the Horse Cards until there is a winner, a second place getter and a third place getter.

At the conclusion of the race. The Bookie pays out the prize money to the winning owners. If a horse, that finishes first, second or third, is not owned, no prizemoney is awarded in respect of that horse. For races 1-3 (Maiden Races), the Bookie awards 1x the Profits. For races 4-6 (Handicap Races) the Bookie awards 2x the Profits and for races 7 and 8 (Feature Races), the Bookie awards 3 x the Profits.

The Bookie must then payout any prizemoney owed under Punters Cards. Once done so, or if no prizemoney is awarded, the Punter must place his Punters Card back under the pile.

Once prizemoney and punters payouts are awarded, the Bookie either pays out or collects on players' bets on the calculation provided for by the Bookies Card. If the Bookies Card showed odds of 4:1, and the player bet 10k, the Bookie must pay the player 40k. Unsuccesful bets are collected by the Bookie and placed back in the 'bank'.

When all prize money and bet money is awarded, players must count their profits. A trophy (bronze for Maiden Races, silver for Handicap Races and gold for Feature Races) is provided to the player with the most profit from that race. The player keeps the trophy with their cash wallet for counting at the end of the game.

Once trophies are awarded, all players draw their players cards again ahead of the next race.

At the end of the game, the players then count the value of their trophies. Bronze trophies are worth 1 point, Silvers are worth 2, and Golds are worth 3. A Player could win the game by not having won any feature races. Conversely, a player might head into race 7 not having won any races for the entire meet, and could win races 7 and 8 and win the game.

Players can trade their horses with other players at the conclusion of any races for an agreed price. Horses are valuable as they provide an alternative revenue stream. Horses drawn frequently in races may be worth selling, as chance would mean it's unlikely to win again. Players who do not purchase horses at the initial pre-meet auction may wish to purchase horses ahead of the more valuable Feature Races.

A player is eliminated if they are declared bankrupt and have no more money or horses to play.

—description from the designer

name: Der Elektro-Kühlschrank
description:
Each player has his own track from space 1 to space 100, the fridge. Movement is determined by a die. The first player to reach space 100, wins the game. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the player.

This game was published about 1929-1931 to promote electric fridges in Germany.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Les saisons
description:
Les saisons is a loto game base game. Each player has a board. At his turn, he choose a hidden tile. If it fits his board, he can plug it and play again, if not an other player plays. The first to finish his board wins.

—user summary

name: Das verwunschene Schloss
description: The players start at space 1. Movement is determined by a die. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the player. The first player to reach the treasure vault on space 50 wins the game.

name: La main dans le sac
description:
Each player has the alphabet in raised letters in a plastic bag hanging around his neck and with two openings on the sides.

A card representing a word is drawn and the player must be the first to compose this word in front of us by leaving the good letters one by one. Bad letters count in negative.

name: Word for Word
description:
Contents:

54 cards, each with a letter and point value, or a wild card
Pencil
Score Pad
Carrying Case


The deck is dealt out to make a face-down hand for each player. For a turn a player reveals the top card of their hand and either plays it to the table, or uses it plus cards already on the table to form a word, keeping all the cards used. After all cards are played the player with the highest total score for the cards they gathered wins.

There are also detailed rules for a solitaire game, whose object is to go through the deck in a similar manner and use all the cards to form words.

(The rules say "for two players" for the regular game, but this is playable just as easily with more than two. The older game Logomachy has similar game play and deck size, and it allows for more players, though it recommends teams for an even numbers of players, and two decks for six or more.)

—user summary

name: Dirty Pooch
description:
Dirty Pooch is a strategic card game that allows flea flinging amongst your opponents’ dogs. Who says this has to be realistic? The premise of the game is to get rid all of your initial fleas via action cards by either flinging them to your best friend–to-be-friendemy or discarding them back to wherever fleas come from. You can either try to win the entire the game by being the first owner to get rid of all their dogs’ fleas or obstruct your friend from getting rid of their dogs’ fleas. This game can be as nice or mean as you wish for it to be.

—description from the designer
categories: Animals, Card Game, Humor, Party Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Take That

name: Cadbury's Space Game
description:
A spin and move game produced by the Cadbury Chocolate company in Australia.

The game sees players starting on earth and traversing a path to the moon. Along the way a number of detours can be encountered as well as things like cosmic rays, sun spots and magnetic deviations that will cause delays in reaching the moon. The winner is the first to reach the moon.

The game is similar in graphics to another space game of the 1950's called A trip to the Moon by the English chocolate company Fry's.
The promotional game was included in an Cadbury showbag from the Adelaide Royal Show in the 1950's. Showbags are a very popular and distinctive feature of Australian shows (the Australian term for fairs or carnivals) and confectionery and toy manufacturers are keen to promote products, samples and brands in their Showbags.

—user summary

name: Trivial Pursuit: Volume III
description:
This is it, the Genus Edition successor to the original Trivial Pursuit game — and still the one to beat! Because Volume III covers all those challenging subject areas that let you prove you're a real know-it-all!

How are you on Geography, Entertainment, History, Art & Literature, Science & Nature and Sports & Leisure? These questions and answers will tackle your brain and tickle your fancy. So join all those trivia buffs who've helped make Trivial Pursuit the best-selling trivia board game of all time!

Think you've got all the answers? Then prove it!

—description from the back of the box

name: Optio
description:
Optio is a quick-play set of miniatures rules for Ancient battles. It's played on a square grid - so no measuring - and eschews dice or other randomizers for a purely deterministic combat system. It's thus "chesslike" in a sense.

The name comes from optio, the title for a centurion's second-in-command in the Roman army.

name: Bumpers
description:
Bumpers is a board game that incorporates card counting, collusion, competition, bluffing, and risk taking. A complete Bumpers set includes 1 game board, 12 game pieces (called bumpers), and a 52-card deck.

The 12 bumpers are divided among 4 teams, which each team starting with 1 large bumper and 2 small bumpers (3 bumpers per team, 4 teams, so 12 bumpers total). The board displays a series of spaces connected by lines; bumpers move to and from said spaces along said lines.

The goal of the game is to be the player the holds the only large bumper on the board for 1 full turn. No bumper can pass any other bumper, large bumpers can only land on (capture) other large bumpers, and small bumpers cannot capture or be captured any other bumpers.

Players take turns drawing a card from the draw deck and playing cards from their hand. Players then move their bumpers based on the cards they played, corralling, controlling, and capturing their opponents' large bumpers.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Memory, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Take That

name: Chanciee
description:
Chanciee is a 4 dice based game with a mathematical thinking and luck roll factor! The game is very simple to play and perfect for kids, teens, and parents.

Parents who want to demonstrate to the kids how easy to calculate numbers and think about combinations trough choice, luck, and thoughts!

All you need to do is roll dice and make your own choice how many dice would you like to roll. You will be surprised, how different thinking bring different outcomes!

—description from the publisher

name: Pokémon TCG: Lost Thunder Expansion
description:
Pokémon TCG: Sun & Moon—Lost Thunder is the name given to the eigth main expansion of cards from the Sun & Moon Series of the Pokémon Trading Card Game (the Sun & Moon Era in Japan).
The expansion includes 236 cards.

Theme Decks: Blazing Volcano (FireGrass), Storm Caller (Lightning)
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Crystal Stones
description:
In the Age of Dragons, comes four to the land of crystals.
Player get to play the role of one of the dragons collecting crystals. The objective is collecting 20 crystal stone without losing all six health points. First player gets 20 crystal stones wins.

Every dragon get started with two same colored crystals and one black die representing six health points. Each turn players roll 5 pink dice determining the type of action they can take. Dragons get one action on their turns.

name: Perpetual Anarchy
description:
Perpetual Anarchy is a game for the "2019 Two-Player PnP Design Contest".



OVERVIEW
Perpetual Anarchy is a strategic 2-player game using a standard 52-card deck. Players are states in a world of international anarchy, attempting to impose their supremacy on the other state. Choose the money allocation between immediate benefit with armaments and wealth and long-lasting benefit with military and civil technologies. Finally, establish the state policy: focus on producing, defensing or attacking.

Perpetual Anarchy features bluff, push-your-luck and simultaneous action selection.

GAME THEORY
Perpetual Anarchy was inspired by game theory researches, especially by the PhD student in political science Nathan Alexander Sears' article: Simulating War and Peace in IR Theory with a Classroom Game

COMPONENTS
1 scoring board
1 technology board
28 cards (from an ordinary 52-card deck)
6 tokens

SETUP
Each player has 3 personal tokens (one for the scoring board and two for the technology board) and 14 cards in hand:

11 numbered cards: two 0s (10s), two 1s, two 2s, two 3s, one 4s, one 5, one 6.
3 action cards: attack (King), defense (Jack), production (Queen).


GAMEPLAY
The game is divided in multiple rounds. In each round, there are three phases. At the end of a round, players pick up all of their played cards back into their hands ready for immediate re-use.

Phase 1: Card Playing
Players place 5 face-down card in a row on the table simultaneously. From left to right:

1. the action card (attack, defense or production);
2. it is a numbered card representing wealth allocation;
3. it is a numbered card representing armament allocation;
4. it is a numbered card representing civil tech allocation;
5. it is a numbered card representing military tech allocation.

There are some restrictions on playing numbered cards:

Each state has a budget of 7 billion per round, so they have to choose how to allocate it: the sum of number of the player’s cards has to be 7 or less. Unused budget is lost.
The maximum military tech allocation is 2, so it is possible to play only 0, 1 or 2 for military tech
The maximum civil tech allocation is 2, so it is possible to play only 0, 1 or 2 for civil tech


When both players have placed their cards, every card is turned face-up. If a player wrongly played cards exceeding the sum limit of 7, the opponent decides which card or cards to decrease in order to be within 7. If both players make a mistake in the same round, the round is considered null and void.

Phase 2: Peace/War Scoring
If a state attacks the other one or both states attack, a war begins. Otherwise, states are at peace.
Based on the cards played and the tech levels, states score points as explained below.

Phase 3: Tech Increasing
If a state didn’t lose the war in the round, it can increase its tech levels based on its tech allocations.

PEACE
If a state at peace chooses the production action, he scores as many points as the value on its played wealth card + civil tech level.

If a state at peace chooses the defense action, he scores as many points as the value on its played wealth card -1 (reputation cost).

WAR
A state’s firepower is the sum of its armament allocation, military tech level and action bonus:

Production: +0 action bonus.
Attack: +1 action bonus.
Defense: +2 action bonus.


If states are at war, whoever has the higher firepower wins the war.

If production or defense wins the war: it scores its own wealth allocation + the opponent’s one.
If attack wins the war: it scores its own wealth allocation + the opponent’s one - 1 (reputation cost).

When production or defense lose the war, it scores nothing and it loses its tech allocations.
When attack loses the war, it scores -1 and it loses its tech allocations.

ARMISTICE
In case of equal firepower, the war ends with an armistice: attack scores its own wealth allocation – 1; production and defense score their own wealth allocation. Tech allocations are not lost.

MILITARY TECH
A state can allocate part of its budget researching tech for military purposes. The number on the military tech card, namely the military tech allocation, determines how many steps a state can progress on the military tech board. The resolution of military tech cards occurs after the peace/war scoring.

Initially, the military tech level is 0; then, every 4 steps, a state increases its military tech level by 1. The military tech level contributes to a state’s firepower.

If a state is defeated, he loses its military tech allocation (but it doesn’t lose its military tech level).

CIVIL TECH
A state can allocate part of its budget researching tech for civil purposes. The number on the civil tech card, namely the civil tech allocation, determines how many steps a state can progress on the civil tech board. The resolution of civil tech cards occurs after the peace/war scoring.

Initially, the civil tech level is 0; then, every 3 steps, a state increases its civil tech level by 1. The civil tech level contribute to increase the efficiency in the production processes: the civil tech level contributes to the score of a production state at peace.

If a state is defeated, he loses its civil tech allocation (but it doesn’t lose its civil tech level).

END OF THE GAME AND SCORING
The game ends when the first player gets 50 or more. Before the beginning of the game, players may arrange to play for less or more points.
At the end of the game, the player who has more points wins.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Civilization, Math, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Master's Hand
description:
The City of Darklight lies North, near the dreaded Haze Rifts, and the Othmogian Darkness. This is a place where mighty Adventurers gather to meet their fate, a city of mythical splendor, diabolical secrecy and eternal conflict.. You emerged as one of the Masters of the City, bound to a unique Origin and a dark Fate.

You must survive the Masters’ conflict. You must rise in Power and defeat your Archenemy,
Recruit your allies Master, your Ancestral Destiny lies in front of you...

Master's Hand (MH) is a tactical RPG card game themed by the dark conflict and power struggle that eternally curses the ancient City of Darklight.
It is a pure (rapid) PVP strategy game for 2 players who they must manipulate masterfully 16 unique adventurers in order to survive and defeat their enemy.
In the beginning of the game, each Master select his Origin Card by the 8 available Origins. Origins provide unique abilities to the 2 players and define the style of play, their available strategies, and general Tone & Immersion.
The Game is played in 10 rounds. In each round the 2 players exchange turns.
Both Masters use the Adventurer deck.
Each adventurer can be played with two ways: a) Be entering the Master's Party (Recruitment)
or b) be played from hand as a Secret Ally. The Adventurers belong to 4 orders each assigned to a unique color. City, Nature, Divine and Outlaw.

There are 2 winning conditions in MH.
Drop your opponents life to 0, or have more life than him at the end of round 10.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Das Geheimnis Der Tiroler Berge
description:
Das Geheimnis Der Tiroler Berge ("The Secret of the Tyrolean Mountains") is a family board game in which you "search, move mountains and find Tyrol's treasures". The game is for 2-4 players, and is listed with a difficulty of ages 6-99.

It is distributed as a promotional item to promote tourism in the region of Tyrol, Austria.

—user summary

name: Projeto
description:
Projeto is a game designed to teach Project Management skills and give to the classroom some experience running a big project for the King: it´s Castle.

The players have 8 years, $60,000,000.00, 300 workers and lot's of tasks to finish the castle. The project may be delayed due to some risks like weather or war. Also, some expectations must be fullfiled, after all, it´s the king ordering a new castle !!

The 8 years are divided in a way that gives the players 2 hours to complete the game. It's a cooperative game and the players must divide the tasks among themselves. While one player takes care of the time passing, another must allocate the workers, other must buy/provide stones, another must transport the stones to the castle section being build. Each semester some events may occur, like snow, war or even good weather, causing delays or making things faster.

After 8 years, the King will move to the castle and make the quality assurance to check if the castle is really safe, if it can accommodate the soldiers and horses and have room for food storage. According to the sections finished, the players score points. A minimum requirement of 50 points must be achieved, of a total of 75 points possible.

—description from the designer

name: The Cutting Room Floor: The Moviebuilding Game
description:
Have you ever watched a movie and thought to yourself, "I could make a better movie than THIS"? Well, now you can.

Cutting Room Floor is a card-drafing, storytelling, moviebuilding game for 2-5 players. You take on the role of a movie Editor, piecing together the movie that YOU want to make! Choose your genre, build your Movie Timeline by drafting Story Beats, Characters, Props, and Locations from the Cutting Room Floor, all while adhering to your Producers' demands and staying under budget. Match Bonus Icons for the type of movie you're making to earn bonuses from the FX Cards!

At the end of the game, pitch your movie to your fellow Editors, and give each other Movie a unique Star Rating. The Editor with the highest combined Star Rating is the winner!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Open Drafting, Simulation, Storytelling, Variable Player Powers

name: Schau dich um: der Fuchs geht um!
description:
Up to 6 hares try to cover the white track from the upper left of the game board to the lower right without getting cought by the fox. In board segments I to IX movement is determinated by two dice, a color die (green/red)and a number die (1-6). If green and a number is rolled, the hare advances to the next space of this number. If red and a number is rolled, the hare is put on the corresponding number of the red circle of the board segment, it occupies. In segment X only the number die is used.

The fox starts at the foxhole in the center of the game board and uses the red track to catch the hares at the intersections or on the red circles. If the fox rolles green and a number, it advances on the black dots. If it rolles red and reaches an intersection with the white track or the center of a circle it may catch a hare on the intersection or on a red space on the circle. If a hare is caught it gets eaten and is out of the game.

If a hare gets on an intersection it cries "Fox!" and the fox has to immediately return to the foxhole.

The first hare to reach the orange space at section X wins the game. The game ends when all hares have escaped or have been caught. The caught hares pay the fox and the fox pays the escaped hares.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Trip to the Moon Game
description:
A spin and move game produced by the British Chocolate company Fry's.

The game sees players starting on earth and traversing a path to the moon. Along the way a number of detours and problems can be encountered, like gyroscope damage, an air cabin leak and a hostile spaceship. These will cause delays in reaching the moon. The winner is the first to reach the moon.

The promotional game was a free giveaway in Britain and Northern Ireland. To win the free game children would draw a spaceship or describe a trip to the moon and then include 2 chocolate wrappers to claim their game before April of 1955.

The game is similar to one produced by the Cadbury chocolate company in Australia during the same period.

—user summary

name: Noodle Knots
description:
In the game of Noodle Knots, a mischievous chef tries to get you all tangled up in knots! Players place “noodle” wristbands on both of their wrists and then connect them to the wrist bands of the other players to form a circle. One additional player acts as the chef and reads cards to direct one player at a time to touch a body part of another. If the noodled players can perform the actions without the wrist band noodles snapping apart, the round continues! But before long, the connecting noodles will break! When it’s your turn to be the chef, your goal is to break the noodles using the fewest body part cards! Get ready for plenty of laughter as you play this silly game of teamwork that gets you and your friends all tied up in knots!

Comes with 10 wrist bands, 20 action cards that feature body parts, and instructions.

name: Spikey Sam's Nachomania
description:
Spikey Sam’s Nachomania is a fast game of spicy fun! You earn points by keeping your eyes peeled for just the right nacho toppings and being ready to grab Spikey Sam fast!

First, grab a nacho chip from the pile and place it in front of you. Then shake up Spikey Sam and check his sombrero to see which toppings he reveals. If your chips show those toppings, be the first to grab Spikey Sam! And watch for the Golden Chip to add extra points, but watch out for the Angry Sam chip – he’ll make you lose points!

Game includes 1 cactus shaker and 36 game chips.

name: The Heroes of Ermaroda Castle
description:
"Our last stronghold is under siege. Hundreds of evil minions are storming towards the castle. Our only hope depends on three mighty heroes... Three, against a huge horde..."

The heroes know, if they can maintain the castle long enough, when the sun will rise, the war will be over.
But until that time they wil have to do whatever it takes to stop the enemy forces for as long as possible!

The Heroes of Ermaroda Castle - is a boardgame wich can be played solo or as 2-4 player co-op. You must survive for 15 rounds defending the castle. You choose 3 or 4 heroes who will help you to complete this achievement. Every round there will be an enemy-phase where minions move and also attack. The heroes-phase let you control your heroes who will have 3 actions each. The heroes will also have unique abilities and upgrades to stop the enemy. If after 15 rounds the castle still stands, you win the game.

-description from designer
