mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: The Colourable Words Game
description:
The Colourable Words Game is a word based competitive family game of 2-4 players played over two phases. In the first phase, players try to score letters with the help of a D6 or D4 on a circular board. Each letter provides points as mentioned on the letter. The letters are divided in 6 colours and the phase enters its last round once a player manages to get letters in each colour. In the second phase players try to create a maximum of three words out of the letters they have scored, with each word providing points. Six letter words score bonus points. The second phase is completed once at least one player finishes putting down all three words. The player with the highest total points over two phases wins the game.

—description from the designer

name: News@11: News Flash Promo
description:
A small, demo version of News@11 released prior to its Kickstarter campaign.

There are enough cards for 3 to 5 players to play 2 rounds, but you'll need a marker.

Contains 4 Segment cards, 8 Cue Cards & 1 instruction card.

The fill-in-the-blank cue cards allow players to customize game to their interests.

name: Formula 1 Grand Prix
description:
Grand prix for small racers.

Every player selects a team (McLaren, Ferrari, Williams or Benneton) and tries to arrive to the finish line as quickly as possible. A race lasts for 1, 2 or 3 laps. A player rolls a die and moves his car for the given number of spaces.

Velika nagrada za male dirkače.

Vsak igralec izbere svoje moštvo (McLaren, Ferrari, Williams ali Benetton) in poskuša čim hitreje priti s svojim avtom do cilja. Dirka traja 1, 2, ali 3 kroge. Igralec vrže kocko in premakne svoj avto za toliko polj kot jih pokaže kocka.

—user summary

name: Wurmsalat
description: Salad of worms is a tile based game where the players place tiles in order to construct worms of different colours from tail to nose.

name: Charged Canada: Electric Vehicle Mission-Based Strategy Board Game
description:
Charged Canada is an electric vehicle mission-based board game. Charged Canada brings you back to a not too distant past where there are no charging stations across the entire nation. It's up to you and your friends to decide where to put the charging stations as you see fit with your missions.

Missions include traveling from a specific city to city, collecting resources, and building charging stations or solar installation. Each player receives their own mission cards at the beginning of each game playthrough. With hundreds of mission cards to choose from, your three starting missions are not going to be the same as the other players.

Each round is determined using the actions cards, which can be used right away or held for later use.

Strategy game elements include:
map building
deck building
point to point movement

With multiple ways to win, typically through completing a mission card for the victory point on that card. Another way is to create charging stations or solar installations to earn a victory point for each.

The first one to the victory point limit wins. The VP limit is dependent on the number of players as Charged Canada can have up to 8 players. The higher the number of players the lower the VP limit.

Each playthrough will be different based on the mission cards that everyone has and decides how to proceed with those missions.

Charged Canada is easy to learn and play for even the most beginner to board games.

-description from designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting, Point to Point Movement

name: Schau genau! Die Maus
description:
The subtitle "Die Maus (the mouse)" is from a children TV series.
The mouse is only on the cover and on each side of the cards, therefore not really part of the game play.
There are 5 round cards, with each 16 different images on both sides.
The images are from different categories (animals, fruits, clothing, vehicles, ...)
These 5 cards are placed in the middle of the table. The player who finds first the image which is on all 5 cards (allways exact 1) gets a chip of his choice.
The 5 cards are new placed (turning some of the cards) and a new round starts.
If a player has 4 equal chips he wins the game.

name: Flirtalarm
description:
The dream couple is being sought for a theater project or the school sport championships. Find the best matching pairs for specific events. Romance, sportiness, popularity and interests / talents play the most important roles in the right combination of the dream couples. Jokers influence the gameplay and do not allow pairings to arise or change them in unexpected directions.


6 playing cards - 3 boys and 3 girls cards - are issued to each player
3 event cards are laid open
Players take turns taking a card to an event and reloading a new card
the player who completes the pair to the event receives the cards
Joker cards (suspend, blockade, veto) can affect the game for your own benefit
the game ends when all event cards have been played
the player with the most points wins the game


—user summary

name: Under Construction: Poland
description:
We are currently observing the largest construction boom in Poland since the reconstruction after World War II. These days not storks but steel cranes are characteristic Features of Polish landscape.

The players are directors of large construction companies. The companies succeeded in winning numerous tenders and divided Poland into several areas of operation. Each player hurries to perform tasks in several voivodeships, since Polish people and business need new roads and bridges.

name: 5 Minute Samurai
description:
This is a 5 Minute card game. you have a have a hand of 6 cards. you play higher and high until someone can't play and they get those cards to a pile to be counted later for scoring. play is over rounds until the deck is gone. then game is over and hands left are discarded into pile to be counted. cards 1 to 13, with 2 different wild cards per deck. This game is 1 to 4 player, but 2 decks can be put together to make it 8 players.

—user summary

name: Road to Reno
description:
In this 2-4 player game your goal is simple: win a $1,000 hand of blackjack at Casino Reno and win the game. Along the way you'll gamble, bluff, buy, and bet to avoid being left penniless in the desert.

Players move around the game board by pulling cards from the top of a draw pile. They can also bet on these movement cards to make money and win action cards. The spaces on the board offer opportunities to gain asset and action cards, gamble in casinos, and play poker against other players. Avoid losing money when players gamble in your casino and manage to make money when you gamble in other players' casinos and you'll be in Reno before you know it!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Pigs R Poppin'
description:
Pigs-R-Poppin' There's no stoppin.' Ready, aim, launch your Pig-o-nauts into the orbiting Sty-in-the-Sky. All pigs in, you win!

Pigs-R-Poppin' consists of 16 soft rubber Pig-o-nauts, 4 brightly colored launching shuttles, and one Sty-in-the Sky space station. Players launch their Pig-o-nauts from the spring-loaded arms on their shuttles, aiming for docking bays in the Sty-in-the-Sky space station. To make their task more difficult, the Sty-in-the-Sky is constantly moving, turning on a single rubber tire at bottom of the space station. The first person to land 4 pigs safely into their docking bay wins.

name: Mini Skittle Alley
description:
Tabletop miniature 10 pin bowling.

All the fun of 10 pin bowling only on a smaller scale! The objective is to knock down as many pins as possible. Each bowler has ten frames in which to knock down pins, with each frame being composed of up to two bowls.

Line up the aiming handle and push the marble down the alley. Skittles that are knocked over should be cleared off the alley before the second bowl. The crib can then be used to quickly and accurately set the skittles back for the next player.

—description from the publisher

name: Finger Pool
description:
A disc flicking version of classic billiards.

Use the triangle to rack the 15 billiard discs and flick the white cue disc to strike them. Basic pool rules apply, with the winner being the first to sink all seven of their billiard discs plus the number 8 disc. The felt covered gameboard rotates for easy tabletop playing and the woven string pockets ensure discs do not fall onto the floor.

—user summary

name: Turkey Shoot
description:
Bring the fun of a classic Turkey Shoot to your table.

Players load their shotgun card with bird shot or a slug and take aim at classic turkey shoot targets. Tilt the back of the shotgun up to dump your bird shot or slug onto the target and see if you can get the best shot and win a turkey. Each turkey claimed is worth points depending on its weight. After 10 events the turkeys are weighed and the player with the most points wins!

—description from the publisher

name: Anticipation
description:
Counters with numbered arrows indicate the direction along which each player will pick their following placement as players wrangle their counters across the hex plan board. Each player is attempting to connect 8 pieces or encircle any of the other players with 6 of their own to arrive at one of the four winning conditions first.

Cultivating more than a single attacking option and pre-positioning outliers along the same line form the basis of strategy.

Each player has 28 turns to make or foil those 8 connections without becoming unable to place in line with their preceding directional arrow or becoming themselves encircled.

This means that a game might come down to the longest continuous line of either players pieces as that which distinguishes the winner.

—user summary
mechanics: Enclosure, Hexagon Grid, Pattern Recognition, Player Elimination

name: The Raven
description:
The Raven is a party game to be played while watching an episode of Game of Thrones. First players draft item, event, or situation cards, then they start an episode and play like travel bingo. First player to get rids of all their cards win.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Print & Play, Real-time

name: Late Night Alias: Promo Card #1
description:
New clue card for the game. The words are:
1 Referee
2 Ear muffs
3 Heartbreaker
4 Chest
5 Afternoon delight
6 Cover

Card included in issue 27 of Tabletop Gaming
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Word Game

name: Fellowship of Fools: The (Friendship) Game
description:
We are all Fools on our journeys through this world. It’s dangerous to go alone. Take this game with you.

Fellowship of Fools: The (Friendship) Game (or FoF) is based on the Tarot, in use since the 14th century for games and since the 17th century for divination. The art for Fellowship of Fools dates back to 1761 to its creation in France by Nicolas Conver de Marseilles and is called the Tarot de Marseilles. Today, Tarot cards are widely used for game playing, creativity, divination and personal development. Our hope is that FoF can turn that inward reflection of the Tarot outward to help players develop friendships.

We’ve split the Tarot deck into its two parts—-the Major Arcana for Situations and the Minor Arcana for Topics. On each card are two different prompts—-corresponding to the upright and the reversed meaning of the card. Numbers next to the prompts indicate their difficulty, possible points that can be gained or lost for playing that prompt, as well as the number of Topic Prompts that can be played for that Situation Prompt.

There are multiple ways to play Fellowship of Fools: The (Friendship) Game: solo, with two players, or with multiple players. We encourage players to experiment with the cards and find their own ways to play. Visit to our Gamplay page to see the many ways to play, then experiment with the game and submit your own ways to play!

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Card Game, Exploration, Party Game
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Paper-and-Pencil, Role Playing, Simulation, Storytelling

name: Animals Poop Race
description:
In this game you play as a "pooplord" of a preselected kingdom. Your goal is to grow up your animals from "Puppy" stage to "Wise" stage. How? You have 3 types of cards: Animals, Kingdoms and Extras. Animals are your creatures, your babies, you take care of them. Each animal belongs to a kingdom. There are 6 Kingdom cards: Alpacas, Flamingos, Pandas, Unicorns, Sloths and Dinosaurs. Your goal is to own 3 animals of your kingdom on your field, complete of their "poop markers" aka being Wise. Extra cards can help you doing that! EXTRAS are 2 different types: TRICKS (can be used unlimitedly and in any moment) and TREATS (can be played max 2 per turn unless specified otherwise). Each turn has different phases. The first thing you want to do is to position "poop markers" on your animals card (does not apply in the first player's first turn). You get 1 poop marker per animal. Then you draw 2 cards, choosing between the 2 decks (animals deck, extras deck), the combination is up to you (1/1, 2/0, 0/2). You can play a maximum of 2 cards per turn, if there aren't cards in your field allowing you to play more. Playing cards, the player should try to prevent opponents to stack poop markers on animals while trying to fully stack his own animals. The winner is the first player owning 3 wise animals on his field. During the "stacking poop" phase, poop markers can't be prevented, so be sure to clean up the poop you want to delete before the next player's turn's begin (before your ending phase, to be clear). All this stuff fits into funny artworks and weird characters!

—description from the designer

name: Singin' in the Game!: On augmente le volume
description:
In this first expansion of Singin' in the Game!, you will find more than 260 new french speaking artists, some new variations and 18 jokers (such as "Don't play this card" , "Find another song", "choose your category"...) to add even more interactions to the game.

On augmente le volume est la première extension pour Singin' in the Game!

Celle-ci contient:


Plus de 260 nouveaux artistes.
18 jokers pour encore plus de coups-bas et d'intéractions.
Plusieurs variantes dont un mode solo "compétitif".
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Music, Party Game

name: Singin' in the Game!: Le volume est à fond !
description:
In this second expansion of "Singin' in the Game!", you will find more than 260 new french speaking artists, some new variations and 20 jokers (such as "Steal a joker to another team" , " The right to find lyrics in spite of singing", " Don't make any mistake"...) to add even more interactions to the game.

Singin' in the Game! (vol3): Le volume est à fond! est la seconde extension du jeu Singin' in the Game!

Celle-ci contient:


Plus de 260 nouveaux artistes.
Plusieurs variantes.
20 nouveaux jokers.

name: Haulin'
description:
Every day, semi trucks haul loads across the country on short and long hauls. How these loads get to their destinations takes planning and a knowledge of the highways of our country.

Choose a handle, take the driver’s seat of a semi truck, and test your skills against other truckers as you cross the country in an effort to rise to the top of the trucking industry. Haulin’ is an immersive game that will put you in the drivers seat of your very own semi truck. Traveling through an often changing world of natural disasters and dreaded road construction, as a semi driver, your job is to choose which loads you want to pick up and deliver to cities in need. Choose to deliver dedicated loads which only you have been hired to haul or race against fellow truckers to be the first to deliver nationwide dispatch loads. Be warned, trucking is a competitive business. As you race to haul more loads than anyone else, keep an eye on the other truckers.

The trucker who delivers all of their dedicated loads first, ends the game. However, the trucker who delivers the most loads to cities in need will win the game, so plan well and get Haulin’!

name: Cryptkins: The Card Game
description: Cryptkins: The Card Game uses Cryptozoic's "Gryphon" card game engine to deliver a simultaneous, easy-to-learn tabletop experience. Each player has a ten-card deck that allows them to call forth allies or use super powers.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Real-time

name: Benjamin Blümchen: Café Blümchen
description:
Dice Game with six different Variants. You try to get most pieces of a cake, or get rid of cherries you can place on a cake.

Incl. 12 pieces of cake, 12 chips, 2 meeples, 1 dice and the rulebook.

"To the icing on the cake, ready, go! Sure, when Benjamin opens a small café, everyone is there. And everyone wants a piece of the Neustadt cherry cake. It's a good thing that there are six delicious dishes here. So everyone is guaranteed to find something that tastes good when dicing."
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Gameshop Valentine's Game
description:
Find your way to Together.....

A Valentime's themed card game for 2 player. All player roles are non-gender specific.

Needed to play:
5 cards, 9 cubes and 1d6 inside a d6

In this game, both players are playing cooperatively. Your goal is to move your player markers from their starting spaces to the ‘Together’ spaces, at the end of the game board, during your shared turn. If you cannot do this before the marker on the board’s time track reaches 0, or, if either of you has 0 energy at the end of your shared player turn, you lose.

Setup
Place the two halves of the game board so that the sides marked A face each other. Place the 2 player markers on their respective starting spaces at the end of the board. Place each of the 4 Hobgoblins of Sadness markers on the 4 black squares. Place 1 on the board’s time track. Lastly, each player should choose one side of a personality card and place a marker, in their
matching color, on the [8] space of their energy track.

Players play:
One player rolls the die in a die. Each player then chooses one of die roll results to apply to either movement or energy.

For each 6 rolled, move the marker on the time track down 1 number. Remember: if the marker on time track on reaches 0, you have both lost the game.

Movement is either left or right, forward or back, never diagonally (unless a special action allows this).

At any time during their shared turn, each player may use the special action listed on their card. Reduce the energy on your card’s track to pay for this, as specified by the special action. Your energy levels may never go above 8 or below 0. Remember: if either of you has 0 energy at the end of your shared player turn, you have both lost the game.

Players may move to a space occupied by a Hobgoblin. If, at any time, a player’s marker is on the same space as a Hobgoblin, they may spend 2 energy to send the Hobgoblin back to a starting space of their choice.

Hobgoblins of Sadness play:
All Hobgoblins of Sadness now move 2 spaces - left, right, forward or back, never diagonally. Players will always move the Hobgoblins towards the player marker nearest to a Hobgoblin’s position. If both player markers are equally distant, move the Hobgoblin to the player with the most energy. If still tied, move them towards the player of your choice.

If a Hobgoblin moves to a player’s space they will reduce that player’s energy by 1 or 2.

Next Turns and Game End:
Players now move or gain energy on their shared turn, followed by the Hobgoblins movement. If both players enter their final ‘Together’ spaces at the same time, during their shared turn, they win the game and have found their way to Together.

If you cannot do this before the marker on the board’s time track reaches 0, or, if either of you has 0 energy at the end of your shared player turn, you lose.

A new game in the "Gameshop" series.

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Blood of Empires
description:
Blood of Empires is a game of a grand strategy set in the ancient Mediterranean region, starting in 264 BC. It is for 2-4 players and takes about 2-3 hours to play. It is a card driven game where each player is dealt a hand of cards to play during a round that will allow them to take different actions in the game that also act as a fog of war. The simple rules make play easy but there is depth to the strategy and the players constantly have meaningful choices to make.

Since the death of Alexander the Great in 323 BC his empire has fragmented, the two most powerful factions being to the east; the Seleucid Empire and Ptolemaic Egypt. Meanwhile Rome has been solidifying its hold of the Italian peninsula and the Carthaginians have become the dominant trade and naval power of the western Mediterranean. Historically, 264 BC was the year the first Punic War began between Rome and Carthage. Many other wars followed and by 188 BC Rome had defeated, contained or occupied her foes.

In this game each player takes on the role of one of the four major factions; Rome, Carthage, Egypt or the Seleucid Empire and will fight so that they can become the dominant power. Players will try to expand their territory, manoeuvre their armies and defeat their enemies in battle.

Empires will pay in blood to rise or fall. How will history unfold this time?

—description from the designer

name: Ski-Hi: New York to Paris
description:
Based on Charles Lindbergh's historic solo flight across the Atlantic from New York to Paris in 1927.

This is a simple roll-and-move type of game, however some setbacks and helps are added by landing on colored squares which send a player backwards down a detour, all the way back to the "Starting Field", down a short-cut detour, gaining a second turn, or out of the game completely by being "lost at sea" after landing on a black square. Landing on a space occupied by another "airship" also sends them back to start. An exact number is needed to win the game.

The goal is to complete a flight from New York to Paris ahead of your opponents.

name: TANKS: The Modern Age – Striker Tank Expansion
description:
The Spartan Armored Personnel Carrier was initially intended to carry infantry for British reconnaissance forces. The Spartan MCT pairs this swift vehicle with a MILAN Compact Turret equipped with a pair of MILAN anti-tank guided missiles, whilst the Striker carries the heavier Swingfire anti-tank guided missiles.

Plastic components.

Contents:
1 Striker or Spartan MCT Tank
1 Striker Tank Card
1 Spartan MCT Tank Card
1 Hero Card
2 Crew Cards
2 Upgrade Cards
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame

name: Unicorn Tears: The Greatest card game the multiverse has ever known
description:
Unicorn Tears is a fast paced card game of strategy and wit. The game was designed and illustrated by a 13 year old entrepreneur with a passion for tabletop games!

Players take turns drawing cards until someone draws a Unicorn Tear and loses the game. The deck is made up of cards that let you avoid sudden death by Unicorn Tears by peeking at cards before you draw, forcing your opponent to draw multiple cards, shuffling the deck or stopping the Unicorn Tears with the all powerful Anti Depressant card. There is even one unstoppable card called Buddy the Narwhal, Buddy allows you to switch your hand with any player you choose.

The game gets more and more exciting and dangerous with each card you draw because the less cards that are left in the deck means a bigger chance of drawing a Unicorn Tear and dying an instant terrible death of shame and disappointment.

—description from the publisher

name: Imperial Chess
description:
There are four different chess variants in the game: the normal "Chess" for 2 people, the "Imperial Chess" for 4 people on an extended board (8x8 playing field with an extension on each side of 4x8 squares), the "Feudal Chess" for 4 people on a 9x9 field and the "Super Chess" for 2 people on a 16x8 field. The figures are made of plastic in four colors, black and white for the two 2-person-variants and additionally red and gray for the 4-person-variants.

—user summary

name: FORVM: Trade Empires of Rome
description:
In FORVM, players compete to become the most prestigious Roman by having their agents engage in trade in markets across the Roman Empire. In each turn, agents are set out one step at a time across the network of markets to establish horrea (warehouses), negotiate alliances or break them apart, establish a presence in a region or prevent another player from accessing it.

Trade functions through every market where a player has established a warehouse. The further from Rome, the higher the transport and information costs and the lower the profit. But agents who are connected back to Rome are better informed, and so can get a better return. Fortunes can be made by creating continuous trade routes accessing the wealth of the edges of Empire and the Barbaricum beyond!

Money is not the only way for a player to grow in prestige; a combination of clever board control and alliances and benefactions allow a player to move up the cursus honorum (prestige ladder) to become Consul! But fate will always play a role, and can upset the most intricate of plans.

—description from the publisher

name: Head Waiter
description:
One player straps the tray to their head and places all of the food items on it and acts as the waiter. Everyone else is a customer. Customers have 2 food cards and they take turns calling out the item on their card to the waiter. If the waiter can walk over, feel around on their head, and deliver the correct item, they get to keep the card. There are also action cards which the waiter can collect during play. Once a waiter drops a piece of food or delivers the wrong item, they score one point per card they've collected and a new player gets to act as the waiter. Most points wins.

-description from designer

name: Mix & Mayhem
description:
Mix & Mayhem is a fast-paced family battling card game for 2 to 4 players. It can be played in 4 different ways, providing exciting variation and wide age range appeal. One of the games aimed at young children is a simple mix and match stlye game. One of the other games is a Top Trumps style of selecting a category and the highest value wins. The other two of the game variations are trick taking games that involve trying to create the most powerful creatures and battling them against your opponent.

The game contains 72 cards, including 60 character cards and 12 special action cards. The 60 character cards include 20 Head cards, 20 Torso cards, and 20 leg cards. Combined in the right sequence, these cards create 20 fearsome characters ready to do battle, however, when the cards are mixed with cards from other characters they can create up to 8,000 unique characters each with their own unique name and powers. You will create crazy, scary, funny, unusual and wonderful characters to battle and try to defeat your opponents.

Mix & Mayhem cards can be played in 4 different ways, You Complete Me, Wipe Them Out, Skirmish, and Bunch of Fives. The rules for each game are described below.

You Complete Me!
Preparation: Remove all of the Action cards. Shuffle the Character cards and place them in a pile
face down.
Playing the game: Decide who goes first, then each player takes it in turns to take a card from the pile and lay them face up in front of them. As the game progresses each player will be able to mix their cards to create weird and wonderful creatures as the game progresses.
The winner: The aim is to be the first player to create one of the 20 original characters made up of the set of correct 3 cards. If neither player is able to create one of the 20 original characters before the cards are all drawn then the cards are collected, re-shuffled, and drawn again until there is a winner.

Wipe Them Out!
Preparation: Split the cards into 3 separate piles for Heads, Torsos and Legs (including the Action cards which are also marked on the back of the card as Head, Torso and Legs cards). Shuffle each pile and deal the cards face down to each player so that each player has their own separate piles of Head
cards, Torso cards, and Leg cards. Each player should have the same number of body part cards.
To play the game: Each player picks up the top card of each pile of body parts so they have a complete character, with a Head card, Torso card and Legs card. If they pick up an Action card instead of a character body part they should keep this and draw another card from the top of the pile until they have a character body part. The Action cards that they may have picked up can be used during the game. Players hold the cards facing themselves, so only they can see them. Decide who goes first, then that player will select a category – either Brains, Strength or Speed. Each player shows their card to reveal the value of the chosen body part. The player with the highest
value wins the battle and the player with the lowest value must discard the body part card that lost. Then the loser must pick up the next top card from their pile of the same category until they have a complete character again. The winner of the battle can keep the same cards in play. However, each card can only be used a maximum of 2 times to win a battle. After an individual body part card has won 2 battles it must be discarded and a new one drawn. Players will take it in turns to select a category. Both players must always have at least 3 cards in play, including a Head card, Torso card and Legs card in addition to any Action cards that have been collected. To create some extra mayhem the Action cards that have been drawn by players during the game can be used when it is their turn at any stage of the game. Once a player uses an Action card it must then be discarded.
The winner: The object of the game is to defeat your opponent by wiping out a pile of their cards so that they are no longer able to make up a full character and therefore unable to continue to battle. When a player is unable to make a complete character they are defeated and their opponent is the winner of the game.

Skirmish!
Preparation: Shuffle all of the cards (Character and Action cards) into a single pile.
Playing the game: Each player will take it in turns to draw a card from the top of the pile. The cards are laid face up so they are visible to both players. When both players have a complete character of a Head card, Torso card and Legs card they are ready for battle. Players can create the character of
their choice to battle with from any of the character cards they have drawn. Each turn, players have the option to challenge their opponent to a battle, or to draw another card to
try and create more powerful characters. Once a challenge to battle has been made by either player, the characters they both have created for the battle must be declared and put side by side. The total character score is calculated by adding together the brains, strength and speed values, and the player
with the highest total character score wins that battle. If a player is able to create one of the correct 20 unique character sets then their overall character score is increased by an extra 10 bonus points. The player who makes the challenge may think they have the most powerful character because they
can see the values of their opponent’s characters, however, their opponent may create mayhem by playing one of their Action cards that they have collected to swing the outcome of the battle. A player can use one or more Action cards at any time. Once a player uses an Action card it must then
be discarded. The players continue to draw further cards and engage in new battles with new characters until all
cards have been drawn and there are no further complete characters in the remaining cards held by both players.
The winner: The player who has won the most individual battles once all the cards have been drawn
wins the game.

Bunch of Fives!
Preparation: Remove all of the Action cards from the deck and deal all of the remaining character cards into separate Head, Torso and Legs piles. Each player will be dealt 3 Head cards, 3 Torso cards and 3 Legs cards, allowing each player to make up 3 separate characters. The cards are laid face down so they are not visible to the opposing player. Each player should then privately arrange their cards to create 3 different characters with their own unique name and overall value.
Playing the game: Decide who goes first, then that player will lay down one of their characters to engage in battle with their opponent. The other player must then choose and lay down one of their characters. Whoever has the highest total score (by adding together the brains, strength and speed values) wins that hand. If a player is able to create one of the correct 20 unique character sets then their overall character score is increased by an extra 10 bonus points. Players will take it in turns to lay a character first. Once all 3 characters have battled the players will then be dealt another 3 Head cards, 3 Torso cards and 3 Legs cards for another round of 3 battles.
Following the second round of 3 battles there will be 1 final round of 3 battles, so there will be 3 rounds of 3 battles making a total of 9 battles.
The winner: The first player to win 5 battles is the winner of the game. It is possible therefore to
win the game outright after only 2 rounds without the need for the final round.

—description from the designer

name: Oppervlakte-spel
description:
Start with an area on graph paper with a close area (20x10 or choose together).

When it's your turn, you throw two dice (choose: D4,D6,D8,D10).
You have to claim an area with the size of the dice (for instance: if you throw 2 and 3, you have to claim an 2x3 rectangle).
You're claimed area's have to touch each other.

The game ends if you both have 2 turns in a row without claiming an area.

The one with the biggest claimed area wins.

Variant: Can also played with claiming an area with twice the sum as circumference (for instance: if you throw 2 and 3, you have to claim an area with a circumference of 2+3+2+3=10).

—user summary

name: L'as des as
description:
L'as des as follows the principle of Backgammon. The game board is round and the pawns continue with no hope other than capturing or being captured. The goal of the game is to be the last in the running, having captured and put in prison all the opposing pieces.
The pieces represent card colors: spades, hearts, diamonds and clover. The pieces are safe when they are on an arrow of the same denomination.

—user summary

name: Autopeli Kaara
description:
The game consists of 52 cards that have a number, suit and a picture of a car in them. Suit can also be recognised from the background colour of the card. Each player is dealt with three cards, additionally one card is dealt and opened for the table. Players try to collect cards in the table with the cards in their hands, aiming to as many cards and aces and hearts as possible.

Each card has a picture of a different car from 1888-1922, except in aces, where there are pictures of tyres. Beneath a car there is the name and the year of the car.

—user summary

name: Lumi
description:
Lumi is a confrontational tile placement game in which two players are setting up chains of lights.

They try to hook-up more light bulbs of their own color than their opponent and to secure them in time before the opponent can destroy their plans.

At the end of the game, players score certain points for lamps powered by batteries, depending on their position on the cable.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Tile Placement

name: The Lost Island
description:
The Lost Island is a treasure hunting game, where you, your family and friends fight and trade among each other to collect many riches and become the most wealthy person.

The game includes 10 different game objectives for a fresh new experience every time you play.

Each player will have their own player objective to fulfill before the game ends, and automatically lose if he/she failed to finish it.

Each round, a player picks up an event card, for an exciting beginning either luck or unlucky.

During a player's turn, you have to roll 2 dice and play according to the dice.

There are 5 different actions in the dice

Force trade
Movement
Fight
Build map
Go mining
Your choice of action


There are hidden treasure chests on the map that could help you become wealthy faster. Your goal is to finish your player objective, game objective, and collect as much money as possible by trading cards, fighting your teammates, crafting jewelry, and collecting treasure chests.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Events, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Set Collection, Tile Placement, Trading

name: Star Flickers: Mines & Munitions
description:
New weapons and terrain for Star Flickers! Mines and Munitions is the first expansion in the exciting game Star Flickers. In this expansion, you'll find large mine clusters that you'll either need to avoid as terrain, or use as weapons against other players!

New weapons include:

Minefields deploy temporary (and damaging) terrain tiles!
Hard Burn allows a player to damage another player by boosting away from them.
Guided Rockets greatly improve the accuracy of normal rockets, but deal less damage.


Plus, three new Star Flickers (Orange, Purple & Green) join the fray.

—description from the publisher
categories: Action / Dexterity, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction

name: Star Flickers: Through The Storm
description:
New terrain tiles for Star Flickers! Through the Storm is the second expansion to the exciting game Star Flickers. In Through the Storm, you'll have to navigate massive space clouds and their devastating ion-storm versions. Don't bump into the storm or you'll be ionized, losing your next turn!

These new (and huge!) tiles add a wealth of new options for those interested in new terrain set-ups for the base game.

Can you make it Through the Storm?

—description from the publisher
categories: Action / Dexterity, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction

name: Nimm den andern!
description:
The players have to transfer numbered tiles from the center of the game board to their home section. Most tiles are upside down, so their numbers are hidden. If a player takes a tile he can use, he collects it. Otherwise he puts it aside for the second half of the game. If a player takes a tile he can use from a space with the same number, he may also take a second tile, which has it's number un the upside, and a coin.

If a player is about to take a tile and another player shouts: "Take another one!" he may chose to do so. If he can use the other tile, the other player gets a penality. If he can't use the other tile, he himself has to pay a penality.

The first player to complete his home section wins the game.

—user summary

name: Die tolle 11
description:
This game simulates a soccer game. Each player moves 11 pieces about the board. Movement is determined by a die. A goal is achieved, if a player manages to get a forward on a space marked with a "T" in the opponents goal.

The first player to score a previously agreed on number of goals or scores the most goals in a fixed amount of time, wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Torpedo Attack Game
description:
Google Translation: Naval Battle Chess

Set all enemy vessels and rocks at any place on the game board. Place the torpedo boats in the port corresponding to their colour. First player spins the spinner and moves his/her boat in the direction indicated. If a torpedo boat moves onto a space occupied by an enemy vessel, that player takes the vessel off the game board and scores the points indicated. If the boat hits a rock, it is moved to the nearest port for repairs and the player misses two turns. If a boat lands on a space occupied by another player's boat, or if the boat travels off the game board, the moving player stays on the original spot and loses one turn. The game is over when all enemy vessels are sunk, or when the play time has elapsed. The winner is the player with the highest score.

—description from the rulebook

name: Roxane
description:
“And what is a kiss, specifically? A pledge properly sealed, a promise seasoned to taste, a vow stamped with the immediacy of a lip, a rosy circle drawn around the verb 'to love.' A kiss is a message too intimate for the ear, infinity captured in the bee's brief visit to a flower, secular communication with an aftertaste of heaven, the pulse rising from the heart to utter its name on a lover's lip: 'Forever.” ― Edmond Rostand, Cyrano de Bergerac

In Roxane, 2 to 4 players engage in a friendly competition vowing for the love of the beautiful Roxane. Players will have to compose the most beautiful poem using subjects, verbs, adverbs, complements and similes. Players will not only have to create rhymes, but the most exquisite sentences, scoring them extra points as the game progresses. Who will emerge as the best poet of them all?

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Queue, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Rogue!
description:
Rogue! is a designy, dungeon-diving, strategic card game of backstabbing, trickery, and deceit.

You and your friends are rogues (backstabbing, greedy thieves) and you're about to enter a dungeon where you have one goal: make it out with more loot than anyone else. You'll fight grotesque and weird monsters, suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, and, worst of all, you'll have to deal with the other two-faced lowlifes in the dungeon: your fellow players.

Players take turns drawing from THE DUNGEON DECK. If you draw a draw a LOOT card, it's your lucky day. A FORTUNE card can lead to success or disaster. If you draw a MONSTER card, you'll be forced to discard some of your precious LOOT. Fortunately, you've got ROGUE cards. These are the bread and butter of the game. Your bag of tricks. ROGUE cards can be used to divert monster damage to other players, steal loot, peek at and rearrange dungeon cards, and lay deadly boobytraps for other players.

When the last card from THE DUNGEON is drawn, the player with the highest total value of LOOT cards wins.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Take That

name: Stick Figure Fighters: Super Power Expansion
description:
Add new equipment to your Stick Figure Fighters to become an even greater Stick Figure warrior! Expansion includes 30 new equipment cards including helmets, armor, shoes and weapons.

-description from publisher
categories: Card Game, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Medieval, Party Game
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: CoreBall: The Zero Gravity Sport – Preachers Team Expansion
description:
The Preachers reject the idea of individual stars, and instead trusts good old teamwork. Their hyperlinked flyers allows them unprecedented levels of synergy and their combo potential is limitless. They might not beat you up, but they will surely beat you out!

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Sports
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: NeuroPunk: Artificial Intelligence
description:
In the year 2047, Artificial Intelligence becomes so powerful that the government uses the technology to control the citizen. Sadly nobody knows about it because A.I. is so smart that it can be invisible to all. A group of radicals called Neuropunk has the latest technology that outperforms A.I. by using their own brain. This technology is called ‘Savant’, by re-wiring the human Neural Network, their brain can perform the computation that surpasses machine intelligence. Now, they want to hack into the government system and remove all the A.I.

It’s a Print and Play solo card game similar to Poker Game. The player will play against an Artificial Intelligence opponent. Peephole cards are used to read the hidden information encoded in the Decision Card. This new mechanics can create Bluffing and Deduction for the game, emulating a human player with stronger artificial intelligence.

The goal is to defeat as many A.I. and obtain Achievement Points.

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play

name: Prelude to Biopunk: Gang Ratta
description:
Take on the faction of Terra Corporate Security or The Gang Ratta in an all out fight for the sprawl. Will you command the genetically engineered rat-folk or lead the corporate assault on rodent-crime within their borders?

This is a Quantum System product including multiple modular boards, square and counters fighting/movement, ability card play, an easy-intro format and mecha/netrunning content. This game is compatible with other Biopunk products.

Straight up competitive play rules and a mission book are included. Not only fighting is needed to win this module but skill in shady deals, technology and vehicles as well will help you win this running battle between a free people and Corporate enforcement.

The winner at the end is determined by that final mission in the campaign book. It may be a last stand by the Ratta or their rise to solvency.

This is a Basic game that not only involves the original struggle in the Biopunk Era in the Infantry HMU but is also appropriate for adult gamers new to tactical board-games.

—description from the publisher

name: Thoughts Confound Psychology
description: The game is similar to Apples to Apples and Cards Against Humanity. Each player is dealt seven white cards. One player starts the game by reading a black card. All the other players then choose the white card from their hand that is the best fit for that card. The reader chooses the answer they like best and the player who submitted that card gets to keep the black card they won. Play continues until "you get tired" and the player with the most black cards is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Get Set Go
description:
Be the first to finish the race with 10 out of 12 of your elite athletes or skillfully "final-tag" three of your opponent's athletes.

—description from the back of the box

name: Taktillinen partiopeli
description:
Simple tactical wargame of two identical forces of contemporary military units on cardboard standees trying to capture the other side's headquarters (flag piece). Played on a map where pieces can only move along roads and foot paths shown in three different colors that allow units to move one to three steps per turn. Combat is deterministic with either the attacked piece being eliminated or both pieces depending on the types of pieces involved. Barbed wire can be used to block enemy movement. Each side's forces includes two demolition units that can destroy any enemy piece (including barbed wire) at the cost of itself also being destroyed. They can also be used to demolish any of the five bridges shown on the map and red wooden pawns are included in the game to mark bridges that have been destroyed.

—user summary

name: Richesses d'Armor
description:
Richesses d'Armor is a local game made by women farmers.

The goal of the game is to create a farm by reconstructing a puzzle of six pieces. Each piece represents the various components of the farm: production, status of the farmer, building, equipment, crops and diversification activities (tourism, sale of farm products ...). From dairy farming to pig farming, including beef, poultry, mutton and vegetables, six farms, representative of all the productions present in Côtes-d'Armor, must be reconstituted. At the beginning of the game, each player receives a sum in euros to buy the pieces of the puzzle. During his journey in the department, the player answers questions about agriculture, economy, heritage ... What is the particularity of a biennial plant? According to the legend, who is at the origin of the source of the Rance ? .... In total more than 600 questions classified according to three major themes. The correct answers and event cards allow to buy the pieces of the puzzle. The player loses money with certain cards or when he passes on the exploitation of another player.

—user summary

name: Teppo
description:
The Tanegashima, or Teppo, is a matchlock-configured arquebus that was introduced to Japan by the Portuguese in the 16th Century. Although originally lacklustre on the battlefield in comparison to more traditional weapons, a raft of ingenious alterations resulted in the Teppo proving instrumental throughout the internecine wars of the late Sengoku period.

In this set of rules for tabletop figures you will be able to build armies from the Sengoku period and pit them against each other in a visceral battle for honour and glory.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Junkyard Champ
description:
By 2089, Robo-fights are the most popular sport. Looking forward to compete in the next championship, your dev team sneaks at nights in the city junkyards, trying to beat other teams first to spare parts and scraps to assemble a robo-fighter, all the Robo-Fighting world will be cheering for.

In Junkyard Champ, you will secretly deploy your dice (= team members)around the city trying to outbid your opponents for spare parts, which you may color-match to your robots’ circuits or sell to rich clients.

With the credits you get, you can bribe the guards of the central scrap yard, the notorious "Champ cemetery" to have the chance to physically search in a bag full of tokens for old batteries, adapters and other equipment, which will enhance your robots’ abilities.

Once you have built your robot, you may start competing in the Robo-arena against AI opponents or other players to advance to the finals and have a chance for the coveted World Robo-Champion title.

—description from the designer

name: Voyage Interplanetaire
description:
A space journey that travels to planets in our solar system and returns to earth.

This french space game is a simple roll and move of pieces around a board. One dice is used initially until space 13 is reached, thereafter two dice are used.

The planets have features that either help or hinder the players. Neptune the ice planet causes players to miss a turn and Mars has friendly robots that gives players a token. Venus has lush vegetation, while Mercury is way too hot.

Players win the game by being first to return to earth by exact throw of the dice. Upon being first they receive further tokens from the other players.

The game graphics of robots and the planets is similar in style to the Buck Rogers board games of the 1930s. A German board game called Das Raketenflugzeug has an almost identical playing board and similar graphics

No publisher is evident on the game.

—user summary

name: Jeu De L'espace
description:
This late 1950s French board game is unique in promoting business around the Rouen city in France.

The object of the game is for players to travel to planets by business named rockets. Players then transfer to flying saucers visiting major celestial stars and finally being first to arrive at Messier 31 (better known as the Andromeda galaxy).

A simple roll and move game where the pieces are constructed by a small rectangular card and a pin. Players push the pin into the board as they move along the space paths. They roll the dice 3 times during each players move. Some features on the board help players such as the Sputnik, while others apply a penalty such as the Space Monster.

The first to reach Messier 31 also have to answer 3 questions (2 related to the local businesses and one space question.

The game was handed out by the advertised businesses to customers.

—user summary

name: Fate/Grand Order: Summon Pencil Servant
description:
ﾌｪｲﾄｸﾞﾗﾝﾄﾞｵｰﾀﾞｰ　ｻﾓﾝﾍﾟﾝｼﾙｻｰｳﾞｧﾝﾄ is a competitive, collectible pencil game based on the mobile app game "Fate Grand Order".

In the Summon Pencil Servant board game players collect "pencil servants" and use them to fight one another by rolling pencils. Each pencil represents a servant. Servants have special skills, stats and classes.

The game nature of "Fate / Grand Order" is strongly reflected, and the strategic nature as in the main game is reproduced.

The game is available in the form of "starter sets" and "booster packs".

—user summary
categories: Collectible Components, Fighting, Video Game Theme

name: The Lost Journal of Flintlock Flynn
description:
An exciting escape room style game unfolding over the course of 6 unique mailings. Full of maps, puzzles, riddles, and adventure to discover.

As each mailing arrives you will try to work out where the treasure of Flintlock Flynn has been buried, if you manage to solve all the hidden messages, deal with betrayal in your team, then your reward is a chest filled with gold and gems!

We want to offer families a challenge to test their wits. Designed for kids to work together with their parents they'll solve various puzzles and riddles to spell out the hidden story.

The puzzles and adventure can either be enjoyed solo, or tackled together with your friends, the game transcends the more mundane escape room style games with physical puzzles and amazing components.

name: Allwords
description:
A rummy-type word card game. The deck has 2 cards for each consonant, 4 cards for each vowel, and 2 wild cards.

Players have a 7-card hand, and on their turn they draw to top of the draw or discard pile and discard a card. The object is to make one or more words from their hand. The game ends when a player reveals a 7-letter word in their hand. The players are ranked according the the length of the longest word in their hand, with ties broken by the length of their second word, etc. Players who cannot use all their letters to make words bust and lose the hand.

—user summary

name: Alpha-Beta
description:
"The Cross-Word Building Card Game". This is an Australian entry among the crossword-based card games which were very popular in the 1930s. The game is for 2 or more, with two decks being used if 5 or more play.

Ten cards are dealt to each player. During their turn, a player may do one of the following:

Lay down a complete word from their hand.
Add letters to an existing word to make another word, either in-line or crossing it as in a crossword puzzle. Adding "S" to make plurals is not allowed.
Change an existing word into a different word by removing one or more letters and adding one or more letters from the hand. Cards not removed must remain in the same order.
Discard a card and draw a card from the top of the deck or discard pile.


When one player empties their hand, each other player scores the sum of the values of the cards still in hand. Consonants are 2 points each, vowels are A 25, E 20, I 15, O 10, U 5. When one player's total reaches 100 or more, the player with the lowest score wins.

—user summary

name: Azet
description:
A French-language entry in the crowded field of crossword-based card games that were very popular in the 1930s, though this one might have been printed later.

Each player starts with a hand of 10 cards, each with a letter, and in their turn they either play a word from their hand, or add letters to other words to make new words, or discard and draw. When one player runs out of cards each player scores the points of their remaining cards in hand. When one player reaches 100 points the player with the lowest point total wins.

—user summary

name: SpellSwords
description:
In SpellSwords, you and up to three friends play a party of heroes exploring the dreaded DUNGEON OF AETOZEE.

Use letter cards to build the dungeon word-by-word. Move your character to collect power gems and use letters on future turns, but beware, your words will summon a monster... or worse, a fearsome Boss!

Don't fear, use your SpellSword to harness the power of words and power gems to create powerful weapons that improve both your combat and spelling abilities.

The player who earns the most points in spelled words, defeated monsters and collected gems wins the game!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Word Game
mechanics: Modular Board, Network and Route Building, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers

name: Eklan
description:
This would appear to be a traditional two player abstract strategy game from Africa.

It was well enough known in the Ivory Coast for that country to issue a set of two postage stamps featuring the game on 11 August 1984 [SG 810-811 / Scott 720-721; designed by Didier / Edila]. Curiously, however, no other information seems to be available on it except from these stamps, and it is not mentioned in any of the major games books in my possession, including that by L'Hôte, who is usually a good source for games of the Francophone world.

It is played by two people, on a board similar to that of Nine men's Morris, that is to say, there are 24 playing spaces arranged on the corners and mid-points of the edges of three concentric squares. However, no diagonals are marked, and the spaces consists of holes, into which the players insert black and white sticks. One of the stamps shows Eklan being played on an apparently traditional board fashioned into a small table, similar to those used in quality Go or Mancala sets. The dimensions I give below have been estimated from those pictures (the depth being the approximate height of the illustrated table).

The board is shown as having a narrow raised 'lip' around its edges, except at open at the corners. The part of the board between this lip and the outermost set of eight holes is coloured beige, and the regions within it are respectively coloured white, green, and - at the centre - yellow. Presumably these details are merely decorative. The sticks would seem to protrude about 6 centimetres out from their holes, and the white ones slant towards one player, while the black ones slant towards his opponent who sits opposite.

—user summary

name: Golf
description:
The players start on space 1 and have to get to space 100 (hole 18). Movement is determined by a die and quiz questions about the rules of golf play. The first player to reach hole 18 wins the game.

On each space the player has to answer a question about the golf rules. A correct answer allows the player to advance 6, 12, 18 or 30 spaces in accordance with the difficulty level of the question, while a wrong answer compels the player to go back 5 spaces.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Kam'on: Premium Expansion
description: KAM'ON Premium Deck expansion with 144 total cards. Includes 112 original starter deck cards and an additional 32 premium expansion cards.
categories: Ancient, Bluffing, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Negotiation, Religious

name: Hawksworld: The War for the Wasteland
description:
Hawksworld is a 2 to 4 player strategic board game where opponents fight for resources and strategic objectives in order to achieve VICTORY.

Inspired by the best Real Time Strategy computer games, Hawksworld successfully translates into a turn based board game the escalation, tactical nuances, and delicate balancing between claiming resources, upgrading tech, and maintaining supremacy on the battleground.

While players build their armies on the battlefield they also use engine building mechanics, worker placement and a programmable system for issuing orders that creates a pace and escalation culminating in some murderously tense moments right up until the final moves of the game.

Exploring the map and revealing terrain and resources sets the tone in the early game.
Capturing resources, building a base and a force to match the challenges before you shapes the mid game.
Finally, each factions force fights to claim strategic objectives to win the game.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Majority / Influence, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Aura Fight Game of Tactical Combat in Aura Battler Dunbine
description:
The game is a hexagonal tactical combat game similiar to Battletech set in the Dunbine anime universe where mechs from the Dunbine anime are pitted against each other. The game a some scenarios which are taken from the anime. Game system reminds me of the old mecha combat Tsukuda hobby Japan games of the 80s.

How, well like battletech you destroy your opponent, each player plays a mech or a group mechs.

—user summary
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: What We Became
description:
Have you ever wondered what comes after the zombie apocalypse? What might society look like in a world where the undead are a threat to the living, but where their presence is just an aspect of life?

What We Became is a board game for 4 to 8 players that explores these questions. Players take on the role of community leaders, each of them with a specific vision of what their society could be. They will need to work together to keep the community safe, erect new buildings, and instill new ways of doing things among the populace, but always remembering that none of the other players shares their exact vision.

What We Became is highly competitive, but the environment presents enough of a threat that players will need to negotiate and work together with adversaries to stay alive, all while trying to outmaneuver them to come out ahead. At the end of each game, you will realize that a story has been told about the ups, downs, successes, and failures of a community decades after the world as we know it has ceased to exist.

—description from the publisher

name: Alien Comms
description:
As an engineer in Alien Comms you are here to establish a new Telecommunications Station on a small satellite in a galaxy far away.

In Alien Comms, each turn you flip cards from three piles to make three different action sets from which every player chooses one. On one side you will find an Alien faction and an antenna model; on the other side, an Alien extension number and a energy adapter. You mark the chosen Alien Extension on it´s Alien faction and the Antenna Model on their tracks. Then you draw the antenna model and the energy adapter on an empty spot on your satellite.

But, what am I going to do with all of these antennas? Well... connect them to the Astronomic Entities, of course! There might be others trying to do the same as you and in these times it is known that nobody will buy the "second" quickest connection... Since actions are taken at the same time, all players can claim their connection to an Astronomic Entities on the same turn, but not on the next ¡so be quick to claim them before it is too late!

Each day a new galaxy is discovered and many are waiting to be the first ones to establish a contact there... Will you be the next?

—description from the designer

name: TANKS: The Modern Age – French Gazelle Helicopter Expansion
description:
The Gazelle is small, highly manoeuvrable and fast. The French use this versatile little Helicopter as a scout armed with a 20mm cannon that is very capable of successfully engaging light vehicles and Helicopters. Instead it can be equipped with HOT (Haut subsonique Optiquement Teleguide Tire d’un Tube) missiles to become a very effective tank hunter. The Gazelle is definitely more hunter than prey.

This pack contains:
1x Unassembled Plastic Gazelle Helicopter
1x Gazelle (HOT) Helicopter Card
1x Gazelle (20mm) Helicopter Card
2x Hero Cards
5x Crew Cards
3x Upgrade Cards
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Equate This!
description:
Equate This! is a game where players create expressions to form an equation using BEDMAS over 5 rounds using number cards and operator cards. The player with the most points at the end of the 5 rounds wins the game. (BEDMAS is outlined in the rules for those who have forgotten it)

The excitement in this game is trying to solve for a common answer, using the cards you have, and get a better equation than all the other players. "Better" is relative though, as you don't need to be a math whiz to win. For example, to solve for 8, you can have 4+4+5-5 or (3-1)2+(15-11). Make them as simple or as complex as you'd like, just make sure you don't get stuck when you need to place down your equation.

—description from the designer

name: Reader's Digest Quiz Night
description:
"Test your knowledge and have fun with 10,000 questions and answers"
Bound volume contains 912 10 question-long quizzes on topics ranging from science to art and literature to history to film … alternatively, play from 35 pages of 6-question quick quizzes on topics like "Who said?", "World Capitals," "TV Duos," "Our Bodies," etc. There are also quizzes explicitly for younger players. Players keep track of their right answers over multiple rounds; highest scorer wins.
categories: Book, Children's Game, Educational, Party Game, Trivia

name: Holmgang
description:
Choose your warrior! Get your weapons ready! And enter the Holmgang, the deadliest place in the North, where the most powerful warriors fighting each other for life and death. Without fear! Without limits! Are you prepared?

Holmgang is a bluffing combat card game set in Norse history. Players playing as warriors in Norse arena called Holmgang to claim their rights and glory. During the game, players play hidden cards on the board, once all actions are done players reveal cards one by one and execute their actions simultaneously. Move, Attack, Defend or do any of your special character ability to outplay your opponent. But be aware, you are slowly running out of options so be careful in your planning to always have some backup plan.

Each character is equipped with a unique set of weapons and 13 cards. Cards allow players to move with their weapons around the board or do some sneaky moves to try to find an undefended spot where they can hit the enemy with their attack. Attacking is the only way how players can deal damage to an opponent's character and defeat it. Each round players put 4 hidden cards on the board that creates their action decks. Once both action decks are complete, players execute all card from their decks one by one. The games end when one of the player's characters health is reduced to 0.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Queue, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Ghostwords
description:
A hybrid of Uno and the word game Ghost. Players start with a hand of 5 cards, mostly letters, and in a turn a player may do one of:

Add a letter to the row(s) of cards on the table. Each row of cards is supposed to be a portion of a valid word.
Challenge the previous player to name a valid word for each row.
Play a specialty card.
Draw a card.


The first player to empty their hand wins.

Specialty cards include:

Wild: may be played to a row and stand for any letter.
Back At You: reverses play order.
Invisible: pass for one turn, and a challenge to you from the next player goes to the previous player.
New Ghostword: allows a new row of cards to be played to.


—user summary

name: Domino Rummy
description:
A unique card game, whose cards mostly have spots like dominoes, and whose play is a bit like Rummy but still unique.

The 54-card deck consists of:
10 Deuces
12 Treys
12 Fours
10 Fives
2 Tens
6 Queens of Spades
2 Jokers

Players are dealt 4-card hands. In their turn a player:

Draws one or more cards from the deck or discard pile.
Plays one card from their hand on the table in front of them.
Optionally plays one or more Queens on top of other players' cards (one card per Queen), to discard both the cards. The target player may play a Joker to counter the Queen.
Discards a card.


The hand ends once one player has 4 cards on the table in front of them. Each player then scores:

The sum of the numbers of the cards in front of them.
If they went out, a bonus of 5 points, plus and extra 5 points if their cards are 2-3-4-5, or an extra 10 if they are 4 of a kind.
The sum of the cards' values still in hand is subtracted.


Hands are played until one player reaches at least 100 points, and the highest score wins.

Two decks can be combined for playing up to 8 players.

—user summary

name: Spellbound: Card Game
description:
The object of the game is to make words by adding your cards to columns of letters already on the table. Whenever a word is complete (i.e. it is not possible to add more letters to make a longer word) the player that completed the word removes the cards from the table and keeps them, scoring points. The game ends when a player has put down all their cards. All cards collected from formed words score positive points. All cards left in a player's hand at the end of the game score negative points.

—description from the rulebook

name: Sound Hounds
description:
Contents:

100 Playing Cards
Game Play Instructions


Playing Time: About 15 minutes

Draw "head" cards and match them with "tail" cards to make words. The first player to build three words with each "tail" card is the winner!

Learn as You Play

Recognize beginning sounds and word endings
Decode unfamiliar words
Build phonics skills


Game includes:

19 initial sounds
11 initial blends
31 word endings


—description from the back the box

name: Word Monkeys
description:
From publisher's website:

The game with banan-appeal. Spunky monkeys make spelling fun! This lively game has players building words and adding points as they go. An enjoyable way to boost word recognition, phonics, and addition skills.

From the back of the box:

Contents:

100 Playing Cards
Game Play Instructions


Playing Time: About 15 minutes

Build a word. Use as many letters as possible. Add up the points. Go bananas and build a bunch of words! The first player to reach 30 points wins. Wild Card keeps game play exciting!

Learn as You Play

Strengthen spelling and reading skills
Build word recognition and vocabulary
Develop phonics skills
Practice addition

name: Kapprodd
description:
A simple racegame with Canoes.You throw the dice and move as many steps as the dice shows. Sometimes you end your move at a spot where you either are lucky or poor.
In the beginning of the game you also have the opportunity to bet on whose canoe is going to win.

name: Arc of Eckaris
description:
Arc of Eckaris is a strategy board game for 4 to 6 players set in an original sci-fi universe.

During the game, you will use the influence of one of six unique factions to acquire planets, defeat your opponents, and/or capture the Arc of Eckaris.

Players take turns choosing from limited of number of actions to perform per turn including playing cards, using unique player powers, and deploying Influence, among others.

Players may win the game in one of three ways: Acquire 20 Victory Points, defeat all other players by depleting their Influence, or acquire the Arc of Eckaris.

—description from the publisher

name: Discovery of Australia
description: A roll-and-move game along a 100-space track depicting the various expeditions that discovered and settled Australia, from De Quiros and Torres in 1605, Tasman (1642), Dirk Hartog (1616), Dampier (1688 & 1699), Cook (1770), Phillp (1788), Bass (1798), Grant (1800) and Flinders 1802-03. Brief historical notes are given, and various spaces give penalties and bonuses.

name: Ik hou van Gorinchem
description: A promotionele game for the town of Gorinchem. It’s a retheme of The Game of Goose.

name: Quatro
description:
A cross between Scrabble and Memory/Concentration/Pelmanism.
—user summary

Quatro is a word game for 2, 3 or 4 players. Words are formed by remembering the position of letter coins placed face down on the playing board. Players compete for the highest score by making words of at least four letters. Keen memory and ingenuity are rewarded by bonus points for Premium and Dividend words.

OBJECTIVE

The objective is to turn up coins all of which together form a word of four or more letters. Scoring is based on the value of the letters in the word. In addition, bonuses are scored for Premium words, which are words containing five or more letters, and also for Dividend words, which are words made entirely of letters all of the same color (all gold or all black).

Charts, showing the frequency of the letters and the point value assigned to each letter, are printed on the playing board.

—description from the rulebook

name: Zoo-phonics 3 in 1 Game
description:
This early product of Zoo-phonics uses different decks with sets of pairs of cards. One deck has 26 pairs for each letter of the alphabet, along with the name of the animal assigned to that letter, e.g. Allie Alligator, Honey Horse, Vincent Vampire Bat. Another deck has 40 pairs of 2- or 3-letter blends and digraphs.

The three games are adaptations of traditional childrens' games: Zoophonia (Old Maid, except the one with the Zoophonia card wins); Zoo-Fish (Go Fish), and Zoo-Memory (Memory). The alphabet deck also says it can be used for spelling games. Whenever cards are requested or matches made, the player must say the card's animal name, make its sound, and do its sign according to the Zoo-phonics kinesthetic system.

—user summary

name: Time Thief
description:
There are only two time-travel devices in existence, and you and your friend have managed to steal them. They will allow you to be the perfect thieves, traveling through time to when your target is most vulnerable and snatching it away to the future ... er, present.

It wouldn't have been possible without your friend, but now that you have the time-travel device, you don't need him. So you have decided to go back to the night the time-travel devices were invented and steal them BOTH. Unfortunately, your backstabbing buddy had the same idea.

GOAL

You need to infiltrate the facility with the time-travel devices while the cameras are off, the alarm is disabled, and the robot guard is deactivated. If neither player successfully infiltrates, or both players infiltrate at the same time, shuffle the decks and start a new game. After all, you can both travel through time, so you might as well try again.

—description from the box and the rulebook

name: Castlecomb
description:
Castlecomb is a card laying game of territory control for 1-5 players. As you play cards of terrain, settlements, and strongholds to create territories of your own, watch out as other players are looking to do the same. The cards a have requirements that have to be met to be played and to be operational to score at the end of the game, where the high score is the victor.

—description form the designer
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Territory Building

name: SPPOKER
description:
"A unique card game of Spelling and Poker."

The Deck: The cards have traditional playing cards suit and rank in one corner (e.g. two of clubs, queen of hearts), and a letter of the alphabet in the opposite corner. There are also 2 jokers.

Play: For a hand, each player is dealt 7 cards, and looks for both the best poker hand, and the longest word, they have in their hand. Then each player holds out a fist with 0-2 tokens in it, and all open their hands at the same time. 0 tokens means they are trying for the best poker hand, 1 token for the longest word, 2 tokens for both (Double Down).

Scoring: For those trying for just the best poker hand, or just the longest word, the player who has the best hand gets 1 point, with tied players each getting 1 point. A player going Double Down must have the best hand in both areas, with no ties. If they do, they get 4 points, if not, they lose 2 points.

More hands are played until one player has 12 points in a 2-player game, 10 points for 3 or 4, 8 points for 5 or 6, 6 points for 7 or 8.

—user summary

name: Kern Alphabet Card Games
description:
This deck has two copies of each letter of the alphabet, with the letters painted by Donna Kern in delightful and creative ways. For example, the 'A' is an A-shaped apple with a bit out of it; the 'K' is made from keys, the 'R' from a ribbon, etc.

Rules are included for several games: Kern Rummy (draw and discard until you can use all your hand to make one or more words); children's games Go Fish, Rotten Egg (Old Maid) and Concentration; and KernWords (laying down cards in crossword fashion, with new cards not having to make words in every direction).

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Word Game

name: Pla-Pak
description:
The Pla-Pak deck has two cards for each letter, showing a few items that start with that letter, and two "Dunce" cards, showing a boy on a stool wearing a traditional Dunce cap.

Rules for 4 games are included:


Rummy-Dunce: 2-4 players each get 10 cards. Typical draw-and-discard play is done until one player can use his hand to spell one or more words; they score 10 points plus 1 point per each letter in others' hands that are not used in words they spell from their hands. Dunce cards are wild and stand for any letter. The first to 50 points wins.



Grand Champion: Like Rummy-Dunce, except the discard pile is spread out to see each card. One can take any card in the discard pile along with every card above it as long as they immediately lay down a word using that letter; only one card is discarded. When the deck is used up players use as many of their cards as they can to form words, and get one point per unused card. Each player is eliminated on reaching 50 total points, and the last player left is Grand Champion.



Hit the Bowl: A player sits in a chair and throws each card one at a time at a bowl 6 feet away. After the deck is all used the player gets 1 point for each card in the bowl, and spells as many words as they can from those cards, scoring the length of each word. First player to 50 wins.



Dunce: Played like Old Maid, using just one of the Dunce cards.


—user summary

name: Combilet
description:
Combilet is a combination letter game consisting of 76 cards. Each card has four selections of single and two letter combinations. The red side is made up of consonant-vowel, and vowel-consonant combinations, such as SA-AS, and the black side is made up of either two single letters, or a single letter and a double consonant, such as PR, TH etc., with some exceptions.

"The selections on each card are listed on the upper left hand corner. [Note there are four upper-left corners depending on how you orient the card, each one having a different selection in large font.]
—description from the rulebook

There are rules for 3 games:

Combilet

Each player has a 5-card hand. On their turn a player may do one of these:

Play a word of 5+ letters from the hand in front them.
Play a word of 3 or 4 letters from the hand to a common pool.
Take a word from the pool by adding cards that make it a 5+ letter word.
Take a word from another player by using cards that increase it, change it, or replace single letters with 2-letter combinations.


Then they fill their hand back out to 5 cards. Play presumably goes until the deck runs out or some other end condition is reached.
