Each word's score encourages using 2-letter combinations: its score is 5 points each for the first two combinations, 10 points each for each combination beyond two, and 1 point for each single-letter card in the word.

Fast Combilet

Each player gets 5 cards which they try to make one or more words out of. Scoring is similar to that in regular Combilet. The player with the highest-scoring hand gets his score and that of each other play.

Solitaire

The deck is split into 5 piles, and the player makes words from the top cards, laying them aside and trying to finish the whole deck.

—user summary

name: Words
description:
From a deck of 48 letter cards, the dealer chooses the size of the hand for the deal, dealing 3, 4 or 5 cards to each player face down. At a signal from the dealer, everyone looks at their hand and tries to make a word using all their cards. They can discard cards and be dealt replacements as desired. The first person to make a word says "Word!" and gets 10 points; achieving 100 points total over several hands wins the game.

An alternate way to play is to deal 8 cards per player. Players take turns placing one letter in the center of the table; if a player completes a word using all letters they take them and start a new "trick". Taking the most words wins.

—user summary

name: Monaco
description:
Monaco has two identical decks of 54 cards. 52 of them have:

Traditional playing card ranks and suits in the upper left corner (e.g. King of Spades)
A one- or two-letter prefix in the upper left corner (copied in small print above the card's rank).
Four suffixes of 1-4 letters listed below the card's suit along the left side. Each suffix is printed in either black, red, green or brown ink; the mix and order of the colors varies from card to card, so the color is probably significant but the pattern is hard to discern.


The remaining 2 cards contain a list of 300 words, each of which is a combination of a prefix and a suffix from the other cards. These words actually look mostly like nonsense words and are likely a set of names, perhaps associated with Monaco.

It looks apparent that an important part of the game is to combine cards so that a prefix and a suffix combine to make a word in the list. But the game's mechanics, the meaning of the different colors, and even its publication details are unknown until a copy of their rules can be found.

—user summary

name: Coreball: The Zero Gravity Sport – Technoticks Team Expansion
description:
The Technoticks are the most tech savvy team in the professional league. Their suits are fitted with the most advanced partial AI computers and they can hack anything in a matter of miliseconds. Their trickery makes them the most hated foe by the other teams. They enjoy that.

The Technoticks Team Expansions contains:
3 x Technotick miniatures.
6 x Merc miniatures in Technotick colours.
9 x Flyer cards.
16 x Playing cards.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Sports
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Footenstein
description:
Object of the game is to remove all the bolts from Frankenstein's foot one by one using the included "mad scientist wrench" tool. One wrong move and the foot comes "alive". There are several difficulty levels the game can be set to. The players are eliminated if they cause the foot to move - the last player standing is the winner.

—user summary
categories: Action / Dexterity, Children's Game, Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: LINGO
description:
The LINGO deck consists of 54 playing cards. Each contains a letter and a number 1-11.

Each player is dealt 3 cards, and in a turn a player either plays 1-3 cards to the table to form a word, or draws 1 card and discards 1 card.

The cards in the center form a 5x5 array. With the first word played, one of the cards is designated as the center of the square. After the first word, each word must use all the cards played and at least one card already on the table. Consecutive letters in a word must be adjacent in any direction, orthogonal or diagonal, but the word as a whole may zigzag and change directions. It's like the array from Big Boggle, built up gradually with cards rather than dice.

Each word scores like this: letters already on the board score their printed value, letters played from the hand are double their value, unless they are played to a corner of the square, or are the last cards played in the square, in which case their value is tripled.

Their is also a solitaire game: one plays cards in a row, one at a time, and when a set of consecutive cards make a word, they are made into a single pile with any of those letters on the top. If all the cards can be combined into a single pile at the end, one wins.

—user summmary

name: Nuts And Bots
description:
In Nuts And Bots, 2-4 players compete to construct their giant robot, a MegaBot, by building it part by part. First player to build their MegaBot wins.

The board is the Factory and consists of shared Workstation Tiles that players move around the Factory to form Assembly Lines. Blueprints show the pattern of Workstations required in an Assembly Line to build legs, torsos, arms, and heads, and all of these are needed to complete a MegaBot.

Players have a number of WorkBots and can build more. WorkBots are the driving force in the Factory and each Workstation needs a WorkBot on it. Only then will the Workstation be a functioning part of an Assembly Line. Only by moving Workstations around the Factory to match a Blueprint and placing a WorkBot on each Workstation will the next part of a MegaBot come rolling off the Assembly Line.

On their turn, players can move a Workstation and move a WorkBot. Each type of Workstation is limited in number, and players will try to move Workstations out of other players’ Assembly Lines to use within their own. Take control of a Workstation by having more WorkBots on it than anyone else, then it can be moved. Protect a Workstation by having enough WorkBots left on it to prevent the other players moving it.

Nuts And Bots has simple rules and simple actions but requires thought and puzzle-solving to win in an ever-changing environment.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: X Arrr!
description:
In X Arrr!, 2-4 pirate crews journey around an island full of secret paths to collect their buried treasure. X marks the spot! The first player to get both pirates and all of their treasure back to their ship is the winner. Arrr!

The island is built randomly from discs showing paths that can be rotated to link with the paths on neighbouring island discs. On their turn players can change paths or rotate any island disc. Pirates automatically move forward if rotating an island disc extends the path the pirate is on, and if they pass over a treasure they’ll pick it up, but end their turn on the same disc as another pirate crew and they’ll be ambushed.

It takes skill to navigate the island, collect all the treasures, and avoid the other pirate crews, but make the right moves and a pirate can travel long distances along the same style of path in their turn.

X Arrr! usually plays in 20-25 minutes. It has simple rules and simple actions but still requires players to think and plan to win the game.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Modular Board, Pattern Building, Point to Point Movement

name: Wobuga
description:
Wobuga comes from WOrd BUilding GAme.

It includes 72 letters: 6 each for A, E, I, O; 4 each for U, Y; 2 each of all other letters.

To start, the letters are stirred face down, and each player draws 5 letters. A turn consists of drawing a letter and then either making a word out of one's hand, or adding one or more letters to words already on the table without rearranging their order. After playing, a player draws again and continues playing until announcing "I am thru", and the turn goes to the left. One can also make a sentence out of their own words, after which those words cannot be further altered. When a turn is over and other players see plays they could have done, they say "Wobuga" and can make the play for them and score the points they could have scored.

Points scored are: 5 points for each letter played during one's turn, 10 points for each word of a sentence, and 25 points for making the word "Wobuga". The highest score when all the letters are used wins.

There is also a solitaire mode where a player takes repeated turns and tries to use all the letters. Also, Wobuga Rush, where two players each play with a half deck in solitaire mode, and play through all their letters. Each player gets 5 points for each letter not used, and -10 points for being the first to say "I am thru"; the lower score wins.

—user summary

name: Word for Word
description:
Includes a deck of 61 cards having two sets of consonants (42) and three sets of vowels (15) (each letter having a point value), and four wild cards; plus a reference card showing the letter values, and a 1-minute sand timer.

Players have hands of 8 cards. The first player lays down a word from their hand of at least 3 cards. From then on, a turn is made by making a new word using at least one of the cards on the table, and at least on of the cards in the hand (the unused table cards are discarded), and drawing back up to an 8 card hand. The new word's score is the sum of the letter values newly laid down, with the older letters not scoring; except if all the table letters are used then the score is the entire word, doubled; if all the cards in hand are used in the new word the score is the entire word tripled.

The game ends when every player has had an equal number of turns after a player's score reaches a pre-determined total.

The solitaire game has the player playing cards to the table one at a time, either starting a new column (up to 5 columns), or adding a letter to an existing column. Two columns can also be combined end to end. Whenever a column forms a complete word it can be removed. The player wins if they can remove all the cards.

—user summary

name: Morgarhum Market
description:
Morgarhum Market is a 2-player mini game played with a deck of 18 cards. In the game, players are rival traders in the fictional market town of Morgarhum.

Players will draw and play cards representing goods of different values such as weapons, food, drink and accessories. Each goods card also has an action that is activated when played, allowing players to do such things as conceal goods, alter the value of goods on the market, or to have certain goods confiscated.

Additional powerful abilities are available by bribing town officials and players must decide when or if to activate these.

Players compete over three rounds to have the highest value goods on their market stall, with each round representing a day of trading.

—description form the publisher

name: Scorpion Dice Game
description: A dice game in a tube, where the dice have a scorpion instead of the 1. The object is to get the highest score after 3 turns.

name: Casino
description:
This is a roll-and-move board game, which merges the gameplay of Monopoly with Casino "mini-games."

On a player's turn, they roll two dice and move clock-wise around a board, and take the action of the spot they land on.

If a player lands on a property, and it is unowned, they may purchase it. If it is owned, then they must play the owner rent money.

If they land on "Tough Luck" and "Jackpot" card spots, the player takes a card from the corresponding card pile and follows the instructions on the chosen card.

The unique aspect of the game is that if you land on a "Casino" spot, then the player plays a Casino "mini-game." There are four mini-games: Roulette, Black Jack, Craps, and slots. (The game comes with a small roulette wheel, and dice to replicate slot machines.) Players can place bets on these games.

The first player to reach $35,000 (or the person with the most money after a set amount of time) is the winner.

—user summary
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Alphanasta
description:
A straight-forward adaptation of the card game Canasta into a word game. Instead of clustering traditional cards into melds of identical rank, lettered cards are melded into words.

The Alphanasta deck consists of two packs of 54 cards, which combined include: 40 vowels, 48 consonants, 8 doubles (e.g. J/K or W/X, where you can use it as either letter), 8 pairs (e.g. ER or ED, where both letters are used in the printed order, and 4 triples (ING). Vowels are worth 5 points each, consonants 10, doubles and pairs 20, and triples 50.

Each player is dealt 13 cards each, or 11 in partnership games. In a turn a player:
1. Draws: either A) the top of the draw pile, or B) the entire discard pile. B) can only be done if the top discard is used to extend an existing word, or meld a new word of 4+ letters using cards from the hand.
2. May do this as much as they wish: A) meld new words from the hand of 4+ letters; B) add cards to either end of an tabled word of theirs, making it a new word.
3. Discards a card from the hand, unless they are going out.

Doubles, pairs, and triples are considered Wild cards for the purposes of impure words (it's impure if it ends in a Wild); and of freezing the discard pile (which cannot be drawn unless the top card is used for a new word of 5+ letters rather than 4+).

A player or team may go out if they have at least two Word Canastas (words of 7+ letters), or one Alphanasta (a word of 10+ letters played from the hand). At this point all players score the sum of the letter values in the words they have on the table, plus these bonuses:
100 points for going out
300 an impure Word Canasta
500 a pure Words Canasta
1000 an Alphanasta
100 for each letter over 7 in a Word Canasta.

The first player to reach 3000 points over several hands, or 5000 for partnership games, wins.

—user summary
publishers: Courtney Graphica, The Valentine Publishing Co. Pty. Ltd.

name: Dragons of Thruduit
description:
Dragons of Thruduit is an LCG game where you battle with elemental dragons!

Object of the game: in order to win you need to defeat all the opponents dragons. This can be done in any assortment of ways, but will be discussed later.

Dragons of Thruduit’s play has phases to it.
1: draw phase
2: level phase
3: play phase
4: attack phase
5: resolve phase
6: end phase

-Draw phase-
During the draw phase each player draws a single card. The player who goes first does not get to draw a card on their first turn.

-Level phase-
For this phase each player gains soul tokens equal to their head dragon's soul cost. You can only have a max soul count of 20. If you go above this, just take 20.
Now each player can choose to level up. If you have 10 souls then you can spend them in order to gain one level. Each player starts at level one.

-Play phase-
You may now play cards. If you wish to play a card there are a few requirements you must meet. You must be that card’s level or higher, and you must also pay that’s card soul cost. If you do both of these things then you can play the card. After you play a card, remove soul tokens from your soul pool according to the cards soul cost. Example: if you play a card that costs 5 souls, you must remove 5 soul tokens. You can only play 3 cards onto the field a single play phase.

-Attack Phase-
The first player will now attack. The player can choose any number of dragons to attack. Your dragon can only attack at an opponent’s dragon with a lower than or equal level to that dragon. Once you attack that dragon its health decreases by the attacking dragons damage value. You may attack with any number of dragons on the board as long as they can fulfill the requirements above.

-Resolve phase-
Both players now remove health counters from all their dragons that took damage this turn.

-End Phase-
Your turn ends and your opponent's turn starts.

—description from the publisher

name: Stuck for Words
description:
Includes 200 letter cards and a sand timer.

Each player draws 16 letters face down. The timer is turned, and each player turns their letters face up, arranges them into a 4x4 grid, and moves them around to form the longest word they can find. When time runs out, if the word is valid, they keep the letters used, and the rest are returned.

After 4 rounds, the player with the most kept letters wins. Play can be varied in difficulty with more or fewer letters, or in length with more or fewer rounds.

—user summary

name: Pirate Attack!:  The Magic Shop
description:
The first expansion pack of 50 cards Pirate Attack- The Magic Shop, adds a Magic Shop full of things to help your ships and hurt your enemies.

Double your ships cannons, double its strength, reincarnate a ship, make a ship fire to the left or right instead of its normal target.

Also adds a Hurricane Card and The Royal Navy.

This tuck box will fold up and be placed under the plastic tray in the Main Game box and the cards will fit into the Main Game tray.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Pirates

name: Pirate Attack!: Raise the Dead
description:
The second expansion pack of 50 cards Pirate Attack- Raise The Dead, adds more ships, more main deck cards and more Magic Cards.

Raise a dead ship, Duplicate a ship, Spirit of Good Fortune, Sails of Invisibility, Eliminate Add Ons are several more of the things in the magic shop to help you and hurt your enemy.

Also adds a 3 larger ships and a larger Royal Navy.

This tuck box will fold up and be placed under the plastic tray in the Main Game box and the cards will fit into the Main Game tray.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Pirates

name: Pirate Attack!: Miss-Direction
description:
The third expansion pack of 50 cards Pirate Attack- Miss-Direction, adds more ships, more Magic Cards, more Sea Creatures and Wind Storms.

Exploding Cannons, Miss- Direction to redirect a cards location Force an Attack to force your opponets to attack each other.

Also adds 2 more ships, Stranded on an Island, Whirlpools and Wind Storms.

This tuck box will fold up and be placed under the plastic tray in the Main Game box and the cards will fit into the Main Game tray.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Pirates

name: Pirate Attack!:  Walk the Plank
description:
The forth expansion pack of 100 cards and 2 Dice Pirate Attack- Walk The Plank, adds another ship, more Magic Cards and many new play cards that create all new things to happen during the game.

Force Field, Vision to remove Sails of Invisibility, Return to Port to send ships back to port and get rid of the Armada Card and The Gambler to gamble gold or ships against other players.

Also adds another ship, Walk The Plank, The Trap, Smoke Screen, Power Play, The Magician, Damn Pirates, Insurance, Davy Jones Locker, End Of The World and other bonus cards.

This tuck box will fold up and be placed under the plastic tray in the Main Game box and the cards will fit into the Main Game tray.

—description from the publisher

name: Pirate Attack!:  The Tavern
description:
The fifth expansion pack of 100 cards and 1 Chip Pirate Attack- The Tavern, adds a whole new market. The Tavern is a place where you can bribe a drunk sailor into telling you secrets and information, some good, some bad.

The Tavern is full of good and bad items. Items that will help you, give you bonuses or hurt you or other players. You take your chance at The Tavern, but when it helps, it really helps.

Also adds some bonus cards to the main deck.

This tuck box will fold up and be placed under the plastic tray in the Main Game box and the cards will fit into the Main Game tray.

—description form the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Pirates

name: Pirate Attack!:  Special Abilities
description:
The sixth (and final) expansion pack of 50 cards and 2 Dice Pirate Attack- Special Abilities, gives players (who choose to) a Special Ability, but only if they are willing to Sell Their Soul to get it.

These cards are optional for players that want them. You can get a Special Ability like Magic Master, Money Master, The Vault, Raid The Shop and more that will help you throughout the game, but to get this you must first Sell Your Soul by getting something like Sharks, Banned From The Bar, Easy Target and No Free Gold.

Also add 20 more ships with special abilities built into the ship.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Pirates

name: Wordage
description:
Wordage has two identical decks; one deck is used for 2-4 players, both decks for 5-8 players. Each deck has: 3 A's and E's, 2 O's, I's and S's, and 1 of each other letter, all in red, and the same again all in black, plus two Joiner cards that can stand for any letter, making 68 cards. Each letter has a point value of 1-5.

Each player is dealt 14 cards (children 10 cards), and during their turn a player draws a card, lays down cards if possible, and discards a card. The initial lay-down must be one or more words that have at least 14 points in value and include at least one 5+ letter word in one color (for children, at least 10 points and no color requirement). A word's value is the sum of its letters' values, plus bonuses for length, doubled if the word is of one color.

In turns after the initial lay-down, a player may also: draw the top discard instead of the top of the deck; add letters to any word on the table instead of playing a new word (this doesn't score points, though); replace a Joiner (wild) card with the letter it currently stands from from the hand.

The player who plays all the cards in their hand except one which is then discarded, wins the round. The game is won by the first player to win two rounds consecutively; for shorter games, the consecutive requirement is dropped.

In the party version of the game, points for words played are tallied and totaled -- a score pad is included -- and a round's winner gets a bonus of 50 points plus the values of the cards left in others' hands.

—user summary

name: Das grosse Bibel-Quiz-Spiel
description:
777 questions and answers about the bible. Goal of the game is to get a complete set of cards consisting of 5 different categories and create a Picture with all of them.

—user summary

name: Zauber-Lesen
description:
The game contains 64 cards with pictures and the corresponding words and 32 envolopes.

The kids put all cards in the envelopes so that they can only read the words. The envelopes are put face down on the table and the start player takes one envelope and tries to read the word. If he doesn't manage to, he opens the envelope and looks at the picture and let everybody else know what he sees.

Then the player can have a look at another envelope to find pairs.

—user summary

name: Barbie: Traum-Spiel
description: Jump and run dice game for 2-6 girls.

name: Loriots Spielekiste
description:
Loriots Spielekiste ("Loriots game box") contains two games from Loriot:

Way to success
Rummy with Loriot images

name: Urodziny Pluto
description: Short jump and run game to catch Pluto.

name: Face Another Foe: Wargaming the Lace Wars
description:
Based on the best selling MAD DOGS Indian Mutiny rules. Medium to large scale battles. Inc sample army lists and scenarios. Inc Jacobite Wars and War in the East.

—description from publisher
categories: Age of Reason, Miniatures, Pike and Shot, Wargame

name: Bongopoly
description:
GAME GOALS
Idea of game is to, through shrewd purchasing and luck, manage to survive by either bonging your self or your friends to oblivion.
RULES
BASIC EQUIPMENT The game consist of the BOARD, with space over which the player's pieces are moved. There are two DICE, TOKEN of various color , TWO sets of card for CHANCE and BOOBY-TRAP pace . There i a TITLE DEED card for every property and FOUR canister which hold the Bonging material or STASH of your choice and with this material you purchase the properties.
STARTING THE GAME Place board on table with Chance and Booby-Trap cards face down on their allotted paces. Each player is provided one colored token to represent him on his travels around the board. The bonging material or stash is used to purchase, pay penalties or rent for properties on the board. NOTE: Each player must supply their own stash and all players must begin with EQUAL amounts of STASH. Recommended for this game is at least one canister of cleaned bonging material or stash for each player. NOTE: ONE player must also supply a Bong to be used in conjunction with this game.That player is elected BONGMASTER( See Bongmaster).Each player chooses one colored token and shakes one dice. The player with the highest total start the game first. All players place their TOKE on the corner marked UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION "GO".
Upon landing on the space with his TOKEN, a player may be entitled to purchase RealEstate or other properties -or be obliged to pay bongs, pay taxes, draw a Chance or Booby-Trap card or "You Have Been Busted", etc.
If a player passes out or is unable to continue to play PRIOR to going bankrupt, all of that player's assets are divided as equally as possible by the players on each side of him.
The game is won by the last player not to go bankrupt (or pass out).

name: Lemming Launcher
description:
A fast-paced meeple-roller where worker placement and area control strategies will keep you on top.

Lemming athletes of all stripes are teaming up to launch over the edge of competition cliffs around the world.

Your goal is to free fall and land with enough skill (and dignity) to dominate the landing field and lead your squad of furry little rodents to international victory ... go team!!

"Pay attention to landing styles ... they may save your bacon in a tiebreaker." Lois Leapworth, Red Squad Leader, Big Falls Aqua Flyers, Big Falls, B.C., Canada

Earn Achievement Trophies for squad landing formations and landing pad area control -- the squad with the most trophies at the end of the game wins!

Download rules and PnP files here: https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/2177605/lemming-launcher-pn...

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Worker Placement

name: Varsity Quarterback
description:
A card driven football game, with players calling plays and drawing a card to determine the outcome.

The board is cardboard, with two push pins for the 10 yard markers and one for the football.

—user summary

name: Bubbles
description:
It’s Bath time, and this means war! Defend your Bubble Forts against your enemies as you seek to destroy theirs. Throw bubbles, seek out treasure and martial those hedgehogs as you prepare to play dirty for some good clean fun!

Aim of the Game:
Be the last duck standing by Destroying your opponents’ bubble forts. This is done by landing three bubbles on forts of the same colour.

Overview: Each player starts with a number of Bubble Forts in play and a hand of six cards. These cards are either Bubbles (which can be played on other players Forts so long as they match colour) or Treasure cards (these will be items that help you defend yourself or hinder you opponents' plays).

Players take turns playing a card from their hand, with opponents reacting with their own Treasure cards. Any time a Bubble Fort has 3 or more Bubbles on it, it pops and gives the owner extra cards to play with. But if all of your Forts are popped, you are out! The winner is the last player standing.

—description from the publisher

name: Campo
description:
High tempo, back and forth gameplay. A competitive roll and move football (soccer) boardgame for two players. The game may be played by two groups of people but the rules of the game are still the same.

Roll the dice and tactically choose where to move the ball towards your opponents goal. Play either a timed game or until a certain score. As in football the winner is the player with the most goals.

The board is double sided. One side is Campo: Arena for age 6+ and on the other, Campo: Stadion for ages 10+.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Panjango Game
description:
The fast-moving, quick-thinking, fun challenge game exploring the world of work!

Ever dreamed of launching a rocket to Mars? Or coaching the sports stars of the future? How about saving lives or protecting the planet? Explore more than 120 amazing jobs with The Panjango Game!

Play with up to six players to complete a wide variety of quick-fire challenges including Acting Out, Story Chains, Unscramble or Disaster Plans!

The game is designed for use by young people aged 8 and over in the home, or the classroom, and includes 24 challenge varieties, 10 mini games and information on 126 careers.

- Gives learning context and demonstrates the exciting applications of learning in life after school
- Develops key skills such as team working, communication, problem solving, creativity and confidence
- Encourages risk taking and helps young people to discover their hidden talents
- Makes career learning more fun and engaging through an interactive exploration of the world of work
- Opens minds, broadens horizons, raises aspirations and helps children find their purpose
mechanics: Acting, Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Storytelling

name: Ninja Ninja: Throwing Stars Card Game
description:
Ninja Ninja is a highly strategic card and throwing foam stars game that the whole family can play.

Decks are made up of standard cards, challenge cards, master ninja cards, body cards with stands and foam throwing stars.

Ninja Ninja's play rounds to capture other cards. Playing a Ninja Ninja throwing card allows you to take out the competition by throwing ninja ninja stars at other playing cards on stands. If you don't master the art of throwing Ninja Ninja foam stars and you miss, then the opponent gets your Ninja Ninja star. This is where your inner Ninja Ninja skills come in. The game gets more involved as stars are exchanged and more player cards are lost in Ninja Ninja battle!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Flicking, Open Drafting, Variable Player Powers

name: Crumpet Chaos
description:
Englishman everywhere are going crazy trying to collect their crumpets. The Royal Family, with their bad teeth and etiquette slips, are heavily influencing each Player's ability to collect and keep their mouth watering slabs of deliciousness.

Crumpet Chaos is a card game. Flip a card to reveal a royal action for your crumpets. The object of the game is to transfer six crumpets into the safe zone. The first person to safely collect six crumpets WINS.

—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Card Game, Humor, Napoleonic, Party Game, Renaissance

name: Dragnarok
description:
Being a dragon is usually pretty awesome —wings, fire breath, a big pile o'gold to sleep on at night — until THEY showed up, that is, a "party" of adventurers who trespassed on your land, in your cavern, to steal YOUR gold. Why? What rights did they have to it? Why is it okay to trample all over yours? Good news, though, as you've found the village and castle keep they call home. You're fed up, and you're a dragon, so you're not reasonable. Time to get your gold back and to burn them and their village to the ground.

Dragnorak is a scenario-based, fantasy dexterity game in which players, acting as dragons, burn hero and villager meeples on a three-dimensional board. During their turn, a player may take a free movement action, then one of four different dexterity attack actions: Firebomb, Spit, Boulder Wheel, and Swoop. Most gold wins, of course, as befits dragons, and don't worry about missed shots because they build up your RAGE, which allows you to keep attacking until ideally there is nothing left.

—description from the publisher

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: Protectors G.U.A.R.D. Monster – Sky Sentinel
description:
Sky Sentinel has earned a place among G.U.A.R.D.'s defenders as one of the first super mechs created to protect the Earth, one of two initial Liberty-class weapons platforms. After the tragic destruction of its counterpart, Laser Knight, Sky Sentinel stood alone for a time against those who would destroy the planet, taking advantage of its advanced mobility to rapidly redeploy from one theater to another. This revered super mech is exceptionally equipped to coordinate the efforts of strike fighters and rocket choppers in its vicinity, unleashing unparalleled concentrated firepower.

—description from the box

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: Destroyers Martian Menace Monster – Deimos-9
description:
This enigmatic tripod walker known only as Deimos-9 would follow after the Ares Mothership and continue the process of harvesting resources while expeditiously dismantling Earth's defenses. Impacting initially in a compact spherical form, it unfolded to reveal its long legs and extending manipulator appendages, proving it could swiftly cross any terrain as it focused on urban centers. Deimos-9 has shown the capability of reaping vast amounts of energy in minutes and seems to prefer to prey on power plants, solar grids, and other high-energy locations. Its grappling manipulators and limbs are made of advanced Martian metals and polymers, being extremely durable despite a fragile appearance.

—description from the box

name: Hobby Farmer
description:
The game Hobby Farmer is an attempt to share real-life hobby farm experiences through a board game that everyone can enjoy. The goal is to build a self-sufficient hobby farm, by being the first player to earn the winning number of points by pairing livestock with crops to create sustainable habitats. 2-4 players, ages 6 and up.

On each turn, the player rolls the die and moves the number of spaces indicated. Depending on where he/she lands, the player may purchase livestock animals--such as pigs, horses, or chickens--or food habitats (aka, 'crops')--such as apple orchards, pasture, or vegetable gardens. When an animal or crop is purchased, a tile is placed on the player's farmstead in one of the 16 allotted spaces. Depending on how the player places his/her tile, points will be awarded. For example, placing honeybees next to a flower garden will award 2 points. The first player to reach 7, 10, or 14 points (novice, medium, difficult gameplay) wins.

Players earn currency in the game whenever someone lands on the "Farmer's Market" space. Cards are drawn from a special deck indicating which items are in demand at the Farmer's Market. Depending on which animals or crops the player has on his/her farmstead, he/she will be awarded currency accordingly. He/she can then use that currency to purchase more animals or crops to place on their farm.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction: Turn Order Until Pass, Commodity Speculation, Tile Placement

name: Sugar Maple
description:
You are a settler in a new land that is blessed with abundant sugar-producing Maple Trees. Starting with nothing but your sugar shack and a good measure of determination, you must build your sugar mapling enterprise from the ground up. Exploring the forest and tapping the right kinds of trees will generate cash flow that you can use to upgrade your equipment and expand your operation. But beware, other settlers have similar ambitions and will try to beat you to the tap.
To play, each player chooses a cabin site on the gameboard and places their cabin. They also place one tree tap on a tract of land that is adjacent to their cabin. On each turn, the player rolls a die and moves along a track. Depending on where they land, they may be able to purchase supplies or run into danger.

Whenever any player lands on the Sugar Maple tile, all players participate in the syrup harvest as follows: First each player draws one tree card for every tap placed. The tree cards indicate how many gallons of syrup are collected. After all the tree cards are counted, players receive currency (gallons of syrup) that they can use to purchase more land and place more taps.

The game is won by the first player to place all of his/her taps. In a 2-player game, this is 8 taps. In a 3-player game, 7 taps. In a 4-player, 6 taps.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Worker Placement

name: Lunetas
description:
The night is dark and starry, the waters are calm. In the midst of this, navigators try to find constellations, to chart the path of their long journeys. In order to do this, they observe closely, through their lunettes, the patterns of distance between each of the stars.

In Lunetas, each player represents one of these navigators who, in turn, will try to find, in a sky formed by pieces of patterns different from stars, one of the constellations that have in hand, observing the disposition and the colors of the stars that form it. The goal is to find as many constellations before the night ends, trying to get maximum points by solving constellations of varying levels of difficulty.

—description from the publisher

name: Cordel
description:
The Cordel is one of the most remarkable literary genres of Brazilian literature, and its writers, the "cordelistas", lead a poetic life, but also very common. In Cordel, you will be a "cordelista", who builds his life by obtaining and managing inspirations, used to write his "cordels" and take them to the popular fair, marking his captive presence in the line of "cordels".

On the other hand, a "cordelista" is also fundamentally a reader, so you will buy other players' "cordels" for your collection. The best "cordelista" will be the one who can be present with its "cordels" on the clothesline, building patterns of string color sequences, and also obtaining a diverse collection of them. To do this, you must manage your actions well, so you can complete your goals before the others.

In their turn, each player has action points, which can be spent writing cordels (spending inspiration), publishing them, buying cordels from other writers, completing goals or collecting new inspirations. Goals are the key to the game, as the victory points guaranteed by it make up the bulk of the final score. Among these objectives, there are 3 categories: the color standards of the cordels on the poles, the presence of players on the poles and the collection of cordels.

The match ends when one of the players reaches a certain number of goals, then the points are scored for the completed goals and other smaller forms of the score. The one who gets the most points at the end will win.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition

name: Korruptônia
description:
The Democratic Republic of Korruptonia is in turmoil after the last president was suddenly removed from office (once again). The result of this was a dangerous instability, which swept the influence of the main parties in all regions of Korruptônia, creating a fertile environment for a non-partisan outlet of the whole country. So to conserve the stewardsh... or rather, the Korruptonian democracy, the country's main political parties articulate an emergency electoral campaign in order to regain partisan prestige and elect a representative.

In order to be able to elect its representative, the party must increase its influence in the regions of the country, through the presence of its candidate or the support of the media, personalities, smaller parties and companies. With the use of mechanics like area control, auction and hand and resource management, Korruptônia is a strategic game of fantasy themed.

There are five regions of Korruptônia, and each one has different demographic characteristics in each game. All these regions begin with a high influence of the partisans and with almost no influence of the great political parties - each party only initiates with a minor influence in its original region. Each player will have five weeks (or five rounds) to reverse this scenario, gaining enough influence for his candidate to lead the polls at the end of the game.

To achieve this, players will have to manage well each of the phases of the rounds: the campaign phase and the political action phase. In each round, the position of the candidates in the polls will determine the order of the players, in descending order.

In the campaign stage, players must decide whether to move their candidate and pay the costs (of money and speech, which are two of the three resources that the parties must administer) to campaign wherever they are, gaining influence in doing so .

After that, in the political actions phase, each player must take one of the actions of the cards in his hand, eventually having to pay his costs (of money, speech and government positions, which are the three features of the game). These actions range from setting up campaign committees, influencing news media for or against candidates, and also hiring famous people for your campaign, joining smaller parties and attracting companies to fund the campaign (these last three actions require a auction with the other parties). After making an action, the player can exchange resources with the political market, which varies with each negotiation, and also use one of the political actions of the open cards on the table, paying extra costs for this. At the end of each round, the party influence in each region determines an update of the voting intentions of the candidates in the polls.

At the end of five weeks, the party ahead in the polls will win the match.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Hand Management, Modular Board, Variable Phase Order

name: Taquara-Castelo
description:
Taquara-Castelo is a promotional postcard game developed by the collaborative studio Casa do Goblin (Brazil) for a series of collectible flyers of the Castelo das Peças (Rio de Janeiro) event, in which both the playing area and the rules are contained in the space of the back of the flyer.

In this game, players are drivers who must drive their vans, collecting and leaving passengers around the city, while trying to leave the passengers in Castelo (a neighborhood in the central zone of Rio de Janeiro) at the most opportune moment. For this, the vans must cross the track sections, respecting the correct hand of each of them, avoiding being blocked by the others. Managing the van's ability is important: the more crowded, the fewer stretches it can go through in a move. In the end, those who have collected and left a more varied number of passengers will receive a high amount of points, and whoever has more points will win!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Alpha Charlie Tango
description:
Alan Turing, a brilliant mathematician, proved that intelligence can win wars by deciphering the German Enigma code during World War II. Likewise, in Alpha Charlie Tango, players have the challenge of uncovering their opponents' secret codes, deciphering each of their parts through a meticulous and strategic choice of which false messages to send, before they discover their code.

There are five possible characters, but several combinations, and each time a player sends a three character message, each of the other players signals the presence of these characters in their code (if there are equal characters, only one character must be signaled, which the mission of figuring out your code even harder). In turn, a person may try to deduce a part of the code from another person, but if he makes a mistake, he should reveal a part of his own code. Whoever is the only one still has hidden parts of his own code!

—description from the designer
categories: Deduction, Spies/Secret Agents, World War II

name: Os Moscovis
description:
The Moscovis are a very friendly family of fly-spiders. However, all Moscovis have some peculiar and hereditary characteristics. The first is that they do not see the colors well, and they reverse the ability to identify each one a little. That would not be a big problem, were it not for another Moscovis trait: a serious food restriction. For Moscovis, eating flakes of certain colors can have serious consequences, from a bellyache to more serious things! That is, a Moscovis can never "fly" away from it's attention!

In this way, each player is in the shoes of a member of this family in "The Moscovis", trying to correctly identify the colors of the flies, in the order in which they are arranged, using the colors they have in mind (or better, in the hands)! The letters have the name of one color, but the color of the letter is different, and each needs to put the names of the colors in order according to the colors of the flies, as soon as possible. The difficulty is heightened by the fact that each set of cards has different combinations of colors and names.

name: Kam'on: Master Expansion
description:
KAM'ON Master Deck expansion with 156 total cards. Includes 112 original starter deck cards, an additional 32 premium expansion cards, and 12 exclusive FOIL cards.

—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Negotiation, Party Game

name: SWUP
description:
SWUP is a fun and entertaining card game for the whole family. SWUP makes you use your brain to calculate the best possible way of using the cards you are dealt. Block your opponents by building with the right cards and if you remove the last card on the table you get a SWUP. A great math game where you must calculate and stay sharp to win.

SWUP is based on Casino, but with added/changed elements.

Each player is dealt four cards, and four cards are dealt to the table (only first round). Then players either take a trick, by adding cards on the table to become the same value as the card they play, build new cards by adding their card to a card already on the table, or play their cards on the table. Doubles and triples can also be built (and they can't be changed). Once all players have played their four cards, each player is deal four new cards. Play continues until all cards are dealt and played.

Points are scored the follwoing in a players trick pile:
Most cards: 1 point
Most black cards: 2 points
Last trick: 1 point
Each star: 1 point
Each SWUP (clearing the table): 1 point

name: Word Games
description:
This contains:

112 plastic letter tiles
4 plastic tile rack
rules booklet.


There is no board, tiles just being played to the table.

The rules booklet is titled "Eight Different Word Games", and contains rules for:

Crossword
Anagrams
Word Rummy
Word Dominoes
Word Ghost
Snatch Words
Word Solitaire
Pass Words


—user summary

name: Russell's Famous Card Games Children's Library
description:
The box for this collection is made like a book, saying "Card Games for Children" on the spine, and "Russell's FAMOUS CARD GAMES Children's Library" on the front cover, with balloons stating the names of the included games on both covers.

The box also opens like a book into two sides, each of which holds the boxes for 6 card games. These are all in Russell's Big Little card game boxes which are like small match boxes, in size 2 3/4" x 1 7/8" x 1", with the inside sliding out like a drawer, just as in a matchbox. Each side's games slide out away from the spine, but are visible while in the box through cellophane windows.

The left side is labelled "Modern Favorite Games" and contains:

Game of Flags of the United Nations
Domino Cards
Howdy Doody
Cross Numbers
Wild West
Sky Trails


The right side is labelled "Old Favorite Games" and contains:

Old Maid
Authors
Dr. Quack
Crossword
Animal Rummy
Slap Jack


—user summary

name: City
description:
CITY is a fast-paced card game where you compete to be first to build a new city. The closer you are to achieving urban success, the more your opponents will try and stop you! It's a good thing you aren't without weapons of your own.

Each player is trying to build their city. They do this by placing building cards down on the table in front of them.

Opponents may prevent this from happening by attacking their efforts through unique wild cards, swaps, coordination with other players, and building-specific attack cards like Pollution or Thieves.

The first player to successfully build 4 buildings that are free from attacks, wins.

—description from the publisher

name: TMNT Pizza Party Tin Game
description:
Hey Dudes and Dudettes! The Ninja Turtles are having a totally radical pizza party, and you’re the chefs of honor! You’ll need to make the most extreme pizzas on the planet to shell-shock your customers with your outrageous creations! Work quickly though, because as you’re slamming down slices, so are your friends, and the first chef to earn 15 points by making the best pizzas wins!
TMNT Pizza Party is a fast-paced, dexterity game.

Pick your favorite TMNT character, then be the first to build that characters favorite pizza to win the game. Each player draws pizza slice cards into their hand and tries to build a pizza utilizing the same ingredients. Once a pizza is built, the player that has built their pizza with ingredients that best match their character card, wins the game!

—description from the publisher

name: Word-Spell
description:
A Hebrew-language word card game that children and adults can play. It includes:

28 letter cards, showing a large Hebrew letter in block print form, a small cursive form of the letter in the corner, and a background illustration of a word that starts with that letter. (Letters that have multiple cards have a different illustration for each one.)
6 word cards showing two different words, each having its point score and a picture of the what the word is.
1 clown (joker) card which can be used to stand for any letter.
1 rules card, the rules taking both sides.


(Note: The Hebrew alphabet consists primarily of consonants. There are diacritical marks that can indicate vowels, but they are not used anywhere in this game except the front of the box for the game's name.)

The word cards are shuffled at the start of the game, and the letter cards are shuffled at the start of each round. Each round consists of revealing the top word card, dealing 5 letter cards to each player, and revealing the top letter card to start the discard pile. A turn consists of drawing a card (the top of either the draw or discard pile), and discarding a card.

The hand ends when a player can spell one of the two words on the word card from the letters in their hand, at which point they score the points that word is worth. In the rare case that the letter deck has been gone through twice with no one spelling a word, the letter cards are all gathered and re-dealt.

After 5 rounds, the player with the highest score wins.

—user summary

name: Warlord: Ancients & Dark Ages Warfare – Fast Action Wargames Rules for Battles Set in the Period 3000BC - 1100AD
description:
The first set of rules to create a wargame that really looks like a battle in ancient times. Using an innovative system of command and control and the concept of unit attrition to combine the effects of casualties and morale from shooting and melee, a simple set of rules, which at last encourages the strategy and tactics used in ancient times. The stubbornness of the Roman legions and power of heavily armed cavalry are faithfully recreated along with the ferocious but fickle nature of tribal troops. Play well and you will see the enemies battle line collapse rapidly and completely, play poorly you will struggle to control your divisions and they will be defeated in detail.
The command and control system adds unique dimensions to competition and points based games. Points can now be spent on the quality of commanders and the number of divisions fielded (typically 2-3). With better quality generals and more divisions you have more tactical flexibility but you can afford fewer troops.


Figure based as elements – no need to re-base your troops.
Alternate movement – facilitates play.
Command and control system, which replicates the fog of war.
Slick simple D6 based systems – easy to use, swiftly picked up and readily recalled.
Freely accessible – cross- referenced and indexed throughout.
Broken down into core rules and additional explanation.
Integral example army lists; exhaustive range of troop types.
Fast furious action – games of 1000 points per side completed in 90 minutes.
Faithfully gives a historical feel and generates authentic outcomes.
Example battle – Magnesia re-fought, includes scenario and orders of battle.


—description from the publisher

name: Warlord: Advance Guard – Fast Action Wargames Rules for Battles Set in the Period 3000BC - 1100AD
description:
The ideal introduction to the WARLORD SERIES, and to wargames in the period 3500 BC to 1100 AD. An updated and lighter version of the original, highly successful, WARLORD rulebook, which is even faster and more fun to play and introduces some further innovations to enhance the game and improve playability. Action on the miniature battlefield moves swiftly and cleanly to a clear and historically appropriate conclusion. These rules do, beyond question, ‘create wargames that really look like battles in ancient times’, with historically authentic outcomes at each and every stage of the combat.


Using figures based as elements - making play quick and straight forward.
A flexible basing scheme – no need to rebase your troops.
Readily accessible – cross-referenced though-out.
Clearly explained – comprehensive Glossary & Index included.
Simple D6 based mechanisms – swiftly picked-up and easy to use.
Alternative movement – facilitates really fast play.
Integral Command Control system – replicates the chain of command.
Fog of war recreated – the unintended and unexpected happens.
Fast and furious action – complete a game in 90 minutes of play.
Genuinely historical feel – you’ll know the action is just as it really was.
Example battle described – takes you blow by blow through the action.
Ready communication with the Warlord Team – via a google group forum.
Accompanying comprehensive Army Lists – nearly 300 lists for the period.


—description from publisher

name: Cosmic Havoc
description:
Guide your squadron of spaceships to conquer the solar system! But be careful, with planet storms and other beings trying to conquer planets too, you’re in one heck of a battle.

About: Cosmic Havoc can be played by one, two, three or four players that play sequentially.

Fight your way for control of the solar system - controlling the planets on the board. Space ship shaped discs are used by players by flicking them into the holes (planets). The game is played by spinning the Spaceship dial to select a planet to conquer. There are 3 rotating rings on the board which assists in creating Havoc in the Solar System. Players play in the following steps:

A Spaceship Spinner is used to determine which planets players try to flick their spaceship into. Once a planet is landed on with the Spinner, players draw Havoc Cards which tells how many spins the planet's-ring should be spun. Players then flick their spaceship in the direction of the selected planet and aim to land their spaceship. If a players spaceship lands in the planet, that planet is now controlled by the player and the planet is conquered. Up conquering a planet, the conqueror draws a Planet Card and follows the instructions on the card.

And then the next player spins the "Spaceship" dial again and play continues as per the above instructions.

About the board: The board is circular and contains 3 rings where the planets are located and in the middle of the board the sun is located - which holds the Spaceship Dial. Each of the rings turns either clockwise or counter clockwise. The board is divided into twenty quadrants.

Spaceship Disks: Each player starts with 16 Spaceship Discs
Cards: Planet and Havoc Cards
Planet Holes: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn:
Uranus, Neptune. Other holes the Sun and Black holes.

—description from the publisher

name: Lumber: Trader
description:
Lumber: Trader is a light economic game for 2-4 players. It packs a fun and strategic economic experience into a brisk 20-30 minute game with easy to learn rules. Players buy and sell 5 different types of wood. Each type of wood confers a different ability and affects turn order. Each turn consists of players choosing the type of wood they will use to activate an ability and decide turn order, then they sell wood on the stock market, then they buy wood from the market. This game makes for a great gateway into economic games.

The game comes in a wooden case made by hand in California from reclaimed wood. Each set is a unique piece of art showcasing the beautiful wood it was crafted from.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Commodity Speculation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Felix reist um die Welt
description:
The cat Felix is a license figure of the company "Bulls".

Felix and Inky take a trip around the world. That has a specific reason. The friends of Felix, who are scattered all over the world, it is necessary to search and collect. Whether it will succeed?

Each player gets 2 same-colored, different sized figures, which he puts in a row on the starting field. The big figure is Felix, the little one is Inky. The beginning and end of the world tour is BERLIN. Then the dice game can begin. The friends are on the way to find and whoever arrives first in a city can take the friend (the card).

—user summary

name: Les amis du Joli-Bois
description:
This game is close to the game of goose. Each part of the way is an animal as the title "Friends of nice-wood" suggests it. You have to turn a moving arrow to know to which animal you go to. In the advanced rule, some animals stop you or make you go back.

—user summary

name: Le match de l'actualité
description:
This is a trivia game with specific rules. Each card refers to one of four categories which are:

Politics and way of life
Show, sport and adventure
Fashion, news and love stories
Culture and celebrities


In the eighties.

Each card has a text that the playmaker reads, stopping before each word or phrase underlined. All players can then propose one or more answers, in order to win a token.

Five chips of one color win a card of that same color. The first who has the four different color cards wins the game.

—user summary

name: Dr Logic
description:
Dr. Logic is a logical deduction game.

Three or four colored pawns are placed randomly on the bottom lines of the deck. The goal is to discover the combination of displacement that allows to bring a complete stack, if possible while respecting the gradient of colors, on the red arrival box. Other rules alone or in pairs are proposed.

—user summary

name: Rebussimo
description:
A player must compose a rebus, which the others must find. He has for that a minute. After that, opponents also have one minute to find it.

It includes a "Find the intruder" test. The player must compose a long enough rebus with a card that has nothing to do in it. Opponents must find the card that should not be there.

—user summary

name: Cache ou place
description:
Cache ou place (Hide or position) is based on exclusion mechanics and visual recognition.

In the first game mode, the player must hide the "intruder" in the series presented. All symbols have a common character, except one. It's simple, but you have to be careful how you present things.

In the second game mode, the player must place the missing item in the series.

—user summary

name: Tiro
description:
The cards are shuffled and stacked upon another. To hunt the bird on the topmost card, the players roll 3 dice.

A result of 7 and 13 is a near hit and the player has to pay 1 token.

A result of 10, 11 and 12 is a hit and the player gets 1 token from each player.

All other results are misses and the player has to pay 2 tokens into the cash box.

The player with the highest hit result takes the card and gets the prize printed on the bottom of the card, which may be a win, a blank or even a loss.

—user summary

name: Dice and Troll
description:
After been in so many party at some of my friend house, I realized we were become addicted to our phone and social media, and our relationship became distant.

I love innovation so much, then I know we cannot cut this in our life, but we must adapted, that why I decided put together, social media, dice game, and card together.

By putting all this together, all this funny thing we all know already and have fun with it, I am capable to put my friend back together in a party, even if they have a phone on hands

All the social media card worth 1 point up to 9, likes on IG and FB, and views on Snapchat.

You make the count when your turn came back after posting what the card tell you, and before you roll the dice, you will have to delete the troll post.

TRUTH worth 1 point

DARE worth 2 point

ACT LIKE worth 2 point

Challenge worth 2 point

BRAIN worth 1 point

You will able to stole point, share, and lost, with certain card!

The first player at 50 point, win the game!

—description from the designer

name: Psychologist
description:
A fun, fast-paced, party game in which players use their imagination to decide, which amongst their surreal illustrated cards is the best to answer the psychologist's -usually- silly question!

Each round, the game's buzzer asks a specific question. The players need to choose one of their cards, that they think better asks that question. Then, the psychologist (who changes every round) judges the player's answers, awarding victory points to the ones closest to his ideal answer of the question. The player with the most points after 12 rounds of play, wins the game.

—description from the designer

name: Waddingtons Pony Express
description:
The wild west mail delivering strategy game by Waddingtons.

"...when the mail's just gotta get through..."
—description from the game box

"Object:
The object of the game is to be the first person to deliver all his mail and return safely to his home town.

Equipment:
The equipment consists of a playing board, four dispatch boards, four player pieces, three playing dice and one Indian die, forty-two mail cards, twenty-seven Desparado (red) cards and twenty-seven Bonanza (blue} cards"

—description from the instructions

name: Taco Perfecto
description:
Make the perfect taco! Add yummy toppings, dodge the ingredients you don't like, and spice your taco just right.

Players are dealt three "gusto" cards. Choose two of them. These are your favorite ingredients, kept secret from the other players.

Each player also gets a hand of three "ingredient" cards, and three "spice" cards. Players take turns playing cards into piles that represent different tacos, drawing from one of two decks to replace the type of card they just played.

Ingredients are played face up, covering previously played ingredients, and spice cards are played face down, but in a column so you can see how many (but not the value of) cards have been played. There are also cards like "Picky Eater" and "Mystery Pepper" that have special effects on your taco's taste.

When you think a taco has the right ingredients and spices, instead of playing a card on your turn, claim one of the tacos, removing it from play. Once all players have claimed a taco, the player with the tastiest taco (most points) wins!


+5 if your spice sore is between 15 and 20
+3 for each topping that matches your gusto cards
+2 for each Sour Cream card
+1 for each Lime Juice
-1 for each non-matching topping


—description from the publisher

name: Karo Kick
description:
Each player has 11 meeples. Movement is determined by a special die, which enables the following moves:

1 forward
2 forward
3 forward
1 to the right
1 to the left
1 backward


Each time a player gets into the opposite goal, it counts as a point. The player with the most points after a playing time of 30 minutes wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Emil und die Detektive
description:
The goal of the game is to identify the thief. The players take turns drawing a card. The 24 cards give clues, put suspects on the board or send the pawns of the players to different areas of the game board, where they may question a witness (4) or exonerate a suspect (6).
Each exonerated suspect counts 1 point. The player who identifies the thief gets 5 points.

The first player to get 10 points (if need be after several games) wins the game.

—user summary

name: Quartermaster: Apply Within
description:
Like all good spy legends, this one starts with a bang… originating from the Quartermaster’s lab whilst he was tinkering with experimental shoe polish. He leaves behind nothing but a decimated lab, a pair of ash-covered, blastresistant shoes, and a job opening... for Quartermaster.

Now, a team of auditors are cracking down over concerns of health and safety within the facility and are systematically restricting access to each lab. You and the other Quarternovices must scramble to use the blueprints that survived the blast to create the best spy gadget, and win the promotion to Quartermaster!
Applicants beware - with stakes this high, no-one is above sabotage.

Quartermaster: Apply Within is a 10 - 20 minute compact, inventive and ruthless game built around worker-placement and pattern-making. Each turn sees 1-4 players (or Quaternovices) scramble to collect the parts needed to build incredible spy gadgets, while protecting their prototypes against sabotage from devious co-workers.

With a setup influenced by both player choice and chance, and the option to replace up to three players with an AI, Quartermaster: Apply Within is flexible, dynamic, and addictively replayable.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Modular Board, Pattern Building, Take That, Worker Placement

name: Monster
description:
Monster is a gambling game in which the best
hand must defeat the Monster, a hand made
from everyone’s discards.

Equipment:
A Pairs deck. A button for indicating the
dealer, and chips for keeping score.

To Begin:
Start by paying an ante into the pot. If you have 4 or 5 players, the ante is 2 chips. With 6 to 8 players, the ante is 1 chip.
Shuffle the deck and deal a hand of six cards to each player. The player on the dealer’s left will act first. (Move the dealer button only after a full game, i.e., after the pot clears.)
Each player acts once, in turn. On your turn, you may discard zero to three cards, or fold. You are not allowed to keep a hand that includes a pair; if this is your only choice, you must fold. You may want to fold some other hands as well,
depending on circumstances
Your discards go facedown into a pile in the middle, which becomes the Monster’s hand. Folded cards do not go to the Monster; they go completely out of play. Note: This is not draw poker. Your discarded cards are not replaced!

The Showdown:
After each player on the next page) becomes the “Champion,” and
must compare hands with the Monster. When the Champion faces the Monster,he must defeat it in order to take the pot. The
Monster wins ties.

If the Champion loses (or ties), he pays 5 chips to the pot and is knocked out of the game.

Definition of High Hand:
Any player hand that contains a pair is a losing hand, and
can’t be kept for the showdown. All hands in the showdown will be compared by highest card, then second highest card, and so on. The best player hand is 10-9-8-7-6-5. A card is better than nothing, so a hand of 10-8-7-4 is better than 10-8-7. This is similar to comparing poker hands for high card, except that there is no limit on the number of cards that can play. The Monster uses the same rules, but it ignores duplicate cards. Treat the Monster as if it had only one card of each rank.

Winning:
To win the pot, you must become the Champion and defeat the monster. If no one wins, play another round with only the
surviving players. Players who folded, or who lost a fight with the Monster, are out. All cards are reshuffled in the next round
(the Monster does not keep its cards).

Oddities: If one player is left, he automatically wins. If zero players are left, either because they all had to fold, or because the last player couldn’t defeat his own discards, then play again with the same players who started the round.

Ties:
If two Champions win with exactly the same hand, they split the pot. If two Champions have the same hand but lose to the Monster, they must each drop out and pay the 5 chip penalty, unless they are the only two players remaining, in which case they pay 5 chips but play another round.

Strategy: In the first few rounds, you may want to “duck,” playing low hands and trying not to become the Champion. As players leave the game, it becomes easier to defeat the Monster, because it is getting fewer cards.

name: The "Promised Land" Game
description: Players use a spinner to race from the Starting Line to the Finish Line, navigating a board filled with obstacles -- such as "Philistines Massing for Attack! Move Back 4 Spaces" and "Lay Siege to Gat, Miss 1 Turn" -- and rewards -- such as "Capture Ashkelon, Advance 5 Spaces" and "Attack Canaanite War Camp, Advance 2 Spaces."

name: Cnossos
description:
King Minos has locked you in his labyrinth to serve as food to the Minotaur. You must collect cristal fragments to kill the creature and unlock the maze’s exit.
You get fragments by flipping the maze’s tiles or by stealing them from the other players during fights.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board

name: Kosom Kusam
description:
From the Mayan dialect Kosom Kusam that means swallow, this game is about the conquest that the Spaniards made to Mexico, and about the first place they ARRIVED in our country, that is, the island of COZUMEL, in the Mexican state of QUINTANA ROO , which means place of swallows, and in the game, the two players will represent, one to the Spaniards, and the other to the Mayans, and they will have to eliminate the opponent by shifting their chips horizontally or vertically, until they manage to enclose those of the opposing player , or, when one of the players has managed to reach one of the represented corners, like the island, or on the contrary, represented as the sea of the Atlantic, at that moment will be taken for conquest.

—description from the publisher

name: Tex: vapori indiani promo card
description:
A promo card for the Game.

It is a generic action, which reads: "all other players discard 2 action cards"

—user summary
categories: American West, Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Action Queue, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Team-Based Game

name: Arena: A Tavern Game Played with Dice and Cards
description:
Looking for an alternative to three-dragon ante? Arena is an easy to learn dice and cards game where players select terrible monsters and force them to face off against one another for gold and glory!
—description from the publisher

Arena is published as a print-and-play game requiring each player to have three standard dice. The document includes thirty-six card images.

Arena fancifully is presented as a game that adventurers might play in the taverns of Forgotten Realms.

Players receive four coins (betting tokens), three dice, and are dealt four cards. Each card denotes a "monster" that can be played into the Arena.

Play proceeds in rounds. In each round, each player selects a card from their hand and plays it face-down on the table; all cards are revealed simultaneously.

Each "monster" has a specified number of dice (one to three) and players roll the appropriate number of dice to resolve the round - the high result wins, and ties are resolved by re-rolling.

The winning player selects one other player as the round loser. The loser moves a coin (betting token) into the stakes and discards the losing card. All other players return their played card to their hand.

Play proceeds until one player runs out of cards (and coins). At this point the game winner is determined by the player holding the highest number of cards, and ties are resolved by summing the dice value of the held cards; if a tie still exists the players roll dice to determine a winner. The winner claims the stakes.

—user summary
categories: Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Print & Play
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Hand Management

name: Adventure Island: Santa Claus
description:
A promo character for Adventure Island given out to Pegasus Supporters for Christmas 2018.

His stats are 3, 2, 3 but he lets everyone in his location roll 1 extra die for an action.

name: Serengeti
description:
Serengeti is a fast-paced, cooperative board game packed with unique mechanics and beautifully designed artwork. Players traverse treacherous terrain and navigate expansive grasslands in order to rescue endangered safari animals from the snare of trespassing poachers. Each player will take on the role of a reservation official. While on duty, these officials will take actions to save animals and arrest poachers. Players will have to evade stampedes, harsh weather, and poacher traps, but don't worry you will be given equipment to assist you in your efforts.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Variable Player Powers

name: Scions of Avermhir
description: Scions of Avermhir (aver meer) is a new type of tactical strategy game that rewards thought out plans and maneuvers, without taking several hours to play! With a diverse set of goals to achieve and enhancements to acquire, you'll find that every game feels new and fun! The game welcomes new players and old hands alike, with each game ending down to the wire, not giving either player a chance to snowball out of control.

name: Monterey-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF MONTEREY, CALIFORNIA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Monterey we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...one incredible bay - a little something for everyone! Looking for a fun way to experience California’s rugged coast?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Monterey properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO MONTEREY! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many short rib grilled cheeses from The Cannery Row Brewing Company! THIS IS MONTEREY.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Tallahassee-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF TALLAHASEE, FLORIDA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Tallahassee we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, canopy roads, deep-rooted culture, and of course…a whole lotta college spirit - a little something for every Tallahasseean! Looking for a fun way to experience Florida's Capital City?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Tallahassee properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and the IRS and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

Choose your token and advance to GO Tallahassee!You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many jumbo corndogs at Dog Et Al! THIS IS TALLAHASSEE.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Pocket Quiz: Schlager
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information.

The title translates to "schlager music" and the questions are about that topic.

—user summary

name: Pocket Quiz: Querdenken (2019 edition)
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information. Most of the cards also show small illustrations.

The title translates to "lateral thinking" and the questions are about that topic.

—user summary

name: Pocket Quiz: Allgemeinwissen (2019 edition)
description:
This is a small, pocket-sized trivia game. It contains 50 cards with 3 questions each, most of them with multiple choice options. The backside of each card contains the answers and offers additional information.

The title translates to "General Knowledge".

—user summary

name: Die Tour de Tarif
description:
Bike races for 2 - 6 players, with dice throws and card collecting.

Each player has three riders at the start. To start, you need to roll a six. Before the dice roll, the player must indicate one of his three riders for whom the roll is used.

The route is divided into three sections and there are different colored event fields.

Opposing riders can be thrown out. But not in all fields.
There are the following fields:
3 start fields
a target field
white squares (you can hit opposing riders)

Black, red, yellow squares: here the player will be asked questions of the corresponding color, depending on the color field. The question is the player sitting behind the player. If the question is answered correctly, the player gets the card, he has not given a correct answer, then the questioner may keep the card.

Blue fields: these fields serve the catering of the drivers, here can not be beaten. The VIP fields, before leaving you can call according to "VIP-VIP" and then die, the number is then doubled. However, if you only roll a 1, you have to go back to the last stage start.

Pink fields: are event fields, the texts are on the plan.
At the end of the racetrack, at the third stage you can not leave the time loop until you have collected 15 question cards, otherwise you have to go in a circle until you have done that, then you can leave the loop and drive to the finish. Who is the best cyclist?

—user summary

name: Patanto
description:
The board shows two circles on which one can carry out his activities. There are lots of action fields. The task of the players is to put together ideas for inventions and to apply for a patent in Germany or in Europe.
With patent sale or with licensing you make the big money. And with a clever game play, you can win as the richest player.
from inventor to millionaire.

—user summary

name: Die DM rollt
description:
Die DM rollt (1st game)
The four caps of each player start on the spaces marked with a "S". Movement is determined by two dice. The player choses the result of one die to move a cap.
