If a cap gets on a space of another color with a number, the player gets the corresponding amount of game money from the player of this color. The other player may avoid this with a succesfull counter move. He rolls a die. If he manages to reach the cap of his opponent, the opponent has to pay and his cap is returned to a starting position.
If a player traps an opponent cap on a space without a number, he takes the trapped cap with him when he moves again. If this pair of caps get on a numberef space of the color of the trapped cap, the trapped player gets no counter move.
The game ends, when one player is broke. The player with the most money wins the game.

Money Maker (2nd game)
In this game movement is not decided by dice, but by a deck of Cards. Each player sets his 4 caps on numbered spaces of another color. Then each player draws three cards of his color. If there are caps on the spaces indicated by the cards the player has to pay his opponents the indicated amount of money. The owners of caps on spaces of his color not indicated by the cards have to pay hin instead. The game ends afer the whole talons have been played an agreed upon number of times. The player with the most money wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Have A Heart
description:
Object of the game:
To dislodge opponents clip on heart with a pliable plastic sword.

Before Starting Play:
Each player takes one sword and one Heart that he clips on his person, below his shoulders or above his knees.
The Heart may not be placed on the arms. Any player then takes the arrows and throws them in the air or places them in a circle radius of about six feet , disregarding where the colors may fall. The spinner is then placed in the center of the circle.

How to play:
Each player stands on the outside pattern of the arrows . The first player then spins the dial . The dial stops on a blue arrow , the players quickly place any foot on any convenient blue arrow , with toes pointing in the direction of the arrow. When the spinner shows geeen players place the other foot on any green arrow . As the game continues , players may place either foot on the arrow that is most convenient to them . When the spinner stops on a Heart, the player calls out “HAVE A HEART” and each player tries to get each other’s heart with his sword. The hearts may be removed by either knocking them off or by placing the curved part of the sword thru the hole in the heart and pulling it off. If a player loses balance and falls or his heart is removed , he is eliminated from the game. The last player remaining is the winner.

—user summary

name: Zombie Golf
description:
Its the Apocalypse, zombies roam the earth and the golf courses. You and 4 friends are out to answer the age old question; who is the best golfer of the apocalypse.
So grab a golf bag, get down to Demon Sands Country Club and see who can win 9 holes of golf; while not dying by zombies or rage quitting because of frustration.

Zombie Golf can be played as a 3 hole party game or 9 holes of serious screw your neighbor fun.

—description from the publisher
categories: Abstract Strategy, Fighting, Party Game, Sports, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Variable Player Powers

name: Profi: Das heitere Berufespiel
description:
This game was awarded a gold medal in 1974 at the Geneva International Inventors Fair.

It is recommended for children from the age of 12 to playfully learn how important it is to have a good education and vocational training to succeed in life.

The first part of the game is therefore about school and work.
In the second part, players try to buy as many businesses and stocks as possible, hiring employees and working for profit.

In this game, you will learn, among other things, about loans and repayments, corporations, business companies, pre-emption rights, payment difficulties and bankruptcy.

All things that are unfortunately not explained in school lessons.

—user summary

name: Art-ish
description:
You are a talented painter. At least that’s what your mom says. Your art teachers, however, say you’re good… ish. But somehow, you still manage to get portrait commissions (mostly friends and family). They don’t pay very well (just in Exposure), but it’s still nice to be appreciated. So get out there and paint!

In Art-ish you’ll be mixing colors to paint splatters on your canvas with the goal of fulfilling commissions. Be the first player to earn 8 Exposure points to win.

On their turn, players create Splatters using different combinations of Paint Tubes from their hand with the goal of reproducing the model on one of the Commission Cards.

When a player has fulfilled a Commission card by matching its Splatters in the proper location, they gain that number of Exposure and a special ability to use during their subsequent turns. Abilities and points vary depending on the difficulty of the Commission.

-description from publisher

name: Hyde Society
description: Hyde Society is a fantastical game set in the Victorian era, with a traitor mechanism reminiscent of the one in Betrayal at House on the Hill.

name: Three Magic
description: Your goal in Three Magic, a.k.a. スリーマジック, is to collect three cards of mana (the power of the nature) in order to create a spell; create three spells to complete your magic. Do this first, and you win.

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: Protectors Shadow Sun Syndicate Monster – Zor-Raiden
description:
Biomorphic and cybernetic nanotechnology empowers each of the zors, the mightiest class of the Shadow Sun Syndicate's living weapon-warriors. The soldier forming the basis for Zor-Raiden was specifically recruited as one of the last surviving members of a nearly forgotten ninja clan hidden away in the northeastern mountains. Considered brash and headstrong by ranking members of the Syndicate, Raiden is nonetheless extremely skilled in combat and has demonstrated uncanny unspoken coordination with other shinobi units.

—description from the game box

name: Monsterpocalypse Miniatures Game: Protectors Terrasaurs Monster – Armodax
description:
Though the Terrasaurs have shown a remarkable willingness to fight alongside Earth's other defenders, some are trickier to work with than others. Armodax is a hulking monster covered in armored plates and boasting a weighty clubbed tail that serves better than any wrecking ball at toppling buildings. He has demonstrated unrestrained delight in annihilating skyscrapers, factories, and power plants while clashing with Earth's foes. Yet there is no question he is worth preserving, given his unstoppable ferocity. His allies have learned to ensure the complete evacuation of any zone he has entered.

—description from the game box

name: Sukuwareta Girl
description:
In 救ワレタガール ("Saved Girl"), you take on the role of a ghost trying to build up enough good deeds to get your wish granted. To build up good deeds you'll help troubled girls by possessing them to solve their problems.

Each girl has three attributes (Heart, Skill, Strength) and a point value. At the start of the game nine girls are played to the center of the table, and on each turn you can gather tokens or save a girl. To save a girl the power of the girl you currently posses has to equal or exceed the girl to be saved in all three attributes, but if it's too low you can make up the difference with tokens. You can also manipulate the girls currently available to be saved if none of them are a good match or you want to block your opponents.

After you've saved a girl, you always get to keep the points, but you can only possess one girl at a time for saving other girls, so you have to choose carefully. Also each player has one special ghost power they can use once per game, distributed secretly at the start.

—user summary

name: Hot Springs-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF HOT SPRINGS, AR? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Hot Springs we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...the birthplace of spring training baseball - a little something for everyone! Looking for a fun way to experience the Nation’s Health Resort?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Hot Springs properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO HOT SPRINGS! You may soon be the Mayor…or out of the game for eating too many tamales from McClard’s Bar-B-Q! THIS IS HOT SPRINGS.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

description:

It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...the world’s deepest hot spring - a little something for every Pagosa Springian! So choose your token and advance to GO PAGOSA SPRINGS! You may soon be the Mayor…or out of the game for eating too much steak from the Alley House Grille! THIS IS PAGOSA SPRINGS.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course…the fourth-longest run way in the country - a little something for everybody! Looking for a fun way to experience Atwater?

Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

Choose your token and advance to GO ATWATER! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many King Burritos from Isabella’s Bar & Grill! THIS IS ATWATER.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher

publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Moorefield-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF MOOREFIELD, WEST VIRGINIA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Moorefield we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course…a river of epic proportions - a little something for everyone! Looking for a fun way to experience the Poultry Capital of West Virginia?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Moorefield properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

Choose your token and advance to GO MOOREFIELD! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many crab cakes from O’Neills! THIS IS MOOREFIELD.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Socki
description:
A rummy style card game, fun for the whole family!

Socki is an open faced gin rummy game great for the whole family. Easy to learn but takes a lifetime to master. Players try to win a hand by playing all their cards. Once cards are played on the table all players can use them to play more piles of like cards or runs (number sequences) to also try to get rid of all their cards. The fun comes when the piles and runs are rearranged in a way to allow a player to play a card. But be careful if you cannot play a card after all that rearranging you must put it all back! Let the laughter and fun begin.

The player with the lowest score wins.

name: Launder
description:
Launder is a solo money laundering game that requires the player to manage both the money they've laundered and the attention of the FBI, which is represented by Heat.

The player begins the game with a Boss Asset card (representing their illicit employer) and a small amount of Dirty Money, which they use to purchase Building or Person Asset cards. Each Turn, a player advances the current Month, draws an Event card, and resolves the FBI track, which generally tends to hinder the player by adding additional Heat to their most high-profile Assets.

In the Activation Phase, the player can activate their Assets. Most Assets allow the player to roll a variable number of Income Dice, though others allow the player to Refresh Activated Assets, move Heat between different Assets, or take more unique actions. Depending upon the result of the Income Dice, the Asset might generate Clean or Dirty Money, gain Heat, or some combination of the above. If an Asset gains 5+ Heat, it is discarded from play and advances the FBI Track by one space. The exception to this is the Boss Asset, which is not discarded from play (but still advances the FBI Track).

The player can then use their money (Clean or Dirty) to purchase additional Assets, weighing carefully just how much money should be invested and how much should be saved away.

If the player has accumulated enough Clean Money at the end of a Turn, they meet their quota and win the game. If they have not met their quota at the end of 12 Turns, however, their boss rewards them for their failure with a pair of cement shoes and a long walk off a short pier.

name: JATAK!
description:
JATAK! - commonly translated as YESSIR! - is a highly competitive dice game for two or more players. Originally invented in the pubs, bars, and taverns of Copenhagen where dice roll free, it was designed as a contemporary alternative to the timeless - yet sometimes also timeworn - classics such as Liar's Dice, Mia, and Four Twenty-One. Whereas many traditional dice games only play well with multiple players, JATAK! is equally strong with two, three, or four players.

Each player begins the game with a dice mat, a dice cup with two dice, and a separate luck die. A common pool of three dice is kept on the table between the players. Players take turns spending points on their luck die to manipulate the private dice in their cup and the public dice in the pool. However, they can also choose to say JATAK! and pass on the turn. If all players say JATAK! one after the other, the round ends and the cups are removed. The player who has the strongest combination of dice between their cup and the pool wins the round. The first time a player wins a round they flip over their dice mat. The second time they remove it, and the third time they win the game.

The beating heart of JATAK! is the luck die which begins at 6, but quickly falls dangerously low as players spend points to manipulate the dice to their own advantage. Points on the luck die can only be regained if a player loses a round (+1 point) or pushes their luck by rerolling their cup and withdrawing from the round without looking at the result (+1 point). The latter is obviously a desperate move, but one that can pay great dividends if used with skill and care.

Print-and-play dice mat designs and a complete description of the rules in both Danish and English can be found in the files section on this page.

—description from the designer

name: Lanterna
description:
The Galley Warfare Supplement to The Perfect Captain's Spanish Fury system - Sail!
Spanish Fury, Sail! is a game of naval warfare of the late Sixteenth century, covering the Armada as well as Lepanto, enabling players to fight on the sea from Cyprus to the Baltic. With ‘Lanterna’ you can play galley actions as well. New ship cards and counters included.

name: È qui la festa
description:
A compendium with the most well-known movement games, for animating birthday parties and large groups of children.
In the box there are acting and drawing games, in which you have to guess an action, an object or an animal, and traditional games like Strega comanda colore and Il lupo mangia frutta (2 Tag games), and Regina reginella.

—description from the publisher

name: Quizminister
description:
Danish quiz game about politics, for two to four players or teams. Each player/team starts with one tactics token of each kind: committee consultation, spin doctor, and alliance.
The board has six question categories, and if you answer correctly, you have to move to a category that no player/team is already on. Two correct answers in a row lets you visit any category. Three correct answers in a row gives you a random tactics token. The tokens allow for politicking and helping/hindering other players/teams.
The goal of the game is to get to the top of the "career ladder" by answering enough questions correctly.

—user summary

name: Kalmar
description:
This is the game about your city, Kalmar. You buy, sell and trade properties and building plots to win. You will feel at home on the game board, going from Norrliden to Varvsholmen. Cards with pictures and instructions take you from familiar and unfamiliar situations and locations in the historical, contemporary and future Kalmar.

Players assume the role of landlords, purchasing and trading streets, squares and properties. Players landing on the streets and squares of other players must pay rent depending on if the plot is empty or if properties have been built on the plot. The unique plots for the squares Larmtorget, Stortorget, Lilla Torget and Skvallertorget, and for the local newspapers Östran and Barometern, are unbuildable, meaning that the rent is fixed; buying more of the same set garners you more money when players land on those plots.

Players play the game by rolling two dice, adding the sum together and moving on the game board equal to the sum of the dice. Players may only buy properties that are unowned, and it takes owning all streets of an individual color set to be able to build properties on the streets. For example, to be able to build properties on Norrliden, Funkabo must also be owned by you, as it belongs to and completes the orange set. While moving along the board, players may also land on tile which force you to draw cards, whose effects may be both beneficial and disadvantageous.

The goal of this game is, by the roll of the dice and mercantile shrewdness, to be the last player left with money, having forced your competitors into bankruptcy.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Trading

name: Vedo doppio
description:
Vedo doppio is a pattern recognition game.

There are 14 cards with 8 objects and 28 cards with 1 object.
The basic rule of Vedo doppio is that, drawing 2 cards with 8 objects, there are exactly 2 objects in common. Whoever spots the 2 objects in common on both cards picks up the correspondent card.

There are 5 different ways to play. The first 3 games are related to the basic rule described above, the other 2 games are different and, for example, require memory.

—description from the designer

name: Bushido: Master Koju
description:
If Master Koju is in danger all of creation will bend to ensure her safety, and even the most depraved Kami representing the worst aspects of creation will not harm her. This often manifests as wild animals appearing alongside her to attack those who threaten her and her enemies seem to slow down in her presence allowing her allies the opportunity to take out threats before they have a chance to harm her.

Blister contains three models, one 40mm base and two full colour profile cards.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: Limbo: The Passing
description:
You see an intense white light approaching fast at the other end of a tunnel. As you get closer, the train creaks and slowly comes to halt. It’s an old wagon and you are the only passenger on board. You gaze outside the dirty windows. Limbo Central Station, reads the sign...

Limbo: The Passing is the new story driven asymmetrical two player card game from Caper creator Unai Rubio.


Asymmetric 2-player gameplay - refined and tense, inspired by Android: Netrunner. Grab one of the 18 premade decks and get started. Easy to learn, hard to master.



Completely unique lore - discover the city of Limbo, an afterlife cosmo-capitalist city filled with politics, mystery and dark humor. More than 120 unique cards oozing personality.



Repeatable legacy narrative campaign - branching decisions, secret information and an engrossing story in line with the best noir narratives.



Balanced to perfection - a competitive metagame balanced by pro and casual players through two years of constant iteration.



Draft mode - feel like improvising on the go? Stay on your toes with our innovative endless drafting mechanic. The thrill of opening booster pack, with no limits!



Alive! (pun intended) - discover the Manifest, an online updated balance mechanism that makes sure the metagame remains competitive and is up to date with community feedback.



Let’s make Limbo great together - create and upload your own campaigns with the campaign creating toolkit. The only boundary is your imagination!


—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Vault of Dragons: Blessing of the Gods – Cleric Expansion Set
description: Vault of Dragons: Blessing of the Gods – Cleric Expansion Set adds clerics, blessing tokens, and five new dungeon/location titles to the game. Each player receives a male and female cleric, as well as a d8 in their faction color.

name: Enter the Dungeons of Brochuria
description:
A single player dungeon exploring adventure contained in a single pamphlet. All you need is a pen.

—description from the introduction

Enter the Dungeons of Brochuria was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest. The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The solitaire player uses tokens and the board to move their "character" through a dungeon one square at a time, with the count determined by die roll. Squares have various icons representing hazards or encounters which must be handled by the character; or treasure which can be gathered.

The player loses if their character runs out of health and wins if they defeat the final boss.

—user summary

name: Escape from Castle Iggur
description:
A Single Player Survival Game

—description from the introduction

Escape from Castle Iggur was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest. The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The solitaire player moves up through a seven-level dungeon, from the lowest level to the top level, facing a challenge or gaining a reward on each level. Each challenge presents a numeric rating that must be beaten by a modified die roll. Each reward provides a bonus to subsequent die rolls. Points are gained for each challenge defeated.

The player loses when they fail to beat a challenge, or wins when they escape the dungeon. Game points may be compared to other game plays to determine relative success.

—user summary
mechanics: Area Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Fading Light
description:
Fly between stars; Peer into the history of worlds; Collect artifacts; Influence cultural evolution; Mine singularities; Run out of gas; Get caught within an event horizon

Fading Light:

Enter the Dungeons of Brochuria was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest. The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The game primarily is designed for a single player (additional players essentially run a parallel game). Play involves rolling Fudge Dice and consulting action tables to determine turn resolution. The player controls an in game currency ("cultural artifacts") and resource ("gigasecond"). Play proceeds until the player runs out of either (a loss) or holds a specified amount of either (a win).

—description from the introduction

name: Take Root
description:
Congratulations! You all have achieved the dream, you have a farm. The world is nothing but possibility, at least for this next year.

The game takes place over 4 seasons: spring, summer, fall, and winter, with each season having 9 days.

—description from the introduction

Take Root was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest. The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The game is played over four turns with each turn containing nine phases. Players may choose and activity for each phase with an outcome determined by die roll. During play, players accumulate an in-game currency (coins) and resources (seeds and harvested vegetables). Points accumulate through play. At the end of the game, each player puts together a "festival display" of harvested vegetables and the winning display scores points. A few other end-of-game categories also score points. The player with the most accumulated points is the winner.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Turn Order: Time Track

name: Help! I'm a Tetra Block!
description:
Wiggling in place, you tried to roll off the bed as usual, but nothing happened.

There is no bed.

There is no "you".

The vast greyness up ahead seems like the only possible way of escape.

Your body twitches as the high-pitch Russian folk music fills your two-dimensional senses, driving you mad.

What will you do?

—description from the introduction

Help! I'm a Tetra Block! was developed as an entry into the Pamphlet Dungeon Jam contest. The game is presented as a six-pane, tri-fold, print-and-play brochure.

The game is a simple adaptation of Tetris (1984) into a paper-and-pencil, tabletop game. Players alternate rolling a die to determine their piece configuration, and then placing that piece on the board. Points are scored when blocks are played so they touch the top row of the playing grid. If a line is sealed off with a gap, it is crossed off from play. Play continues until no more legal moves are possible, at which point the player with the most points wins.

—user summary

name: Shingon Karuta
description:
真言カルタ (Shingon Karuta) is a Japanese card game of Karuta, using Buddhist mantras (Shingon) and artwork.

In a karuta game, players try to snatch the matching card from the other player's tableau, or protect their own card by covering it first. Typically, a separate player acts as a Reader by reading out loud from a separate deck. Players then deduce from what is read which card on display is the target, and move swiftly.

In this game of Shingon Karuta, the designer aimed to improve the education of Buddhist iconography. There is a deck of Bodhisattva cards and a deck of Shingon cards. A Bodhiattva is a person on the path to Buddhahood, and such people are widely depicted in temple artwork, in sculpture and painting. Shingon Buddhism is one of the main schools in Japan, and the Shingon deck has sections of mantras that relate to specific Bodhisattva images.

As the Shingon card is read out, each player tries to identify the matching Bodhisattva card and snatch it or keep it.

The game was originally published in 2017, but revised in 2019 to unify the artwork to one style. The designer realised that players could simply learn the deck by the different style of artworks, and not by learning the actual Bodhisattvas. By making all the art unified, the game becomes much harder.

In 2018, the designer published an explansion set of 10 more Bodhisattva cards and 10 matching Shingon cards. Players could just play with this expansion set alone. This deck was integrated into the 2019 edition too.

—user summary

name: FakeDigger
description:
It is a gem excavation battle to acquire gems buried in the deck using various strategies.
Each player decides the "target" gem that will be scored high.
"Target" is a high score, but I do not know where it is in the deck.

We will use the hints drawn on the deck to find targets and valuable gems.
Some gems are worthwhile, not worthless, and even have negative scores.

While making full use of the strategy, proceed with the round while disturbing the enemy player so as not to be disturbed by the enemy player.
There is a combination of valuable things, no things, and negative things, each of which is a bonus, so the battle between mentality and strategy will continue until the end ...
---
多彩な戦略を駆使して山札に埋もれた宝石を獲得していく宝石発掘バトルです。
各プレイヤーはそれぞれ高得点となる「ターゲット」の宝石を決めます。
「ターゲット」は高得点ですが、山札のどこにあるかはわかりません。

山札に描かれたヒントを頼りにターゲットや価値のある宝石を見つけていきます。
宝石の中には価値のあるもの、価値のないもの、さらにマイナス得点となってしまうものがあります。

戦略を駆使しながら、敵プレイヤーに邪魔されないよう、また敵プレイヤーを邪魔しながらラウンドを進めていきます。
価値のあるもの、ないもの、マイナスのものもそれぞれボーナスとなる組み合わせがあるため、最後まで気を抜けない心理と戦略の戦いが続きます…
mechanics: Action Points, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Heavy Traffic
description:
Heavy Traffic is a two-player, abstract strategy board game that represents choas in a logistic centre on a 8x8 board.

The aim of the game is to use the truck for transporting your load to a delivery point.

There are 3 starting conditions with all different pickup and delivery points.

A truck with load can move 1 step, a truck without load can move 2 steps.
Also use the trucks wisely to block the other players trucks.

The winner of the game is the player who transport the load as first to the destination.

—user summary

name: Blutube
description:
In Blutube - chi porta l'acqua in casa ("Who bring water in houses") players must compete in order to construct the most efficient city.
This game is a promo collaboration between the water provider GEAL, the City of Lucca, Lucca Crea srl and Ludoteca Lucchese.
The game was made with the support of Red Glove developers.

The game is played on a grid surrounded by bullding tiles. At his turn, each player may place tiles on the grid in order to build a pipe network and bring water to buildings. The buildings may be upgraded from a not sustenaible to a susteinable version: the player that upgrades a building scores points if the pipe network reaches that building.

name: Exogenesis
description:
Freezing cryogel cables hiss as they retract into the sides of your cryopod. As you wake with a chemical-induced headache, the lid of your pod pops open letting warm and oddly humid air rushing into your nose. You smell... foliage?

A holoscreen blinkers on above your face, shining purple data scrolling down, making you flinch as the light pierces your still blurred vision. Blinking away gel, you read the info...

342 years!!? You punch the screen with your fingers requesting a recalc but the data remains the same. You've been locked in cryo for 342years! And what are these bizarre objects apparently arranged in orbit around this alien planet?

Genesis (noun: the origin or beginning of something) and
Exo (prefix: outside, alien)

Exogenesis is a survival exploration game of the 4X style. The Exosurvey ship Cygnus X2 on route to Proxima Centauri is subverted by an alien digital virus that causes the ship to crash on an alien world. As surviving officers onboard, the players must work together to survive, then to explore and lastly to decide whether to repair the ship and leave or uncover the mystery that brought them to this world. Exogenesis is a tough game with powerful protagonists. Failure to prioritise and work diplomatically with each other will lead to failure, and death for the crew. You have been warned.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Cooperative Game, Modular Board, Worker Placement

name: Frank Buck's Bring 'Em Back Alive Game
description:
Frank Buck was a well-known big game trapper who wrote a 1930 book, Bring 'Em Back Alive. In this game there are twelve books of three cards. Each book represents an animal that Fran Buck has brought back alive from the jungles or a scene illustrating adventures on his expeditions. The books are made by fitting the three cards together in the proper way to form a complete picture. The center card of each book has the name of the book at the top and a red number. The other two cards of each book have some descriptive or leading phrase that gives a clue to its proper book without revealing the name.

Players draw a card to determine the dealer. The higher number deals. Players are dealt three cards face up. The remaining cards are placed face down in the center. The dealer plays first. He looks over all the cards to determine whether or not a book may be made up from the cards showing. If the dealed can make up a book, he selects the proper cards and places them in front of him. His turn is complete and play passes to the player on his left. If the dealer can not make up a book, he draws one card from the top of the center pile and tries to make up a book. If successful, he places the book in front of him. If unsuccessful in making up a book, the card drawn is discarded face up. In either case his turn ends and play passes to the left. The player to the left then has the same option as the dealer plus he may use the card which has been discarded. The following general rules apply. A player may get only one book in a turn. After the three original cards a player does not replace any cards which may be drawn from his hand. If a player discards the third card of any book (not realizing that it made a book), any other player may call the name of the animal and pick up the book with out interfering with his turn. When the cards in the pack have all been drawn the discard pile is turned over and used again.

—user summary

name: Protostar
description:
Its rough out on the rim. It’s all you can do to put together enough scratch to keep your boat in the air and a gun out of your face. You take what jobs you can get and don’t ask too many questions about the who or the what. Some days I feel like an inter system taxicab. The better you do, the more influence you get, and that’s worth more than nearly any of the cargo you might be hauling. Build enough of it and enough cash, and you might be able to convince the Central Authority to grant you access to the warp gate to the inner systems. Where life just might be a little bit easier. Maybe.

Protostar s a competitive SciFi Bounty Hunting Game for 1-5 players. Each turn, players pick a different rim system to jump to with their NavCom and explode through the galaxy to accumulate the most achievements to leave this all behind.

Players can route power from their ships to different systems, as well as increase their Boost which defines who gets to take their turn first, and gives more flexibility in battle.

Once players arrive, if they have the cash or the cargo, they may choose from a plethora of actions to help them achieve their goals.


Buy Goods
Sell Goods
Salvage a card (to make money)
Swap a card (to draw a new cord)
Upgrade their ships different systems
Complete a Bounty (to gain Achievements)
Wipe a Bounty off the Board
Fire on another player in their system.
Repair their Hull
Reload their Weapons
Refuel their Engines


If a player is fired on and their shields are brought below 0, they lose some of their resources to the attacking player. But watch out for counter attacks. Its important do pay attention to what system your opponents might be going to, in order to either disrupt their plans, or avoid their fire.
categories: Card Game, Economic, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Hand Management, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: FLIP
description:
FLIP is a simple checker-like game for two players. The game includes a game board like a checker board with a red borderline around one-half and a blue borderline around the other half. There are 24 special chips resembling poker chips that are red on one side and blue on the other. Each player places 12 chips in two rows of six on the first and second row of his side of the board leaving a vacant square to the left and to the right. The player on the red side places chips red side up. The player on the blue side places chips blue side up.

The players' objective is to move their chips across the board to occupy the same positions as the opponent's starting chips. Each turn a player may move one chip one space to an empty square in any direction. A player may also jump an opponent's chip that is adjacent provided there is an empty square behind the chip. Similar to a king in checkers, multiple jumps may be made in a single turn in any direction including diagonally. A player may never jump his own chip. Whenever a diagonal jump is made, the player flips the opponent's chip over to his color and this becomes his chip. Reducing the opponent's number of chips to less than 12 prevents the opponent from winning until he acquires 12 chips again.

—user summary

name: Tom & Jerry: So ein Käse
description:
Funny, colorful and full of happy actions. That's the way Tom and Jerry are known on TV, and so is this game. 2-4 players try to get a complete cheese with their mice - but that's not so easy. Because, as much as one tries to get on the auspicious cheeses fields - the evil teammates always push you back to where you do not want. And turning on the lucky clock usually does not help. And if you almost believe in your destination, you will be stealing another piece of your own cheese. There is only one thing: Pay back with the same coin...

—description from the publisher (translated)
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Ricochet: The New Casino Game
description:
This is a dice game for players who enjoy the hazards of the casino. All players start with 20 chips. The game board is divided into four sections. Each section has 5 identical lanes lead from START to a finish on a GREEN Square. Each player chooses one section and places five chips on the squares marked "START". Each player rolls the pair of dice. High number starts and play continues clockwise.

The game is divided into matches. A match is won by the first player to fill a GREEN square. The chips are moved from START to the GREEN area in their lane according to the roll of the dice. One chip can be moved the total of the dice or each die can be used separately to move two chips. A seven must be split except when chips are in the PURPLE area (see next paragraph). On a roll of doubles the player may move or take the POT if there are any chips in the POT (See RED in next paragraph). To "Ricochet" means to reverse direction while moving one chip. In order to land in the GREEN the count must be exact. If the roll would take the chip beyond the double line, the chip can be reversed at the double line. The winner of a match takes all the chips in play from all players except those chips on START or GREEN. The game is over when one player has filled all five of his GREEN squares. The game winner takes all the chips in play except those on START. The ultimate winner is the player with the most chips.

Each section contains areas of colored squares. A chip cannot remain in the RED area. It must be put in the POT. The WHITE area is safe. Chips may remain in WHITE and be moved when the player wishes. A chip in the BLUE area is safe until another player places a chip in the BLUE. The first player must then surrender his chip to that player. A chip in the PURPLE area must move before a chip in the WHITE, BLUE or START. If there is more than one chip in the PURPLE, the one nearest the GREEN must move first. Chips in PURPLE must use the total on the dice to move one chip. A chip in the ORANGE area is lost and remains frozen until the match is over.

name: Marathon Game
description:
Players draw a running shoe as a token to move on the board and place them on START. Game cards are shuffled and placed face down on the designated space. The player with the Number 1 shoe draws the top game card and follows the instructions on the card for movement. The card is then placed on the designated discard space. Players continue to draw cards in turn until the cards are exhausted. The cards are re-shuffled and placed face down again. Play continues until all players have passed the through the finish chute.

When a player is instructed to go to the Sporting Goods Store, Rest Stop, etc. they lose a turn then discard the card. After loss of turn the player moves back onto the course.

The game board track is littered with information about runners, metabolic processes, metric conversions. running statistics and historical notes.

—user summary

name: Nightmare On Production Street
description:
Do you and your colleagues dare to take a journey into the frightening depths of a turnkey manufacturing project where anything and everything can go wrong? the objective is to travel counterclockwise around the gamer board by rolling the pair of dice, moving forwards or backwards as the squares indicate and by moving as the "Now What" and "Surprise" cards indicate.

Players place their tokens on the "Start Here" space. Each player rolls the dice and high roll goes first. Subsequent turns proceed clockwise. On a turn, the player rolls the dice and moves exactly that number of spaces to land on a space. The player must follow the directions on the space to move further, lose turns, draw a Surprise card or draw a What Now card. If drawing a card, follow its instructions. The turn then ends unless the player rolled doubles in which case the player rolls again.

The game can be won in three ways. First, a players can win by landing on the space that says "Your Turnkey Got Your Product Out. You're a Winner". If players overshoot the space, they continue around the board again. Second, players can agree to a time limit and the player that has traveled around the board the most times wins. There are scores sheet to keep track of progress. Third, there is a four piece visual made up of cards from the two card decks. If a player gets the four cards to complete the visual, they win.

—user summary

name: Slamorama
description:
SLAMORAMA! is a crazy and I mean crazy wrestling card game that will engage your full mental capacity as much as it will tickle your funny bone. Two to four players can brawl in this mental slap-stick game as they pit their moves against each other. You start out by picking one of four wacky wrestlers; "Glittersaurus Wrecks", "Mountain Man Rick", "El Alacran", or "The She-E-O" with their arsenal of insane moves to take out their opponents. Whoever wins the most cards wins the game and you do that by collecting the most tricks. (Publisher Description)

Slamorama is a 2-4 player wrestling card game from Binary Cocoa! Players all play their best moves against each other to win rounds, and whoever wins the most rounds by the time the cards are gone wins the game!

How to play:
1. Each player is given a deck of 13 cards that consists of wrestling moves like punches or slaps or suplexes. 1 is the strongest "move" card, while 7 is the weakest.

2. Players then count to three and throw down what they think will be the strongest move, and whoever that is wins the round! On a tie players throw down an additional card until someone finally wins. No one wins the round if the tie occurs on the last round.

3. Rounds go until all players decks are empty, and whoever wins the most rounds wins!

Special Features:
1. Each wrestler has a signature move that fits their persona. For example. Mountain Man Rick's Special move is the Salmon Slam. He literally picks people up and swings them around like a bear on the Snake River. Glittersaurus Wrecks special move is the rise and shine. She will lift you up just to bring you down. Very down.

2. The game allows for future expansions that will provide more wrestlers! We are planning on calling this first edition the "Red Deck", and (pending successful funding) we will be coming out with a "Green Deck". The Green Deck will have all new wrestlers so that you can combine decks and have up to 8 players in a game.

Alternate Game Modes:
In a standard game of Slamorama each player gets a deck of 13 cards and can have 4 in their hand that they can look at. Each full deck of Slamorama comes with two additional gameplay modes that include the following:

Full Deck Mode - Where you have all 13 cards in your hand and can look at them. Saves time from having to draw cards. Gives more "tactical advantage".

Tag Team Mode - Players choose a partner and play their cards together against opponents to win rounds! They cannot look at or tell each other what they are going to throw down however. Fun with bigger groups!

Game Contents:
52 cards (13 for each wrestler)

3 rule cards (each with a unique way of playing the game)

1 tuck box to hold the cards.
mechanics: Simultaneous Action Selection, Take That, Team-Based Game, Trick-taking

name: Shodo
description:
Shodo is the name given to Japanese calligraphy, considered by many people a true art, quite difficult to be perfected. Shodo art learners must have discipline and observe the techniques in each lesson taught by their master. Therefore, in this game, each player is an apprentice of this art, and therefore must execute the lessons passed by his master, joining the pieces that contain traces of traces, forming the calligraphic drawings required by one of the lessons.

Each player, on his turn, must manage his amount of paint, produced in his Suzuri, which will serve to acquire new pieces of strokes that complete his calligraphic designs or start new ones. The available pieces are renewed on the table as the players use them. Calligraphic drawing lesson cards are arranged randomly with each game, and players must observe the strategy of the other players to try to complete the lessons before the others, which will give them more points.

Completing a calligraphic drawing may not be as simple as doing so requires completing all the strokes already started. Once a drawing is completed and is also compatible with one of the available lessons (requirements may consist of the number of strokes, the shape of the drawing, or even the level of detail), the player may place one of his markers in that lesson. The first to place, in addition to receiving more points, make it impossible for the latter to place markers in the lessons.

Once all the lessons have been completed by at least one person, the game will be over, and it will be the winner who made the most points, obtained through the complexity of their calligraphic designs and the accomplishment of the lessons.

—description from the designer

name: FINAL BURGER -LAST ORDER-
description: A trick-taking game, with bidding, where the cards earned from a trick are used to form hamburgers. The cards are round with a bun shown on the back. The suits are hamburger ingredients, such as a burger, lettuce, tomato, egg, cheese, etc. The pickle and french fry suits act as trump.

name: INFO-MANIA
description:
INFO-MANIA is a challenging word game for any number of players. Each player is in a race against the clock and all other players to think of words in a particular category and starting with a selected set of letters of the alphabet. The player with the highest score wins.

Each player is given a score sheet and pencil. The decks of alphabet cards and category cards are shuffled. One player selects five alphabet cards at random and players copy these letters on their score sheets. One player draws a category card at random and players enter this on their score sheets. The timer is set and play begins.

Players write down words that apply to the category and whose last or major name begins with each of the selected letters. When time runs out each discloses the name he has written under each of the five letters. If only one player used a particular name, he scores 3 points. If two players use the same name, they score 2 points. If three or more players use the same name, they score 1 point. If a player did not write down a name for a letter, they do not score a point. After the first category is completed, the procedure is repeated until five different categories have been played. The player with the highest total points over all five categories is the winner.

—user summary

name: NIWI
description:
NIWI is similar in scoring to the game "The First 5,000" but it involves movement on a game board where a player may land their piece on a space occupied by an opponent's piece sending the opponent's piece backward on the board and reducing the opponent's score.

The object of the game is to achieve the highest score over 5,000 by throwing scoring combinations of six dice. Players move playing pieces counter-clockwise around the numbered board to record their score. The scoring dice are: a 5 equals 50 points, a 1 equals 100 points, any 3 of a kind equals 100 times the 3-of-a-kind number. A roll of six consecutively numbered dice (a straight) on one roll equals 1500 points. A minimum of 500 points in a turn is required to get on the board. A minimum of 300 points in a turn is required to advance on the board. As long as a player rolls at least one scoring die, the player may choose to roll again to try to increase their score for that turn. The scoring dice are set aside and the non-scoring dice are picked up and rolled again. Any roll with no scoring dice ends the player's turn and no points are scored. A player may end their turn after any scoring roll and keep the points accumulated for that turn with one exception. If all six dice are scoring dice either in one roll or in a combination of rolls, the player must roll again. After the first player has scored 5000 points the other players have one last chance to outscore that player. The highest score over 5000 wins.

A player may NIWI an opponent by rolling a score which lands them on the same space as an opponent in front of them. That opponent must then retreat their piece to the previous NIWI corner of the board and their point count is reduced to that of the first scoring space preceding that NIWI corner. Also, the opponent must roll a minimum of 500 points to proceed on the board their next turn.

—user summary

name: Tiddle Poker
description:
Each player takes a set of seven winks and a sqidger (the large disc that flips the winks) of a unique color. Each player also gets a wooden block with a felt surface to use as a place from which to launch one’s own winks. The players’ target is a wooden game board with a nine by six grid with a standard deck of playing cards (with jokers) painted on it.

The players decide which card game they wish to play (the rules give instructions for Draw Poker, Five Card Stud Poker, Seven Card Stud Poker, Blackjack and Beginner Flip Hi, an original game). Each player places one’s own block six inches away from the game board and play.

—user summary
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Betting and Bluffing

name: Onslaught
description:
You and your fellow comrades are teaming up to fend off the oncoming monsters trying to make their way back into Somberwood Citadel. You and your team have to survive the massing waves as they continue to barrage the gates. Can you survive the Onslaught?

Onslaught is a cooperative tower defense game for 1 to 6 players. Each turn more enemies will spawn, but that's ok because in between waves you can go salvaging to upgrade your turrets to make defending easier. At some point The Maker will send one elite monster, or maybe he will even show up to try to finish the job. If you can stop them then you win and have successfully driven him from his castle!

A turn is comprised of multiple phases. The first phase will have all players adding weapons or support cards to their own personal pillbox. The second phase will have monsters advance, followed by having new monsters arrive. The third phase is fending off all monsters visible. Players, in no particular order, will take turns targeting a monster they wish to shoot. If their roll is successful, they damage the monster according to their weapon. If they miss, nothing happens and another player may shoot. Instead of shooting, a player may support a teammate with one of their shots adding extra accuracy. These steps repeat until the elite monster is defeated causing the players to win, or until a single monster has re-entered the citadel causing the players to lose and have to try again another day.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Bull Rally
description:
The stock market draws in investors with dreams of wealth and success — but it often spits them back out with empty pockets. Do you have what it takes to turn a profit?

Bull Rally is a simple, real-time trading game that captures many of the basic concepts and emotions of the stock market.

Over ten trading days, players buy and sell stocks in real time, then update each stock's price on the stock chart based on supply and demand, news reports, and other market conditions. Holding the right stocks at the right time will also earn dividends. The player who earns the most money wins — but anyone who earns a profit is a successful trader!

—description from the designer

name: The Great Collector
description:
Game story:
You came into an unprecedented fortune of masterpiece paintings that previously belonged to some of the greatest collectors of the past - King Charles I, Kaiser Rudolf II, Empress Catherine the Great or a true visionary merchant Sergei Shchukin.

Their art heritage was scattered around the world and you now have the chance to make your mark and reunite these collections back again.

Start your hunt for the missing pieces - pave your way through the dark times of history, roll the dice on erratic art market and steal the show from other collectors in the quest for success.

This game is based on real history events that shaped the world of art we live in today. All the artworks involved did truly belong to the main characters at some point of their lives.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is about creating your own strategy on the way to reassemble one of the greatest art collections of the past and preventing others from being the first to achieve that.

It simulates the turbulent art market with auction bidding, dealer and gallery sales, organising exhibitions and even bluffing when the stakes are high. Various historic and art market events - from maniacs to revolutions - can dramatically change the flow of the game.

To acquire new pieces for the collection you would obviously need some cash. And there are numerous ways to earn some by setting up thematic shows and selling artworks strategically. However, money only won't get you to the top. You have to level up your collector's skills to become the next Great Collector. This will widen your choices and give you a fair advantage on the market.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Set Collection

name: Doubt
description:
The year is 1972. The Cold War continues to strain international relations between NATO allies and the Soviet Union. Your Spymaster suspects that the enemy has compromised operatives within your organization. Find the enemy spies!

At game start, players draw international location cards from the location deck. Choose one as your secret hideout, and leave the rest facedown in the center of the table as false leads. Be the first one to correctly identify the opponent’s true secret locations without being eliminated.

Each round, players pick a card from the intel deck and use it to investigate a hideout. The player who is associated with the hideout location must truthfully confirm or deny whether the intel describes the hideout location correctly. Through deduction, the false hideouts can be identified by piecing the clues together.

Be careful! Each time you investigate a false hideout, you increase the chance of being exposed… and eliminated!

-description from designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Team-Based Game

name: キュービズム (Qubism)
description:
A two-player abstract strategy game where the goal is to move your pawn to the other player's starting row. Cubes with arrows act as obstacles.

On a player's turn they may either move their pawn orthogonally once space (including backwards); place a cube onto the board (with restrictions on the placement of the arrow); or move a cube that is present and rotate it.
publishers: DEBUG MONKEYS (デバッグモンキーズ)

name: Chiangmai Checkers
description:
A two-player abstract strategy game, reputedly originating from Chiangmai, Thailand, where it is said to be called Mhark Nheeb.

Players take turns to move one of their 8 marbles, which initially start on the back row of an 8×8 grid, any number of spaces in a horizontal or vertical direction.

Opposing marbles can be captures in one of two ways - enclosing or balancing.

Enclosing captures are made by moving a marble so as to trap one or more opposing marbles between the marble just moved and a pre-existing friendly marble, in an unbroken straight line, horizontally or vertically. The trapped marbles are removed from the board.

Balancing captures occur when a player moves a marble directly in between two opponents, one on either side in a vertical or horizontal direction, upon which the two opposing marbles are removed from the board.

(The rules in my possession do not state that captures are compulsory, nor do they suggest that any number other than 2 opposing marbles can be captured by balancing. Examples of enclosing captures of 1 or 2 opposing marbles are shown, from which I infer that any number (up to 6) opposing marbles may be captured in this way).

When a player is reduced to a single marble, he or she loses the game, unless he/she can WIN it with the very next move.

(The rules in my possession do not state what happens if a player is reduced from 2 or more down to zero moves in a single capture, but the implication is that this player immediately loses the game).

name: Great Siege of Malta: Battle for St Elmo
description:
The year is 1565 and on a tiny island in the Mediterranean, a small garrison of Knights of St John and Maltese within Fort St Elmo face off against a massive invading force of Ottomans under their supreme naval commander, Piyale Pasha. With control of the Mediterranean as the ultimate prize, will the Knights hold out long enough for relief to arrive from Sicily or will the Pasha succeed in a stunning show of military strength?
The stage is set for the greatest siege in European history.

The Great Siege of Malta is a wargame in two parts. Part 1: the Battle for St Elmo - where players can re-explore the strategies and events of the famous battle; and Part 2: the Siege of Senglea (scheduled for a 2021 release) which can uniquely be combined with part 1 (the boards will fit together) for a tabletop siege of truly epic proportions.

Both games use tokens and/or miniatures to represent the different military units available, on a gameboard presenting a detailed tactical map of the famous locations. The game offers tactical versatility within a simple ruleset that guarantees quick play. A combination of dice and card driven gameplay with a special Command Dice mechanism forces the players to think carefully which military units they will trigger for the round based on the limited available commanders. Combat dice then resolve the outcome of each attack while giving players opportunities to influence the outcomes through card play.

Game rounds represent single days of the siege with the two commanders having opportunities to manipulate their troops and play additional thematically rich special cards. The game can be played as a 'recreation of history' with known events occurring in certain rounds or as a more freeform 'what if' style of game that allows players on both sides to experiment with different strategies. Winning the game is not about destroying the enemy but instead focuses more on the balance of morale between the two opposing forces. Use superior tactics and brave challenges to improve your own morale or undermine the enemy and grab the victory!

The game is as historically accurate as we can make it. BadCatGames has worked closely with academic experts to ensure the game gives players an exciting opportunity to relive this most famous moment in european history in all its detail. Siege of Malta also presents the facts of history as they stand. The game does not take sides in any way and does not glorify either of the forces involved to the detriment of the other. The wargame is simply a gripping and thematic educational opportunity to experience this greatest of sieges.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Simulation

name: Cholent, The Game!: Cholent, the Expansion!
description:
What's the only thing better than Cholent? More Cholent!
Cholent, the Expansion includes a brand new Mazel deck, making the game more wild than ever! You've played the game. Now try it with a bit of Mazel on your side.

—description from the publisher

name: Anderson-Cottonwood-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITIES OF ANDERSON-COTTONWOOD, CA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Anderson-Cottonwood we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...an exquisite park right in between - a little something for everybody! Looking for a fun way to experience the Shasta Cascade?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Anderson-Cottonwood properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO ANDERSON-COTTONWOOD! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many omelets from Becca’s Café! THIS IS ANDERSON-COTTONWOOD.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

-description from designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Clearlake-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF CLEARLAKE, CALIFORNIA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Clearlake we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...the legendary lake itself -a little something for every Clearlaker! Looking for a fun way to experience the small town with a big heart?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Clearlake properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO CLEARLAKE! You may soon be the Mayor…or out of the game for eating too many salmon burritos from the Cactus Grill! THIS IS CLEARLAKE.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

-description from designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Crescent City-Opoly
description:
HOW DO YOU MAKE A GAME ABOUT THE GREAT CITY OF CRESCENT CITY, CA? While it’s impossible to include everything, we jammed all the Crescent City we could into this box. It’s full of outdoor adventures, family attractions, rich traditions and of course...an old, historic lighthouse - a little something for everybody! Looking for a fun way to experience Land’s End?

HERE’S A QUICK IDEA OF HOW TO PLAY! Buy your favorite Crescent City properties, increase your rent by collecting City Blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sound easy? Well, add in some traffic jams, property tax and parking fines and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun! GET YOUR GAME ON!

So choose your token and advance to GO CRESCENT CITY! You may soon be the Mayor… or out of the game for eating too many pizzas from SeaQuake Brewing! THIS IS CRESCENT CITY.... AND IT’S YOUR ROLL!

-description from designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Rock 'n' Rumble
description:
Players get dealt 4 musicians and instruments to form a band. Each player has 2 actions they can take on a turn 1) play a card 2) Trash (discard) one of their instruments. As the bands battle it out to win over the crowd, their ultimate goal is to impress the Record Label Scout who is attending the show. At the start of each game, a label scout is chosen at random and placed on the table. Each label scout has different victory conditions and the first band to meet one of the conditions wins.

-description from designer

name: Carte Junior
description:
Carte Junior is a game with a traditional deck of 40 Italian cards, with children friendly illustrations.
It includes 4 traditional games reimplemented in a simplified version for children, mainly about the final scoring.
The games are Scopa, Briscola, Straccia camicia (Beggar My Neighbour) and Carta più alta (a simplified version of War/Battle).

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Set Collection, Trick-taking

name: Gatekeeper
description:
Tactical turn based game which has you controlling armies of the undead as you gain power and more souls. The aim is to destroy your fellow players gatekeeper pieces, without threatening your own.

A play can earn more souls and expand their army faster the closer to the middle of the board they are willing to get though this places them at risk of being killed themselves, making for an interesting balance between attack and defense.

—description from the designer

name: Of Gods and Men
description:
A tactical board game where you play against other plays to conquer a new world by gaining the most influence over it. Influence is achieved through a combination of warfare, knowledge, money and religion, allowing players to each adopt different strategies to win.

In turns players can choose to explore unsettled territory, attack opponents or pursue religious, knowledge or cultural growth through a variety of research. As players develop, they can increase influence points with the first player to reach 20 points claiming ultimate victory.

The game can be played individually with others or in teams, allowing for many different ways of playing.

—description from the designer

name: Night of Thieves
description:
You play as a thief with a purpose trying to gather as much gold as possible to cripple an oppressive government. The game can be played either against others or in teams and sees you utilising both a combination of luck and skill to get ahead.

Players start off from their chosen guild on the board and roll dice to navigate through the town to try and steal as much loot as possible. Each door requires a certain dice roll for a break-in attempt to be successful, where a card is then picked up athat determines items gained or further actions by the player.

While navigating the town, players must avoid guards who move in random directions each round and also try and solve certain quests thru may gain along the way. Once a player/gud reaches a predetermined amount of money, the game is then won.

Players can play either individually or in teams with optional quests added to make the game even more diverse through each play through.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Trapped!
description:
You play as a group of miners trapped underground and need to work together to try and find your way to a lift and back out safely.

The game starts with players drawing a tile and then placing their markers on the tile. Each player then has a chance to perform a certain number of actions within a turn which includes movement, placement of new tiles and picking up/using objects found in the mine. Every so often rockfall may happen, forcing players to need to dig out of these before continuing. Players also have to manage their energy and weight levels to stay alive and move at a sufficient pace.

The game is one when all players are able to make their way successfully to the elevator shaft out of the mine. Along the way, crystals can also be mined and the surviving player with the most crystals, wins the game.

—description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Tile Placement

name: Plane Wars
description:
In this card and dice game you play as a group of select beings capable of traversing different planes as you need to battle it out not only for your survival, but that of mankind.

Each player starts off by selecting a plane walker from the deck and then a landscape from the plane deck. The landscape will come with a preset effect which alters each players abilities as well as default dice rolls. A set of dice is then rolled by each of the players and combined to form combinations which enable a player to make different moves against their opponent. Every round a new landscape is drawn, so players will need to adjust their tactics per landscape.

The first player to have thief life points reduced to 0 ultimately loses the game. The game can be played with either one or multiple plan walkers per player, depending on length of game that is desired.

—description from designer

name: Star Waves: Season One Expansion
description:
The Season One Expansion adds 5 Fuel and 5 Credits, allowing a third player to join the game. Also, it contains 60 brand-new Cards split into 3 Mini-Episodes.

Each Mini-Episode features 18 Cards, 1 Artifact Card & 1 Quest Card and has it's unique symbol printed on the card. When playing with two or three players, shuffle the added cards of one Mini-Episode into the Action & Location Card piles.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck

name: Keldadrune: The Winds of Fortune
description:
In Keldadrune players each move two tokens via die rolls across a large gridded board. Spaces landed on may do various things to the players or may be purchasable properties; there are "common" properties which have just one card and "kingdom" properties which have two. Players must pay the owners of properties they land on. The properties mostly have names drawn from Greek, Roman, and Norse mythology: Fensalir, Parnassus, House of Aeolus, etc.

There is also a stock market divided into eight groups; a player can choose to be the manager of a group and have some kind of influence over price changes for those stocks (the rules are not very clear). All players can speculate in the stocks. The stocks, in contrast to the properties on the board, are named like real companies and some are just misspelled versions of those (e.g. Kelloogue Breakfast Foods Inc.).

The game features a variety of additional rules, some eccentric. Players who own kingdom properties must be addressed by title, from "Lady" or "Sir" for owning one kingdom to "Maharina" or "Maharaja" for owning all eight. A player landing on a Cupid space must seek out a player of a different gender (the rules say "opposite charm") and travel with them. Etc.

The winner is the player with the most money after a predetermined period of time.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Le Grand Jeu du Champagne
description: A Board/Trivia game based on the Moët et Chandon Champagne world. Questions are about History/Tourism, economy/gastronomy, and viniculture. Board represents the Champagne area.

name: Starforce Command: Planetary Ground Combat
description:
A simple, enjoyable and fun set of Planetary Ground Combat Wargames Rules for micro scale models or counters. The rules form the first part of a trilogy called Star Command.

Included in the download is a rules booklet, a front cover and 40 game cards. No dice are required for playing the game; the game cards will determine any chance or damage results. Card vehicle counters will be available from our website soon as a free download, so all you really need to play the game is your trusty ruler.

Starforce Command is set in the future after your home world has been under alien domination for nearly a millennium. The planetary resistance has successfully struck against the aliens, unleashing a deadly virus that has annihilated the unwanted creatures. But from the blackened ashes of disaster Star Command was born, a military organisation that used the aliens’ technology against them. For over two millennium war as raged unceasingly across the known universe.

Design your own Starforce in a matter of minutes with the use of the free vehicle design sheet, then select your grunt squads and go forth to victory. Land your Starforce with drop ships or appear through jump gates ready to assault your foe. Draw specially designed game cards to determine your random chance, and then use the same cards to inflict damage upon your enemy. Modify and redesign your vehicles if they don’t just fit the role, fine tune them and try again, seek perfection and you might just get the ultimate Starforce.

—description from publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Simulation, Variable Player Powers

name: GORiATE
description:
In GORiATE, each player plays as David against a central Goliath, competing in four battles through the course of the game. Players use a hand of 5 cards to adjust the strength and height that they can sling against Goliath. At the end of the round, the player that casts the striking blow (coming closest to Goliath's number without going over), will earn fame points, and the player with the most fame points wins.

—user summary

name: Saloon Shootout
description:
Saloon Shootout is a mini-tactics game, using only 9 cards and a few dice. You'll need to rely on your wits, your strategy, and your luck to survive.

In Saloon Shootout, you control a team of outlaws who have been surrounded by a rival gang. Your team is severely wounded, and will bleed out quickly unless you can survive the onslaught of knives and bullets headed your way.

Each turn, you move your teammates around a randomly-generated saloon, taking cover from enemy units while trying to take them down. Each character has their own unique attributes and abilities, which you'll need to take advantage of in order to survive.

Featuring interesting tactical gameplay, a unique map-building mechanic, and dozens of team composition, Saloon Shootout is a must if you're interested in games like Imperial Assault or XCOM.

—description from the designer
categories: American West, Dice, Fighting, Print & Play
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board

name: Tableland
description:
Learning 'times' tables is dull but necessary. Tableland makes it fun. Tableland is a unique game devised by Professor Dexter Dunphy of the University of N.S.W. to help his own children enjoy learning their tables. For ages 6 to 10.

In turn, each player rolls a die and moves their token around the board. At crossroads the player can decide for themselves which track to take. If the player lands on a Multiplication space, the player has to give the correct answer or go back to where their have come from. If another player thinks the answer given is wrong, they may 'challenge'. If the challenger is correct they will gain bonus spaces.

If a player lands on a purple space they will receive some advantage; if the player lands on a red space they will receive a disadvantage. First player to the finish space wins.

—user summary

name: kiSabadulos: Csanad – the little locomotive
description:
DIY KIDS sold by HOMESCAPE is a series of escape room style educative puzzle games specifically for kindergarten and pre-school age children.

The first in the series is: "Csanad, the little locomotive" where the group has to help the story protagonist navigate through a busy station by completing several tasks.

Children in groups of 1-4 (aided by an adult game master) solve a total of 8 varied puzzles to advance the story and achieve the final goal. The quest is expected to be completed in 60 minutes, and the team scores points for extra time left as well as puzzles solved without hints. The game comes with a game master guide to set up and play through the adventure.
categories: Adventure, Children's Game, Educational, Print & Play, Puzzle

name: Office Overload
description:
You (and possibly coworkers) go into work one day and come to find that your entire company has been taken over by robots.
You must explore the office to find items fight robots, and defeat your regional manager.

In this game you get 4 game pieces to choose from, The stapler, The Hole Punch, The Staple Remover, and The Binder Clip. In a room you have a Chance to roll a dice to find an event, an item, or an enemy.

Using your Dice and Items, roll to defeat the robots using your DMG, and fight your way to the 5 different offices, 4 of which are mini bosses and optional, however the 5th office, known as the red office is where your regional manager is, and you have to defeat your manager to save the office, and live to work another day.

—description from the designer

name: Find The King
description:
Players are given one set of colored cards, either all reds or all blacks. Players are also given one different colored King. To win the game, you have to find your colored king in your opponent's deck. Players lay their full deck face down, choosing which cards go where. Players take turns choosing which cards move around and which ones fight, with highest number winning. Don't loose track of the king, because if you accidentally expose him, you lose!

—description from the publisher

name: He She Him Her
description: A satirical game where the male army represented by bolts, tries to keep the female army, represented by the brass rings, in the kitchen.

name: Connections
description:
Connections is based on a tested and proven psychological theory known in clinical circles as "Choice Theory". This game allows players to enjoy the benefits and to learn the psychological lessons of the theory without ever having to crack a book, attend a lecture, or lie on the couch.

—description from the publisher

During the game, players roll and move around the board. Along the way, they will encounter cards for Connecting Habits, Disconnecting Habits, and Quality World. Upon giving personal answers to these cards, players will earn points. The first player to reach 1,000 points wins.

The box contains: board, D6, six player pawns, 33 game cards, 6 escape cards, beginner's guide, score pad, and instructions.

—user summary

name: Bridges of Budapest
description:
The Bridges of Budapest is a game about the unification of the cities Buda, Obuda, and Pest in the second half of the 19th Century. These cities sat on either side of the River Danube and only became one when the Szechenyi Chain Bridge was built across the river. In this game, you will design and build the famous bridges and buildings that earned Budapest the soubriquet "The Pearl of the Danube"
