After each three rounds you have to perform certain actions during an »Encampment Phase« in which you try to conquer one of the very important fortified towns. For this combat action each player chooses the more defensive »Threatening Attack« or the more aggressive and physical »Storm Attack«. And the decision is crucial, because not only may it decide over the success or failure of the attack, you may also be attracted to act more aggressively in trying to storm the fortified towns (or strongholds) to make all the more booty (and even to increase your gain in Victory Points) but you'll on the other hand receive all the more Aggression Points, which increases the probability of a more severe punishment at the game's end.
Cause in the end your fate lies in the hands of the »Principals' Justice« and you may yet lose much of what you've gained. And the punishment you'll receive reflects on your actions during game play. The decisions are as hard to make as the paths to win Eysenhudt are manifold. Overall the game is more cooperative than competitive. Nonetheless each player has to find his or her own strategy to score as much Victory Points as possible.

—description from the designer
categories: Medieval, Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Renaissance, Wargame

name: Nazo-toki Book: Akuma no tegata
description:
~ Mystery Solving Book: The Devil’s Handprint ~

„If you decipher the ancient document, a door will open...” – This book is composed of such riddles. All the stories are connected, and the cases progress as the mysteries are being solved. Then eventually, a grandiose final mystery emerges!
One player becomes the questioner. They read the mystery aloud, then draws a card with a picture on it, and shows it to the other players. The card contains clues related to the cases. The clues can be instant hints, or have an importance later on. If you give a wrong answer, you might get an unexpected reply from the questioner. The questioner’s turn goes clockwise.
The main component of the game is a book, which attempts to evoke an atmosphere similar to that of mystery TPRG’s and escape games. The book counts 52 pages, with 8 mysteries to solve. Playtime is about 60~90 minutes. Difficulty is easy, and basically anyone can play it (all the kanji learnt above elementary 6th grade has furigana attached). However, the stories gradually get harder and harder towards the end.
A free demo is available for download on the official homepage.

name: Chicken -n- Waffles
description:
Each player is dealt an equal number of hands of four cards each (quantity depending upon the number of players). An additional hand of four are placed face-up in the center of the play area. Turns happen in real-time and simultaneously with players exchanging only one card from one hand with a card from the pool in the center of the table. Players may only have one hand active at a time in their hand and must lay any others down on the table face-down. When discarding a card to the center to trade, players must call out the name of the animal they are laying down. If it is a pig, instead of yelling "Pig", they say "Waffles", the pig's name.

If a player has both a chicken and Waffles in their hand, they may discard them both to pick up two cards instead of the normal one, exclaiming "Chicken -n- Waffles!"

The goal is to get all your hands to have matching four-of-a-kind sets with the exception of the chicken and Waffles cards - these must be paired up with matching features (color of clothes) and combined with any other pair of animals. The round winner chooses another animal to add to the deck and plays the next round with an additional hand of cards. When playing with four hands (having won one), you may not use the wilds. When you win a second round, you may use wilds again, but must play the rest of the game one-handed. The first player to win three rounds is the overall winner.

In a 6 player game, you play until you win two rounds, with the previous middle round (not being able to use wilds) ignored.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Electronic Movin' Hoops
description:
It’s a race against the clock with the Rec-Tek Electronic Movin’ Hoops! The fun is nonstop with 2 great game options to choose from! Choose to play as a beginner and leave the moving hoops motor off for an easy straight shot, or choose the Advance mode, turn the motor on, and shoot for the moving hoops for a bigger challenge! How many shots can you sink in 60 seconds?

GAME FEATURES:

Motorized Hoops Move Side to Side for added Excitement
Spring-Shooters Swivel so you can Score from any angle
LED Scoring Automatically Tracks the Action
Real Stadium Sounds make you feel like you’re in the game
Complete with 8 Mini Basketballs
Set of Game Rules and Instructions
Assembled Dimensions - 28 IN (L) X 7.5 IN (W) X 9 IN (H)

name: Strange Sites
description:
Humans have been gathering around sacred sites for ages, and you and a university colleague have created an alogrithmic artificial intelligence program for your masters thesis that scours the internet for information about Alien contact with earth, only to discover that the subjects of many historical pieces, and even modern art pieces are painted with the subject being a location of Alien contact. On top of this you discover that there are actually multiple different races of Aliens, that have contacted our planet, waiting for our response to see which side we will join in the galactic, but the only way to contact them must be through discovering the secret behind these strange sites.

Strange sites is a two player game where players are racing to discover the sites of alien contact, and place their meeples onto them, in an attempt to be the first human to successfully make first contact. Each player is given an opportunity to choose a faction, and change it later, then both players investigate locations, and trigger their unique effects to help them speed towards victory. Using a 4x3 grid of randomized locations, players must search for powerful locations, without giving away information, using clever strategies and efficient choices to be the fastest one to victory!

—description from the publisher

name: Third Man
description: Similar to Twelve Men's Morris, this game was marketed in the late 1960s to emphasize the survival mechanism of three pieces.
mechanics: Pattern Building, Point to Point Movement

name: Dust 1947: Cobra/Rattler
description:
The Mickey chassis has been the first walker ever available for the Allies Bloc, thanks to the cunning of Joe Brown and the incredible engineering skills of Rosie Donovan. At first using weapons adapted from regular tanks, it's now up-gunned with latest technology weapons: the dreaded Cobra mounts a powerful Phaser gun capable of dealing with any armored threat, while the Rattler can blow any aircraft from the sky with ease.
This reference allows you to field one of these two variants, in either regular or amphibious configuration.

This reference comes with four Dust 1947 unit cards, one for each variant, amphibious or not, all for the Allied Bloc. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed. It's ready for the battlefield, or for painting, as you wish! You can directly paint over on it, since the priming serves as an undercoat and is compatible with any type of paint.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Dust 1947: Fireball/Punisher – Super Heavy Walker
description:
The Punisher is equipped the heaviest guns mounted on any Allied vehicle on the planet. A single shot from these can turn any armored unit into smoldering heaps of metal. The Fireball possess an incredible flamethrower that can melt any target, and several at the same time if they are aligned! Both these walkers can transport a full squad of soldiers and a hero and are armed with an amazing array of machineguns.
This reference allows you to field one of these two variants.

This reference comes with two Dust 1947 unit cards, one for each variant, both for the Allied Bloc. Like all regular Dust 1947 miniatures, it comes already assembled and primed. It's ready for the battlefield, or for painting, as you wish! You can directly paint over on it, since the priming serves as an undercoat and is compatible with any type of paint.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde
description:
Hidden Identity game based upon "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde"

Three to six players will secretly draw characters from a bag. All characters are considered "good citizens", except for Dr. Jekyll. Then, proceeding through 6 different stories, each player will draw and play clues based on their secret character. As these clues are played on the game board, players will each take turns going on "holiday", which will add to the suspense of determining who is good and who is hiding their real persona. All players can make accusations after successfully winning stories 4 and 5. Beware though! As Dr. Jekyll can make false accusations to further his transformation!

The good citizens are also attempting to remove chemicals (white substance cubes) from the board to thwart Dr. Jekyll's transformation. Dr. Jekyll will try to play clues of his own to eliminate the citizens and transform himself and escape forever.

Based on Robert Louis Stevenson's novella, "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, explore six peculiar incidents while trying to determine who is Dr. Jekyll ...before he escapes as Mr. Hyde! This classic story is the perfect theme for a social deduction game!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Traitor Game

name: Whirl, Spin the Top Game
description:
A spinning top game distributed under Shackman's name.

I've seen a couple of different boxtops for the game. They all seem to be made in Japan, so I'd guess after WWII, so circa 1950 for the games.

Basically there is a concave bowl which has balls which are knocked in holes with point values along the edge of the bowl area.

—user summary

Simple to perform but with fast interesting action. As top spins balls fly into numbered holes.

Rules:
One or more can play
Red ball is double score
Balls jumping outside game don't count for any score

—description from the box

name: Donkey Stack Stix Game
description:
Wooden cutout of a donkey that looks to be about an inch thick. On the donkey's tail is a small circular platform upon which one is to place small sticks that look like small matchsticks.

From the boxtop:


Each child secures batch of colored sticks and in turn places on donkey circle.



Scoring: Person who makes them fall gets nothing, others count sticks of their own color and that is their score.


Presumably the players would have agreed on some target score to win.

name: Conan: Savage Legends
description: Conan: Savage Legends takes place in Conan's Hyborean Age after the ancient necromancer, Xaltotun, shatters the walls of time and space, stranding heroes and villains alike together in Hyborea. You take on the role of a mighty legend, gather your warband, and go forth to battle other legends torn from space and time. Take command of your forces, gather magical artifacts, acquire power, and remind your foes why you deserve the title of legend.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination

name: Roll-A Golf
description:
A simple board game along the lines of Shut the Box.

The player has two dice, and 18 golf tees in two colors (9 of each color). The board has two rows of nine holes, one for the front 9, and another row for the back nine.
—user summary

Start the game with tees of one color in the front 9 holes, and tees of the other color set up in the back nine holes. Play the front 9. Roll the dice. The number showing on the dice determines which tees you can remove & how many you can remove. For example, if a player throws a total of 7 spots on the dice, he may remove the 5&2, or the 4, 2, & 1, or he may remove the tee in Hole 7. Player must use the entire number found on the dice throw. When a number is thrown, and the player can't remove tees on the front, leave what is left. Go to back 9, throw the dice, and start again. See how you rate. Scores are for the front & back holes combined.
—description from the rulebook


0 to 2 tees left - SUPER PRO!
3 tees -- Pro.
4 to 5 tees left -- So, So.
6 or more -- Duffer!"


TRY AGAIN."
—description from the packaging

name: Cookie Time!
description:
Cookie Time! is a fun hand management and set collection game for 2 to 4 players (ages 10 and up). The game takes about 20 to 40 minutes to complete. In this game you are a cookie connoisseur, trying to eat as many different types of cookies as possible to maximize your tasting experience. In addition, every cookie you eat has to be sweeter than the one you just ate.

However, all of your friends are thinking exactly the same way as you do and there are only a limited number of cookies. So think strategically and act fast before all of the tastiest cookies are gone. Sounds interesting? Now it’s Cookie Time!

In this game, the cookie cards can be placed on the plate to be scored as happiness points later. The cards can also be rotated 180 degrees to become money in the Wallet. On your turn, buy a pair of cards from the market to your hand and discard the money from your Wallet to the discard pile according to the market price card next to it. Then you must play 2 cards from your hand to your playing area, either to Plate or Wallet.

Play continues until there are not enough cards to replenish the market. Add all happiness together and the player with the most happiness is the winner of the game.

—description from the designer

name: Malakatl
description:
In Malakatl, players will play the role of miners. One of them is trying to extract silver, the other one tuff, both of which make up the national symbol of the Mexican state of Zacatecas.
The name Malakatl comes from Nahuatl and means winch. It refers to the winch that is used in the mines to lift heavy objects, minerals and water.

The two players must advance at least one of their miners to one of the mines. The other miners will be responsible for selecting the actions, that is, on the board there will be several actions to be carried out, and these actions must be taken by miners, if they are to be carried out. The goal is to extract the tuff or the silver and take them to the center of the board, where the players must build an obelisk which can be made of silver or tuff. But they must be careful not to disturb a sparrow, because by doing so, a mine will be disabled. The goal of the game is to collect as many points and build the obelisk, or make the sparrows settle in the opposite mines.
mechanics: Hand Management, Network and Route Building, Roll / Spin and Move, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers, Worker Placement

name: Score Five
description:
The game is played with "X" and "O" plastic pieces on a fold up board with an 8x8 grid of cells. The objective is to score points by making lines of 3 (5 pts), 4 (10 pts),or 5 (15 pts). A line of 6 immediately wins the game. A few of the spaces on the board are penalty spaces and a few are bonus spaces.

—user summary

name: Beni's Top 11
description:
Beni's Top 11 is a football card game created by the Swiss sports reporter Beni Thurnheer. The base game consists of two teams from the Swiss first football league, Grasshopper Club Zürich and FC Luzern, which can be pitched against each other on a tiny game board (a ball is not included, but any coin or other small item can be used).
Each player shuffles the stack of cards from their teams, which consists of three cards each of 15 players from that team. Then both players flip open the top card from their stack and compare the stats. The winning player (higher number) moves the ball one slot closer to the opponent's goal (or into the goal if the ball is in the box already). Depending on the ball's position, attack or defense values are used. If a player draws the coach, they can choose the stats from one of the three previous cards. After the stack of 45 cards is played through twice (two halves), the player with most goals is the winner.

At least one additional set of cards was released for BSC Young Boys in 1992.
The box credits a G. Meister as well, but whether as artist or co-designer remains unclear.

—user summary

name: Don't DIE Dungeon
description:
A novel solitaire game of dungeon delving played with a single component: a custom six sided die. Under the advanced rules, the game contains all the familiar tropes of a hack and slash dungeon crawl: traps, treasure, leveling, secret passages, monsters, magic items, and more.

The advanced rules also contain some strategy and planning along with some of the luck involved in a typical fantasy game with exploration and combat.

Clearly the achievement of the game, though, is to do it all with a single static game component.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Contract: Blackboss Promo Card
description:
A promo card distributed by the publisher at various conventions.

This mafiosi belongs to the Blackmat family and is worth 7 points. It replaces Darkson, the 3 points card of the same family.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Mafia

name: Hansel and Gretel
description:
Hansel and Gretel is a board game set in the forests of medieval Germany during the Great Famine. It's a treasure hunt, the poison ball from Croquet, and a classic fairy tale all in one!

Backstory
The Great Famine darkens the souls of Germany's forest inhabitants. Parents once faithful and generous have allowed self-preservation and greed to permeate their lives. Trusting and resourceful, Hansel and Gretel find themselves abandoned in the forest and lured into an evil trap.

With faith, greed, trust, and evil on full display, who will learn the lessons and consequences told through this classic Grimm Brother's tale?

Object of the Game
In Hansel and Gretel, you seek the forest for magical treasures, gain special powers, and guide the story's characters to complete startling events from the story line. The game begins with you hiding treats that provide special powers and treasures used to complete events. It progresses as you cooperatively reenact scenes from the story. You'll guide story character's actions and movements. On every turn you'll have meaningful decisions to make, decisions that impact how other's must react to an evolving plot. You earn points for accomplishing any of the following:


Influencing a Character,
Gaining a Special Ability, and
Completing an Event from the story.


Goal
The goal is to have the most points at the end of the game. You accumulate points during the game by finding treats and treasures that give characters special abilities and allow them to complete events from the story. You also earn points during end-game scoring for influencing the tale's four main characters - Hansel, Gretel, Father, and Witch.

To win, you'll enable the characters essential nature for reenacting a tale filled with conflict and consequence. Understanding the story's plot and devising clever strategies that exploit the character's true nature are key to winning.


Will you allow Father to abandon Hansel and Gretel in the Far Forest?
Perhaps you'll embrace the role of the Witch and lock Hansel in a cage?
Or, you might decide to help Gretel escape the Witch and bring her Gems to Father.


The unique hide and seek mechanic ensures endless variations and possibilities giving Hansel and Gretel an extremely high replay value. Regardless of the choices made, you'll explore the inner ego of each character while learning anew this classic tale's twists, turns, and consequences. The story of Hansel and Gretel comes to life in fun, suspenseful, and teachable ways.

—description from the deisgner
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Memory, Role Playing, Storytelling

name: Red Lines: A Syrian Shell Game About Sarin
description:
A compact 2-player wargame about the US and Russia competing in Syria. The US attempts to strike at Russian chemical weapons in Syria without while minimizing collateral damage and trying to avoid escalating a war with Russia. Russia attempts to deter the US strikes by disrupting US detection and targeting, disguising valuable assets, or running out the clock on the strike window.

The game involves elements of bluffing, deduction, budget management, and risk management. It can be played with or without a memory element. The entire game fits onto one page of rules, two pages for the map, and a half page of chits. It requires one 6 sided die to be supplied by the player.
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Dice, Modern Warfare, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Memory

name: Intel-Lectric Junior
description:
This is a quiz game for children. One player chooses a picture and an other has to point to the corresponding picture according to the theme of the used card. There are 12 two sided cards included.

The answers are checked with the quiz master, a pen shaped indicator with an LED. The quiz master is held touching the two sensor pads. If the contact node is pressed on the contact of one picture, the LED lights, if the finger of the other hand touches the contact of the corresponding picture.

—user summary

name: Discovery Duels
description:
Discovery Duels is set in the "Rise of the Occulites" universe.

It is a two player mini game that takes about 10 to 15 minutes to play. It places you as one of Darwin's two kids trying to discover the most about the different Occulite Tribes over the holidays, before you have to go back to school.

Goal: Be the one to discover the most about the Occulite Tribes by having the most Discovery Points after six rounds.

How to Play:
5 cards with different occulite tribes are placed in a row in numberical order (1 to 5).
Each player rolls their five dice. Players count to five while looking at what their opponent has rolled and then secretly order their own dice in a line behind their hand. This determines which card each die will be allocated to. The first die in the line will be allocated to the firest card and so on. The first player to finish allocating dice will break ties during the round.
After both players have finished ordering their dice, they are revealed and then placed on the card they were allocated to. Each card is then resolved in order (1 to 5), paying attention to the rules that are written on the card. When one player has a higher end total for a card than the other player, they are said to DISCOVER the card and receive a number of Discovery Points equal to the number on the card.
Players play six rounds in the way described above, totalling their Discovery Points across all six rounds.

name: Flip Tales
description:
Theme:
FlipTales is a party game for creative people! In FlipTales, you and your friends pretend to be different magical characters in a story, working together to advance the plot. It's like Mad-Libs meets Choose-Your-Own-Adventure.

Game-play:
In each story, one person is the wiz. In each scene of the story, the wiz reads out a prompt, and then the rest of the players freestyle in response.
In freestyle, players go in a circle and act out responses to the prompt. Then, they flip their coins in the air. If they get enough heads, they succeed. the wiz decides how many is enough.
If your character gets damaged, you have to give up strength coins. Lose them all, and you die. There's a lot of danger in the world of FlipTales so watch out

Game setup:
- STEP 1: Choose Wiz
They read the story and decide the result of the players' flips.
- STEP 2: Create characters
Everyone else gets 1 creature card and 1 ability card. Your character is the combination of these two cards.
- STEP 3: Grab coins
Grab the coins indicated on your cards and combine them. When you use your strength, magic, or smarts in the game, flip all your coins of that colour.(or use normal coins with the print & play version)
- STEP 4: Pick a story from the storybook
Hand it to the wiz. (start with the tutorial the first time)

Goal:
In FlipTales, you and your friends pretend to be different magical creatures in a story. You win when you get to the end of the story.

—description from the designer

name: Garden Lotto
description:
Players compete to complete illustrations of garden scenes by being the first to collect the nine tiles shown on their board.

Two methods of play are provided. In method one, players draw tiles face down from the top of either the draw pile or discard pile in hopes of finding tile that matches their board. In method two, all tiles are spread face down on the table and on a players turn they may secretly view any tile they wish, keeping any that match their board.

Garden Lotto was designed for The National Trust and features illustrations representative of the different types of garden found in the British Isles from Tudor times to the nineteenth century. Similar gardens can be seen in many National Trust properties.

—user summary

name: Guess Who Colluded
description:
Guess Who Colluded is about the Trump Presidency: mainly the WHO. Once people are more familiar with the WHO, they'll be more adept to learn the WHAT, WHEN, WHERE, and WHY. After all, this National Emergency is far reaching with many, many wheels turning it, and if we want to prevent America from falling into this pit of despair again, we need to know how to avoid it.

The game requires 2 players taking turns trying to figure out who the other person is. Players analyze patterns in physical characteristics, such as hair color or eyewear, or more abstract characteristics, like currently or previously worked in the White House Administration, to narrow down the playing field. There are two game modes: End the Witch Hunt (Trump vs. Mueller) and Stop the Leaks (Trump vs. Trump).

Cards can be played on a table, floor, or in hand. Players can also use or build custom card holders for a more interactive play through.

Additional notes, rules, and information can be found online in Colluminac.

—description from the designer

name: Sky Riders
description:
Sky Riders is a considerably rare space board game from Parker Brothers. It is dated as a 1940 release in the book American Games (Alex Malloy, 2000) and was featured in a series of advertisements in four consecutive December 1940 issues of Life Magazine.

The object of the game is for players to move around the solar system collecting the rare element, Coronium, and then return it to Earth without it being stolen by other players. Bags of Coronium are represented by yellow or green discs.

Each player starts with a small coloured wooden token (their Miner). Players move through the orbits of different planets based on the roll of two dice. A player collects Coronium by landing on a planet and then throwing a particular number associated with that planet.

When a Miner with five or more bags (discs) of Coronium lands on Mars, it becomes a Martian Raider. The small Miner token is exchanged for a large wooden token of the same colour. The Martian Raider can then capture Coronium from another player by landing directly on the player's Miner.

To win the game, a player must arrive back on Earth, by exact count, with 15 or more bags of Coronium.

name: Agentenjagd
description:
This is a game for 3 men (agents) and 3 women (assistants).
The agents are the active players, while the female assistants watch over the rules and serve alcoholic drinks to the agents.

Each player has 3 Agents (caps) which enter the game board (Paris) from different directions. Movement is determinet by a roulette disc.

If an agent gets on a space with an opponents agent, the later is captured. If an agent gets on a space with a red dot, the player has to draw an assignment card. If he has captured another agent, he may chose to set him free and the released agent has to fulfill the assignment. Some assignments benefit or hinder the agent, others cause the player to take off his clothes or kiss his female assistant.

The first player to reach Montmartre with 2 agents and one captured agent wins the game.

—user summary
categories: Mature / Adult, Party Game, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition des stars – Série n°1
description: This is a card set expansion to Trivial Pursuit containing 50 cards with questions about stars from TV, movies, music and more.

name: Trivial Pursuit: Édition des stars – Série n°2
description: This is a card set expansion to Trivial Pursuit containing 50 cards with questions about stars from TV, movies, music and more.

name: Goblins and Gold
description:
Play as one of several dwarves who've stumbled across a goblin gold mine. Grab the gold and get out!
Goblins and Gold is a game about several dwarves who stumble into a goblin gold mine. The greedy dwarves must grab as much gold as they can carry and make it out of the mine alive. Players compete to steal as much gold from the goblins (and other players) as they can. Goblins and Gold is a dice rolling game with a subtle strategy behind every move you make. Players take turns laying down mine cards to build the mine. This means that players have control over where they want to place gold and goblins. It also means that the board is different every time you play the game! Each player controls their own dwarf, but all the players control the goblin horde and the powerful ogre. Players can play defensively, keeping the goblins away from themselves, or aggressively, pushing the horde towards their opponents. There's only one ogre, but if it hits your dwarf with an attack, instant game over! Use action cards to gain an edge on your opponents. Knock goblins off the board, steal gold from other players, and freeze the ogre in place until your next turn. Plan ahead and make sure you're the dwarf to survive.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Star Fleet Battles: Tournament Book 1991
description:
Revised tournament rules for 1991
12 tournament SSDs
108 tournament counters
108 ammunition counters
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Астронавтьi
description:
Астронавтьi (Astronauts) is soviet era space exploration game where players travel through the cosmos before returning to earth. The game dates from around 1970 determined by an image of a first generation Soyuz spacecraft (1967 - 1971) on the playing board.

Through the roll of the dice players first travel through the solar system before moving through the zodiac constellations. Certain numbered spots provide benefits or setbacks on their travel. Zodiacal cards are also obtained in specific constellation that also give or deduct points.

The winner of the game is the first to return to earth.

—user summary

name: Guffy
description: Guffy is a roll-and-write game similar to but pre-dating the more well-known Yahtzee, itself based on the public domain Yacht.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Second Chance: Election Reload
description:
A parody game of real-world presidency election of the USA.
The players compete to get most of the votes in order to step up to become the president.
Appeals to audience of the intriguing question on how the electoral system should work in a democratic setting
Focuses on inculcating virtues like integrity and fairness in a civilized world.
The players are expected to use treacherous approaches, throwing curve ball strategies to outrun others.

—description from the designer

name: Beyond the Stars: Alpha
description:
Beyond the Stars is a quick drafting game about exploring the galaxy. Amass your crew, gather resources, make discoveries, make contact with civilizations, fight monsters and face the unknown.
The game is meant to be played with 3-4 players and the goal is to acquire the most points by the end of the game. Every Crew Card will have a “play” rule set and a “keep” rule set. The “play” rule set will be relevant for rounds while the “keep” rule set will only come into play at the end of the game when calculating final points. The winner of the game is the player with the highest points after "play" and "keep" points are totaled.

—description from the designer

name: Flash Back 100
description:
Simple game of skill for 2 people. Players takes turns of placing a marble in a slot against a plunger and catapulting the ball along a curved ski ramp where the ball becomes airborne. If the correct force is applied the marble lands in a concentric scoring zone marked 30,20 or 10 points.

The object of the game is to exactly score 100 points. If the player goes over 100 points they must start again.

—user summary

name: Pennz Square Banko Game
description:
Pennz Square Banko Game is a Monopoly-like game based on the freewheeling banking practices of the defunct Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City. Game-play consists of spinning the large spinner in the center of the board, moving to the appropriate space, and following the instructions on the space.

Players start with $1,000,000 and ten assets, and the game is won by being the first player to reach a total of $50,000,000 in combined value of cash and assets.

Spaces can grant money, grant assets, and force loans on the player, which are drawn from a deck of cards. There are also spaces that reward you if you land on them while playing a specific character.

The game is entirely luck-based, as no negotiation or player input is possible. Players can also be eliminated; if a player lands on the Bank Regulator Foreclosure space, they must pay off all loans accrued; if they are unable, they are out of the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Drowned Earth: The Firm Fraction Starter Set
description:
Wherever you find a person willing to do a days work for a days living you can usually find someone else, plotting ways to take it from them. 
Some people call this survival of the fittest, but most of us have a different word for it: crime. 
The Firm are the gangsters and organised criminals of Ulaya. Protection racketeering, theft, robbery, banditry, the sale and supply of illicit substances and services: all of these things are their stock and trade. Violent brutality and ruthlessness permeate all that they do. 
The true extent of their power is not known, and few are brave or foolhardy enough to find out…

—description from the pulbisher
categories: Adventure, Dice, Fighting, Miniatures, Prehistoric, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Storytelling

name: Aujourd' Hui Dans L'Espace Un Voyage Dans La Lune
description:
Aujourd' Hui Dans L'Espace - Un Voyage Dans La Lune (Today in Space - A Journey into the Moon) is a 1960's French space game where players launch rockets into space to land on other worlds and then return them to earth (square 59).

The objective is to land 4 rockets on the moon, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn and return to earth first collecting points along the way.

The quirky thing about the game is how the rockets advance on the board. To advance a rocket, one adds the numbered square the rocket is on with the result from a roulette wheel spin. E.g If a rockets sits on square 6 and the roulette spin is a 2 they may advance to square 8. Problem is there is only 25 squares on the board so a player could remain on a spot if the number spun on the roulette wheel adds up to a number not found on the board. In addition, the numbered squares are either black or red, with red holding unpleasant surprises.

The winner is the player to return their rockets to earth and to have accumulated the highest number of points.

name: Moon Rocket Race Game
description:
The Moon Rocket Race Game is an English 1960's Space Race to the moon and back.

A coloured rocket is chosen to make a return moon trip. Movement of the playing pieces uses the 'Cosmic Enumerator', which is best described as a small sealed container that holds 4 coloured plastic balls that swirl around and the colour that stops in a central depression benefits that coloured rocket.

On the four corners of the playing board players assemble a nine stage rocket based on the colours called out from the 'Cosmic Enumerator'. The ninth stage is a plastic capsule that moves along a path to the moon in the middle of the board. The path is a series of holes and the capsule has a peg that sits in the holes. After getting to the moon the capsule returns to earth. Just before reaching earth a cardboard parachute is attached to the peg on the capsule to simulate splashdown. The winner is the first to get back

—user summary

name: Twinkle Twinkle the game of Stars
description:
Twinkle Twinkle the games of stars is a simple children's game from the 1930's with a celestial theme.

The game board consist of 40 coloured stars. Each star holds a same coloured peg. A spinner is central in the board and a player spins the arrow and removes a coloured peg indicated by the arrow. A white spot on the spinner results in players putting pegs back.

When all pegs are removed from the board, players count their pegs and the most pegs is the winner.

—user summary

name: Pun
description:
Components: 54 (2 × Alphabet/2 × Pun)

Object of the game

The object of the game is to form one or more words on your own hand. The score of a word results from the number of letters. Example: The word "GAME" consists of four letters and thus results in four points. The words "TURN" and "CARD" result in four plus four points, i.e. a total of eight points. The player with the most points on his hand wins.

Pun Rules

The starting order can be determined by lots. The player who draws the highest card in the alphabet begins. First, each player is dealt six cards face down. The remaining cards are dealt face down in the center as the deck. Three cards from the deck are dealt face up in the center. There must always be three cards in the center throughout the game.

Phase 1
The active player may swap an unlimited number of cards with the other players in the first phase. You may also exchange several cards for one.

Phase 2
The active player can then choose between these three options:
1. The player can swap one or more cards from the center with those in his hand and then end his turn.
2. The player can draw a card from the deck and end his turn. This option cannot be selected if there is no more card in the deck.
3. The player can end the round. This ends his turn. The round continues until all other players have completed their turn Now the points of each player are counted.

All words in the dictionary are allowed. Abbreviations and names are not allowed. Players can also agree to allow words in other languages or limit themselves to terms from a specific subject area (e.g. animals). The „Pun- card“ is the wild card and can represent any one of the 26 letters.

-description from designer

Pun Spielanleitung

Karten: 54 (2 × Alphabet/2 × Pun)

Anleitung: Deutsch und Englisch

Anzahl Spieler: 2–8

Altersgruppe: ab 6 Jahren

Autor: Bastian Ruhl

Ziel des Spiels

Ziel des Spiels ist es, ein Wort oder mehrere Wörter auf der eigenen Hand zu bilden. Die Punktzahl eines Wortes ergibt sich aus der Anzahl der Buchstaben (also jeder Buchstabe ist grundsätzlich gleich viel Wert). Beispiel: Das Wort „SPIEL“ besteht aus fünf Buchstaben und ergibt somit fünf Punkte. Die Wörter „ZUG“ und „KARTE“ ergeben drei und fünf Punkte, also insgesamt acht Punkte. Derjenige Spieler, der am Ende die meisten Punkte auf der Hand hat, gewinnt.

Finaler Sieger: Man kann danach Spielen wer nach einer bestimmten Anzahl an Runden die meisten Punkte hat oder wer der Sieger der meisten Runden ist.

Pun-Spielregeln

Wer anfängt, kann ausgelost werden. Der Mitspieler, der die höchste Karte im Alphabet zieht, beginnt. Zuerst bekommt jeder Spieler sechs Karten verdeckt ausgeteilt. Die restlichen Karten werden, als Stapel verdeckt, in die Mitte gelegt. Drei Karten vom Stapel werden offen in die Mitte gelegt. Während des gesamten Spiels müssen immer drei Karten in der Mitte liegen. Der Spielzug eines Spielers besteht aus zwei Phasen.

Phase 1

Der aktive Spieler darf in der ersten Phase mit den anderen Spielern unbegrenzt viele Karten tauschen (verbal und darf verdeckt oder offen stattfinden). Es dürfen auch mehrere Karten gegen eine getauscht werden (bis man selbst nicht mehr tauschen möchte oder die anderen Spieler nicht mehr tauschen möchten). Das Tauschen von Karten ist ein wichtiges strategisches Element und sollte nicht vernachlässigt werden.

Phase 2

Anschließend muss sich der aktive Spieler zwischen drei Möglichkeiten entscheiden:

1. Er kann eine oder mehrere Karten aus der Mitte mit denen auf seiner Hand tauschen und den Zug beenden.

2. Oder der Spieler kann eine Karte vom Stapel ziehen und den Zug beenden. Diese Option ist nicht wählbar, wenn keine Karte mehr im Stapel ist.

3. Der Spieler kann das Spiel beenden. Dadurch ist der Zug beendet. Das Spiel läuft noch eine Runde weiter und endet, sobald der Spieler, der es beendet hat, wieder am Zug wäre. Nun werden die Punkte gezählt.

Die Umlaute Ä, Ö, Ü werden durch AE, OE, UE gebildet und das ẞ durch SS. Alle im Duden stehenden Wörter sind erlaubt. Abkürzungen und Namen sind hingegen nicht gestattet. Die Spieler können sich aber auch darauf einigen, Wörter anderer Sprachen zu erlauben oder sich nur auf Begriffe aus einem bestimmten Themenfeld zu beschränken (z. B. Tiere) (siehe Spielmodus “Stadt, Land, Pun). Die Pun-Karte ist der Joker und kann einen der 26 Buchstaben vertreten.

Es können auch Karten aus dem Deck genommen werden (empfiehlt sich Q, X, Y rauszunehmen, wenn man nur einsprachig deutsch spielt).

name: Diwali
description:
The festival of lights is getting closer. You can breathe happiness in the streets, and at any corner, the emotion is contagious for the great moment coming. Players represent fireworks merchants, who like every year, take advantage of the festivity to offer to the curious and devout the fireworks that will give color and joy to the most colorful party of the year.

On your turn; You can expand your gunpowder factories, producing, open a stall in the market to sell your products and go out calling new customers. You have to keep an eye on what your competitors do; since each night, the scoring phase takes place and only those stalls that satisfy the demand of the clients, as well as those who can fill the sky with colors by shooting their fireworks, will score.

The game lasts 4 rounds and the player with the most points will be declared the winner.

Happy Diwali

—description from the designer

Se acerca la fiesta de las luces. Ya se respira alegria en las calles y en cualquier rincón la emoción se contagia para el gran momento que esta por llegar. Los jugadores representan mercaderes de fuegos artificiales, que, como cada año, aprovechan la festividad para ofrecer a los curiosos y devotos los fuegos artificiales que darán color y alegría a la fiesta más colorida del año.

En tu turno; podrás ampliar tus fabricas de pólvora, producir, abrir tus puestos en el mercado para vender tu producción y salir a captar nuevos clientes. Tienes que estar atento a lo que hacen tus competidores; pues cada noche tendrá lugar una fase de puntuación. Aquellos puestos que puedan satisfacer la demanda de los clientes asi como aquellos que llenen de colores el cielo con sus fuegos artificiales podrán puntuar.

Al cabo de 4 rondas, el jugador con mas puntos será declarado ganador.

Feliz Diwali.

—description from the designer (Spanish)

name: triiips
description:
triiips is a simple, elegant game played with 54 tiles, each with 3 properties… color, shape and fill.

With 3 tiles in your hand, play 1, 2 or 3 tiles to the grid. Any lines you create or extend must have at least one property which is the same on each tile or different on each tile.

Score 1 point for each tile in any line you create or extend on your turn. If a tile is part of 2 lines, count it twice. That is your base score for the turn.

Double it for playing at least one of 3 tiles in a row in which two properties are either the same on each tile or different on each tile.

Triple it for creating a triiip… 3 tiles in a row in which all three properties are either the same on each tile or different on each tile.

Multipliers compound so a well played turn can change things in a hurry.

—description from the designer

name: Cube Route
description:
The Dice routing game by Vantage Point.

Ages 9 through adult. 2 players or teams.
How you roll the dice cube really counts!
One roll backward... three left... two forward
the choice is yours.
The most strategic route wins the game!!

Object: The first player to move their six dice to the goal wins.
Strategy: Top number on die specifies how many spaces it may be moved (rolled) each turn. Select best routes to reach goal before opponent.

name: Big Time Horse Racing
description:
Six horse owners get together annually to race their best thoroughbreds – for a little money, but mainly for bragging rights. There are three races and three strict bets. The most money wins.

Unlike similar table-top games, in Big Time the luck element is minimized. Sure, you’ll have a “stable” of horses, but you won’t roll dice and check your horse card to see how far your steed goes. And you won’t spend your time making multiple bets on which horse will win the race, either. What you will do is focus on the race itself, and your share of the purse

Big Time Horse Racing is a thinking person’s game. The types of horses in a race, the length of the race, post position and how the race will be run are the important factors. On each turn, players will carefully choose a card to play from their hands – but only one card will determine the results which will apply to all the horses on the racetrack. Sometimes you’ll want your card to be chosen, and sometimes you won’t. Sometimes you’ll try to hinder other players instead of helping yourself. Sometimes you’ll benefit all horses of your type, and sometimes you’ll selfishly give yourself a bonus at the expense of those horses.

You’ll also have to decide when to hold your horse back, when to “make your move,” what to do in the turns, and even if you’ll hand the race to an opponent if you can’t finish in the money. There is betting, but it’s limited, and thought will be required here, too – if you want to win the day!

—description from the designer

name: Colonial Marines: Bug Hunt
description:
Colonial Marines: Bug Hunt is an intense cooperative combat game for 1-8 players. Each player portrays a grunt from a squad of colonial space marines that find themselves in repeated close encounters with classic sci-fi/horror xenomorphs. Missions range from simple get-out-alive or search-and-rescue, to elaborate multi-scenario campaigns.

Each player has a pool of colored dice based on his grunt's skills and attributes. He gains access to more dice and more colors as he levels-up. Players choose and roll dice from their pool, then take actions as allowed by those rolls. The xenomorphs move and attack automatically, triggered by those same dice. Play is simultaneous and in real-time, so the pace of the action can be intense and proceeds as quickly as players can roll and apply results!

Cards to buff each grunt add a dizzying variety of perks, special abilities, and hi-tech gear. But the hidden beauty of Colonial Marines: Bug Hunt is its innovative dice combat system that brings true wargame tactics to a genre dominated by entries that are rich in theme but light on strategy.

—description from the designer
categories: Dice, Miniatures, Print & Play, Real-time, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board, Role Playing, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: The Drowned Earth: The Artefacters Fraction Starter Set
description:
Treasure hunters, tomb robbers, adventurers, scavengers and rogues: an Artefacter cuts a glamorous, but undoubtedly nefarious, figure. Often dashing, brave to the point of recklessness, and willing to risk their life for personal gain. They can be found wandering the wilds for valuable artefacts from a bygone age, from which, they hope to become fabulously rich... 
However, there is more to these ambiguous figures than the mercenary opportunist image they project. Underneath the gloss of avarice and roguish indifference lies a secret… 
Few know the truth, but there are rumours that the Artefacters hold to a higher purpose. There are even whispers that they are agents of the ‘New Enlightenment’...

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Prehistoric, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Storytelling

name: Don't Get Me Started
description:
Don’t Get Me Started (DGMS) is a card game where players rant to get as much off their chest as they can.

Players take turns being the ‘hater’. Each round starts with the hater revealing the top rant card from the deck for everyone to see. Read aloud the topics if you’re playing with a large group. There are 3 connected topics on each rant card, ranging from easy to hard (in terms of hateability).

Players progress through different rounds and earn cards along the way. The player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

—description from the publisher

name: Rampage Rumble: A Wrestling Card Game
description:
Rampage Rumble is a wrestling card game for 2-6 players, ages 8+.

This Wrestling Match turned card game pits 2-6 players against each other in a battle to become the Rampage Rumble Champion!
A winner is crowned when he or she successfully defeats their opponent by hitting them with all sorts of sweet moves until their health has been depleted to zero, or until their mom calls and says it’s time to come home.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Take That, Team-Based Game

name: Doctor Who: Exterminate! The Miniatures Game – Draconians
description:
This expansion adds Draconians to Doctor Who: Exterminate! The expansion includes three miniatures, three Draconian faction cards, and three new adventure cards to expand the Doctor Who: Exterminate! universe.

—description from the publisher
categories: Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Enchanted Ruins
description:
The Enchanted Ruins, is a magical dungeon game.

The King of Alessia is dying and he has no heirs, so he will give the kingdom to the first hero that brings him and magical crytals from the Enchanted Ruins.

2 to 4 players will need to reach the center of the ruins and exit to become the winners, they will be building their path in the dungeon by placing rooms, these can be empty, contain traps, monsters and treasures, these rooms can be place upon their path or on the path of other players to make it more difficult to them to reach their goal.

This game uses a game mechanic called the RED GEMS, with this gems the players may cheat a little to achieve their goals, from simple adding to their die rolls in a combat, to replacing a room in the dungeon.

This is a fun and competitive play that will make your friends get angry with you, but remember a Kingdom is in play and everything is allowed.

—description from the designer

name: Tacticolor
description:
Tacticolor is a winning game. It draws its specificity from the mode of moving parts. The large cardboard triangles move by pivoting on one of their three edges. They can then cover another triangle, which amounts to blocking it momentarily.
The possibilities of departure, and therefore of different parts, are unlimited.
The players crossing each other in pairs will cover the opposite location of the playing area left free by the opponent. The winner is the first to have restored his starting figure portion.

—user summary
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Tile Placement

name: Écoute ce bruit…et trouve d'où il provient
description:
Players must recognize the sounds played by the audio cassette. It is also possible to play without the tape provided you mimic the sounds which gives a funny dimension to the game.

—user summary

name: Le grand jeu télé 7 jours
description:
This game refers to a French TV program magazine. Players embody a TV channel director who must compose the best program schedule with the most talented presenter ... while spending the least amount of money possible. They will be able to perform different actions after answering questions. The winner is the one whose grid earns the most points and who spent the least money.

—user summary

name: Telepatix
description:
Telepatix aims to test people’s way of thinking and see if they can connect and create puns, they will create puns using cards that contain only words that have multiple meanings.

In order to start the game you will need a minimum of 6 people to create to teams of 3 players.

Two players from one team will pick a card and try to create a logical sentence using only one word at a time in order to create their sentence. The third person has to guess the word on the card based on the sentence that his two team mates created.

The purpose of the game will be to guess as many cards as possible and to finish first.

—description from the designer

name: Śląsk 1939: San 1939 (Part I – Karpaty)
description:
The game is part of the W39 system and is an extension to the game Śląsk 1939. Maps connects togehther.

Game was published in 22 issue of "Taktyka i strategia" magazine. It uses W39 - Wrzesień 1939 rules.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Wielkopolska 1939
description:
The game is part of the W39 system and is an extension to the game Bzura 1939 and Pomorze 1939. Maps connects togehther.

Game was published in 13 issue of "Taktyka i strategia" magazine. It uses W39 - Wrzesień 1939 rules.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Wargame, World War II

name: Regular Expression cards
description: The theme of this game is regular expressions, a computer science/programming topic. Game play: Make a match pattern using RegExp cards and perform a pattern match against a target card. The player who successfully creates a match pattern gains one victory point. The goal is to gain 5 victory points.

name: Pavillon Noir!
description:
Pavillon Noir ! *Règles d'escarmouche pour Flibustiers* is a pirate skirmish miniature wargame. Fun, simple and originally published in French, in Vae Victis magazine issue #30.

The game uses a simple activation system (using 1d6) between players. Each activated figure has an agility value and weapons. It can perform 2 short actions, 1 long action or 1 "coup d'éclat". Actions can be move, fight, fire, throw stuff, destroy a door... or perform a "coup d'éclat" action (such as clinging a chandelier - 2d6 test using agility). Range combat is done by rolling 1d6 +/- modifiers. Combat is resolved by rolling 1d6 with modifiers (for fighters skill, armor, weapon types...). Moral test also uses 1d6

The game includes rules for ranged weapons, cover, morale.

Scale: 1 mini = 1 man, 1 cm = 1 m, a turn sequence = a few seconds

name: Tournament of Might
description:
Tournament of Might can be played by any number of players at the same time as long as each player has their own army. Each player starts with an army of 30 cards. The goal of the game is to score more Might than any of the other players.

Each army has 10 Hero cards and 20 Might cards. Might cards are the scoring cards and have values between 1 and 10. Hero cards affect which Might cards are scored in a round.

Hero cards are played in order from 1 to 4. Hero 1 cancels the effects of the other player’s Hero card. Hero 2 reduces the lowest Might card to 0. Hero 3 reduces the highest Might card to 0. Hero 4 reduces both Might cards to 0.

Each round is played by picking 1 Hero and 2 Might cards. After all Hero cards have been used, players score any Might cards remaining face up. After 10 rounds, all 30 cards in your army will have been used. Count up all scored Might cards. The player with the most Might is the winner.
categories: Card Game, World War II, Zombies

name: Deliverance From Beyond the Stars!
description:
Deliverance From Beyond the Stars! is a strategic game in Galaxy-Foundation Games' strategic Battle for Andromeda: Conflict for a Trillion Suns! series. It uses the series rulebook, Andromeda Foundation Official Battle Manual.

This game pits the Alliance System of Federated Worlds aka the United Systems of the Alliance Federation, along with their allies the Confederation of Thetan Republics, against the invading N'Dridd, which apparently are some kind of hive race. The rulebook claims that rules are provided to allow the former side to be split between an Alliance player and a Thetan player, but such rules do not actually appear.

The game-specific rulebook has lots of background material on the civilzations involved and their ships, plus rules for special units. It also devotes a lot of space to the special feature of this game in the series, which is that the N'Dridd player starts the game by randomly drawing numbered chits which determine their force composition and deployment. The players get points for accomplishing things and partway through the game is halted to assess points scored and current forces vis-a-vis the N'Dridd's starting chits; this determines what additional forces the N'Dridd gets for the remainder of the game.

From a GFG catalog (reproduced verbatim):


The game posits 6 Variable Options selected by the N'DRIDD player drawing "chits" (counters with numerical designations on them), the Federation “0B" is the same for all but each Chit dictates a specific quantity of N'Dridd "At Start Forces" and a potential follow-up of indeterminate size. The Alliance Player does not know whether to mass his ships in a broad "spread" to stop any small N'Dridd Scout Group and DESTROY IT before it can escape with Data that might "trigger" a huge Task Force or even a Horde. Then again, spreading them out may leave them dangerously exposed if the attack group is NOT a Scout Force but a Task Force that will devastate the Culture.

name: Gretchy & Lucky Mouse Card Game
description:
Object: Collect one mouse and three food cards, but watch out for cats and traps along the way! With a little luck, and some help from Gretchy your mouse will come out on top!

An easy to learn game that will take years to master! Gretchy is ideally suited for both children and adults.

—description from the publisher

name: CivGen: Generals at War
description:
CivGen is a board strategy game for 2, 3 or 4 players. The game contains board with hexes on which players are placing their buildings and military units. Buildings are producing resources, that are used for an empire development. Configuration of buildings and terrain give additional production bonuses. Each player is having a separate card deck with technologies, wonder, action, battle, war and bonus cards, split into eras. Government card determines player action points in round. Players are playing rounds until all players will pass and new turn starts. Players are playing cards to improve resource production, to be able to build better military units and to develop their civilization. There are General cards that have special abilities. General unit is giving bonuses to military units placed on board. When war starts military units are attacking in particular directions, starting from highest attack initiative. Each new turn an event card is taken that gives different bonuses or penalties to players. To resolve an event in some cases players need to roll dice. Players are producing culture points, that can be also obtained during war or from an event cards. Player with highest number of culture points wins.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hexagon Grid, Open Drafting, Tile Placement

name: Ancient Warfare Fast Play Rules: Rules for Wargaming Tactical Level Combat From 3000 BC - 450 AD
description:
Ancient Warfare (AW) is a set of miniature rules for wargaming tactical level combat for the period 1500 BC to 450 AD. These rules span over three thousand years and cover the earliest civilizations up to the fracturing of the Roman Empire to the point of eliminating their offensive strategic ability

The Fast Play rules are an outgrowth of the Ancient Warfare rules.

Ancient Warfare Fast Play Rules use miniature model soldiers on a table laid out with model terrain, along with dice, rulers and various markers designating orders, condition of units, casualties, etc.

name: Loot Boxer: The P&P Roll & Write Game of Epic Unboxing!
description:
Loot Boxer: The P&P Roll & Write Game of Epic Unboxing! challenges you to collect a legendary set of gear for your character by buying and opening loot boxes. The task sounds easy, but will the odds be in your favor?

A game of Loot Boxer will allow you to:


Collect common, rare, epic, and legendary items!
Equip the items on your character sheet to try and complete entire gear sets!
Sell the items you don't want to earn coins!
Buy new loot boxes of 6 different tiers! (Common, Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, and Diamond)


Plus, all you need is a handful of dice, pen, and paper!

Easy to learn, easy to play, but challenging to win!

SUGGESTION: To ensure replayability, you can print the game sheet and laminate it, so you may use an erasable marker instead of pencil and eraser.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Push Your Luck, Set Collection

name: Brytenwalda: Wargaming in the Age of Arthur
description:
Welcome to Brytenwalda, a ruleset which will allow you to recreate battles and raids during the so called British “Age of Arthur” and Saxon invasion. In Brytenwalda you'll impersonate a Chieftain during the Dark Ages, commanding his men in the defence of their homelands or looting and burning those belonging to your enemies.

There were many battles during the Dark Ages (specially in the British islands), but the armies used to be surprisingly small. The laws of King Ine who reigned between the 7th and 8th century provide a good frame of reference. A group of seven ravaging men are regarded as thieves, from seven to thirty-five is called a band and any any group larger than this is regarded as an army. Usually, an invading army arrived in just two or three ships, and even kings could be seen commanding armies no larger than three football teams.

Although the Dark Ages were an extremely violent era with a great number of battles and raids, but only a few were detailed in the chronicles, such as decisive pitch battles or those in which an important person died. Brytenwalda is focused on these kinds of battles which the modern wargamer would call a “skirmish”. While you wont be able to re-enact the Battle of Hastings in Brytenwalda, you'll have plenty of fun leading a band of Scot-Irish pirates, a group of raiding Saxons or a unit of Romano-British pedites patrolling the frontier.

Grab your lucky dice, gather your men, and get ready for battle!

—description from publisher

name: Boco
description:
Objective:
You win when you surround your opponent on every side of their colored space or spaces with your colored spaces. It is possible to tie in this game.

Playing the game:
Play begins with the first player selecting any triangle on the board. The next player must then select a space that shares a side (not tip) with the triangle that was selected. After the first triangle is selected each player alternates by selecting a single space (triangle, square or rectangle) that is connected to the side of any space already selected, whether it be your own, or your opponent’s space. Game ends when a player surrounds an opponent’s space, or spaces, on all sides.

name: Orbita Victaris
description:
Orbita Victaris is a tactical Science-Fiction/ Fantasy card game in which two or four players compete against each other on a shared battlefield.

VICTORY CONDITIONS
The player who has brought the shield points of his opponent to 0 wins or if the opponent can no longer draw cards (from his deck) or when a player gives up.

HOW TO PLAY
Each player starts with 6 shield points at the beginning of the game. These must be clearly visible to the opponentat all times (6-sided cube or by enclosed shield markers).

The maximum hand limit is 7. If a player has more than 7 cards in his hand at the end of their turn, they must place cards on their discard piles until the card limit is reached.

The card text always takes precedence over the rules in the rule book. This does not apply if the card text is incorrect.

Each turn consists of 5 phases, which are always traversed in this order of each move:

Start-phase:

In the initial phase, all effects that are activated by cards already in play at the beginning of the turn are resolved. The order in which the effects become active is determined by the active player. After all effects have been resolved with at the beginning, this phase ends and an action-event follows.

Draw-phase:

In this phase, the active player draws 1 card.

Recovering-phase:

All active player cards that are currently exausted (‘inactive’ on the side), with the exception of Nexus resources, are again recoverd (turned ‘active’ / upright).

Main-phase:

This phase represents the main part of a turn. In its main phase, a player may play cards from his hand, declare attacks, activate unit card effects on the field, or use his operator.

End-phase:

At the beginning of this phase, all effects are dealt with which explicitly occur at the end of the turn. This includes the removal of played command cards with the wording until the end of the turn. As in the initial phase, the active player, if relevant, determines the order of these steps. After that, the other player starts with his initial phase.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting, Science Fiction
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Cathracha
description:
Cathracha is a skirmish/adventure board game for 1-8 players. In this deckbuilding board game, you travel around the cities of the magical island Tir na nOg. Collect weapons, gems and other items to become the strongest druid. Go for an "all against each other" battle, using magical weapons and items to be the last man standing! You can also play solo or with your friends on multiple campaigns, learning the deeper lore of Cathracha and face your enemies with your group of heroes.
Movement is done with a D12 die. Players move around the board, gather cards and attack each other. Players lose when they have lost all life points.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Role Playing

name: Doctor Who: Exterminate! The Miniatures Game – Judoon
description: This expansion adds the Judoon to Doctor Who: Exterminate! The expansion includes three miniatures, 3 Judoon faction cards, and 3 new adventure cards to expand the Doctor Who: Exterminate! universe.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Doctor Who: Exterminate! The Miniatures Game – Zygons
description: This expansion adds Zygons to Doctor Who: Exterminate! The expansion includes two miniatures, three Zygon faction cards, and three new adventure cards to expand the Doctor Who: Exterminate! universe.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Doctor Who: Exterminate! The Miniatures Game – The Silence
description: This expansion adds the Silence to Doctor Who: Exterminate! The expansion includes three miniatures, three Silence faction cards, and three new adventure cards to expand the Doctor Who: Exterminate! universe.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Doctor Who: Exterminate! The Miniatures Game – Vashta Nerada
description: This expansion adds the Vashta Nerada to Doctor Who: Exterminate! The expansion includes three miniatures, a Vashta Nerada faction card, special rules for the Vashta Nerada, and three new adventure cards to expand the Doctor Who: Exterminate! universe.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Doctor Who: Exterminate! The Miniatures Game – Sea Devils
description: This expansion adds Sea Devils to Doctor Who: Exterminate! The expansion includes three miniatures, three Sea Devil faction cards, and three new adventure cards to expand the Doctor Who: Exterminate! universe.
categories: Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Bravely in their Battles! Hastings 1066 and Agincourt 1415
description:
Bravely in their Battles! is a moderately complex tabletop board game of Medieval Age pitched battles. Units are depicted with 2.5” wide playing pieces, and battles occur on an area grid map.

Terrain tiles allow the battlefields to be customized to match historical terrain. In addition, a number of smaller playing pieces represent leaders and various status effects that are placed on the map or units.

Hastings 1066 depicts the hard-fought battle between William, the Duke of Normandy, and English Saxon king Harold Godwinson on October 14th at Senlac Hill in southern England.

Agincourt 1415 depicts the annihilation of a large army of French men at arms by English King Henry V and his elite longbowmen on October 25th near Azincourt, France.

—description from the publisher

name: Make Some Noise!
description:
Make Some Noise! is the family friendly game of mimicry and mayhem.

Get your team to guess as many answers within 30 seconds by imitating the noises of animals, objects, sounds and famous characters.

—description from the designer

name: Dream Quest
description:
There is a land beyond the spheres known only to the most powerful Dreamers. It is a world of strange vistas, fantastical creatures, and inscrutable denizens. It is a land awash in mystery, and travellers there can become easily lost as the very ground around them shifts, changing the pathways and reforming the topography. But you have been drawn here on a quest for the greatest currency in any realm: knowledge.

In Dream Quest, Dreamers travel the Dreamlands as described by H.P. Lovecraft, attempting to complete legs of their journey, gathering knowledge and bartering for favours. Each time a Dreamer is Shaken, they move one step closer to consciousness, and expulsion from the game.

Using a map made of tiles and a hand of both Lore and Destination cards, players attempt to manipulate the map in a variety of ways in order to build continuous pathways. Doing so allows their dreamer to move to a destination, and gather knowledge. Connect multiple destinations for even greater learning. The first to reach the designated Knowledge goal is the winner, but be careful. As soon as any Dreamer wakes up, the game ends for everyone.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Line Drawing, Modular Board, Network and Route Building

name: Professor Prospector: Into the Important Cavern
description:
Professor Prospector is a 30 minute fast paced gemstone set collection card game that pairs historical facts about gemstones and 'Take That' game mechanics. Players compete against each other to be the first to collect 5 pairs of gems using action and upgrade cards that follow a mining theme. Action cards include pickaxes to take cards, torch lamps to see another player's hand, and more. Upgrade cards create status effects, such as Land Deed which increases the player's hand to 8 cards until discarded by the required action card. With 6 cards per hand, each turn players place down pairs to declare gems, use action or upgrade cards, and then draw to fill their hand.

—description from the designer

name: Blue Border
description:
In Blue Border, the players are divers who must play cards to dive to a certain depth, and then return to land. However, they must take care not to dive or come up too quickly.

The game centers around a deck of 32 cards, numbered 1 to 32 on the front, with various shades of blue on the back, corresponding to the number on the card.

On a player's turn, they can choose to play any one of five available cards to the next location in their dive, or can choose to pass. Players can only see the blue back side of the available cards. Once a player has determined a card to play, the other players may challenge that the card is within an acceptable range of cards to be played.

The first player to play 4 descending cards, reach a certain depth, and then 3 more cards to ascend, wins. The rules state that the other players should provide generous applause for the winner.

name: Invasion TCG
description:
Invasion TCG is a fantasy trading card game with no rotation, no vanilla creatures, and no system of mana screw or flood.

A tranquil peace has reigned over the plains of Arazineth for generations, but in the darkness, unseen by all, a fire burns. For in the darkness stirs Hurtheri’s once vanquished legion of dragons. Hellbent on claiming what is rightfully hers, she will lead them to reclaim it, whatever the cost. Will you defend the city, or will you side with the fury set to destroy it?

Players begin the game with 20 life points and 20 cards in their customised deck. Each player takes it in turns to play, taking the following actions:

a) Draw two cards from their deck to start their turn
b) Play creature cards or spell cards
c) Discard a card from their hand and draw a new card from their deck
d) Attack their opponent's life points using their creatures
e) Trigger any card effects they have already out on the field of play
f) Pass the turn to their opponent

Players can elect to take the above actions in any order they wish, or not at all. However, drawing two cards from their deck at the start of a player's turn is mandatory, as it passing the turn to their opponent once they have finished all actions they wish to take.

Players win the game by using their creatures to attack their opponent's life points, reducing them from 20 to 0.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Dice, Fantasy
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Equip: Battle, Collect Credits, and Buy Cards!
description:
A player vs. player card game, Equip is all about building your team, collecting credits, and buying cards. Collecting hero cards, special cards, powering up your cards, and building your team, you battle each other through a best-of-three contest, throwing a coin and rolling a dice in order to collect credits you can use to buy cards.

The game includes 13 Hero Cards, 12 Special Cards, 10 Equip Cards, and 11 Mix Hero Cards. In the set, there are also 1 Zupper Coin, 1 dice, 1 Zupper Shop, 1 Play Mat, 2 Player Cards, 4 Battle Cards, 1 Backer Card, 1 Cursor, and a set of Credit Tickets.

—description from the publisher

name: The Battles of Borodino & Polotsk 1812
description:
Borodino
7 September 1812 was the single bloodiest day of the Napoleonic Wars.

The Russian forces which, since June, had retreated eastwards in front of Napoleon’s advancing Grande Armee at last made their stand at the village of Borodino on the road to Moscow. Their newly appointed commander, Mikhail Kutuzov, had chosen his ground wisely. The marshy and wooded terrain around the village favoured the defender and Kutuzov strengthened his position still further by fortifying many of the natural obstacles. Here the Russians waited.

Far from friendly territory, short of supplies, and with Winter approaching, Napoleon had little choice but to attack in order to open the way to the relative safety of Moscow. A series of frontal attacks by both sides resulted in an orgy of slaughter. The fighting involved around 250,000 troops and nearly 70,000 were left on the battlefield.

Both armies suffered terribly; but, it was the Russians who left the field and the way open for the Grande Armee to march on to Moscow. Too exhausted to follow their beaten foe, nearly week was to pass before the leading units entered the city. The victory proved to be pyrrhic. The Russian Tsar Alexander had no intention of suing for peace; but, instead waited for Winter to come to his aid. With supplies running out and the weather worsening, the Grande Armee evacuated the city in October. So began the famous retreat from Moscow.

The Battle of Borodino is a tactical level two player game covering this bloodiest of battles. One player takes the role of Napoleon, commanding the Grande Armee, and the other of Kutusov leading the Russians. The battle is a source of great debate amongst historians, and players have the opportunity to try some of the options available to both commanders. For example, had Napoleon committed his Imperial Guard, the only significant unit on the battlefield that remained in reserve, or had he heeded the advice of Marshal Davout to try to out-flank the Russian position, might he have succeeded in destroying the Russian army and winning not only the battle, but the entire war?

The First Battle of Polotsk

This relatively little-known battle, which took place on 17 August 1812, was one of the most significant of Napoleon’s invasion of Russia. Leading the majority of his Grande Armee ever eastwards, Napoleon had reached Smolensk. He had assigned Marshal Oudinot, commander of the II Corps, to protect his northern flank and to test the strength of the Russian forces defending the road to St Petersburg, the Russian capital. It transpired that these comprised only a single Corps, perhaps 25,000 men, commanded by General Wittgenstein. Impatient with Oudinot for failing to attack Wittgenstein, Napoleon dispatched St. Cyr's VI Corps to reinforce II Corps, bringing its strength up to about 32,000 men. The aim was to defeat the Russians and, if possible, threaten St Petersburg.

Faulty intelligence lead Oudinot to believe that Wittgenstein was too weak to mount an attack and so split his forces to making it easier for them to forage.
