He deployed II Corps on the southern bank and VI Corps on the northern bank of the River Dvna. Wittgenstein recognised that this left VI Corps, the weaker of the two, particularly vulnerable. The Russians attacked and heavy fighting ensued; but, the VI Corps fought bravely and held their position. Towards the end of the first day’s fighting Marshal Oudinot was seriously wounded and command of both Corps passed to St. Cyr. The second day saw St. Cyr take the initiative. By feigning a retreat he was able to mislead Wittgenstein and suddenly launch a furious attack against the Russian centre and left flank. Just as defeat seemed inevitable, Wittgenstein ordered his cavalry to counterattack. They cut through the advancing enemy units only to be thrown back in confusion by French Cuirassiers.

At this point, both sides were exhausted and had suffered heavy casualties. Each withdrew to a defensible position where they remained, watching each other, for the next two months until Napoleon’s retreat from Moscow saw his northern flank again become the scene of desperate fighting.

Although tactically it was a French victory, in strategic terms the First battle of Polotsk was a draw. Nonetheless, the strategic significance of the battle was immense. With his northern flank no longer threatened Napoleon was able to continue his advance upon Moscow. A grateful Emperor rewarded St-Cyr with a marshal’s baton. The Russian Tsar Alexander was similarly grateful to Wittgenstein. The threat to St Petersburg had been nullified. He awarded Wittgenstein the Order of St George and conferred upon him the title of "Saviour of St Petersburg".

The First Battle of Polotsk is a tactical level two player game covering this strategically significant engagement. One player takes the role of Oudinot, commanding two Corps of the Grande Armee, and the other of Wittgenstein leading the Russians. There is a range of options open to both players to see if they can achieve the decisive and strategically decisive victory which eluded their historical counterparts.

SHS Games

The Seven Hex System (SHS) derives its name from the map which is divided into areas comprised of seven hexes which enables the player to adopt various positions within an area to reflect different tactical formations thereby making it more likely that an attack will succeed or defending units will stand firm. The SHS incorporates several unique features intended to replicate in a simple and intuitive way the options available to a commander (the wargamer) of a large army. So whilst the commander has complete freedom to devise a plan, and a good deal when positioning units which have yet to encounter the enemy, once battle is joined the options become increasingly limited and unforeseen events can play a part in determining the outcome. Nonetheless, even at a tactical level a commander's decisions are crucial in shaping events. The key to success is a sound plan with a margin for error which allows for ill-fortune, the shrewd deployment of units so as to be able to implement that plan, and the timely commitment of reserves.

-description from publisher

name: The Battles of Kliszow 1702 and Fraustadt 1706
description:
Kliszow
The Battle of Kliszow is a tactical level two player game covering this important engagement during the Great Northern War. One player takes the role of King Charles XII leading his Swedish troops, and the other of Augustus the Strong commanding a Saxon-Polish-Lithuanian army. This is a classic example of a small well-trained and highly motivated army taking on a larger force in a strong defensive position. Victory will go to the player who is best able to exploit the advantages available to him.

Earlier in War, the Swedes had repulsed attacks on their empire by the Danes, Russians and Poles and had now taken the offensive by invading the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. After occupying Warsaw, Charles marched west with the aim of defeating Augustus decisively. On 19 July 1702 the two armies were camped only five miles apart. However, they were separated by a large wood and a swamp. The latter shielded Augustus’ camp to the north whilst his left flank was protected by the River Nida. Undeterred by this, and by the fact that his army of 12,000 was outnumbered, maybe by as much as two-to-one, by the Saxon-Polish-Lithuanians, Charles advanced through the woods abandoning most of his guns during the march.

In an effort to secure a decisive victory, Charles’ strategy was envelope the enemy army. However, this plan was disrupted when the commander of the assault on the Saxon-Polish-Lithuanian right flank was killed and the advance halted. The Poles then counter-attacked, but were beaten back by the Swedish infantry, as was an attack by the Saxons across the marsh which separated the centre of the two armies. For reasons which are not entirely clear, the Poles then abandoned Augustus leaving the field and exposing his right flank. Even though Augustus still had the larger army, it was now badly unbalanced and the Swedes immediately began to roll up his right flank. In the chaos that followed, Charles was able to capture most of the enemy’s artillery and to turn these guns upon the Saxon-Polish-Lithuanians. However, fierce resistance by Saxon units in the centre and on the left flank allowed most Saxon-Polish-Lithuanian units to withdraw.

It was certainly a victory, but not the decisive victory for which Charles had been hoping.

Fraustadt

This battle between a Swedish army commanded by General Rehnsköld and a Saxon-Polish-Russian force lead by General Schulenburg took place on 13 February 1706. It has been described as the “Swedish Cannae” because the Swedish cavalry carried out a double envelopment, encircling the enemy and bringing about a decisive victory reminiscent of Hannibal’s success nearly 2,000 years previously. For the loss of only 400 men, the Swedes inflicted 7,000 casualties upon the Saxon-Polish-Russians and captured a similar number.

Prior to the battle, King Charles XII was contemplating recalling his over-stretched forces from Poland. Indeed, in the lead up to the battle Rehnskold deliberately gave the impression that the Swedes were withdrawing by retreating his 10,000 men towards Fraustadt. This ploy was successful in luring Schlenburg, at the head of 20,000 men, away from a very strong defensive position to pursue the Swedes. With the two armies now facing each other the Swedish cavalry launched repeated attacks on both flanks, eventually routing the enemy cavalry stationed on each. They then wheeled to attack the rear of the Saxon-Polish-Russian infantry, with devastating results. At the same time the Swedish infantry began moving forward to assault Schulenburg’s forces from the front, thereby completing the encirclement. Although the Saxon-Polish-Russian right flank held for a while, under this intense pressure the army soon broke and those who were unable to flee surrendered en mass.

In terms of Sweden’s campaign in Poland, the Battle of Fraustadt had snatched victory from the jaws of defeat. Rather than abandoning their campaign, the Swedes had become the dominant military power in the region. Before the year was over Saxony would sue for peace.

Rehnskold had little option but to risk battle with Schlenburg’s superior forces for fear that the odds would be tipped even further against him should Augustus the Strong, commanding 8,000 Saxons, join with Schlenburg. Augustus was only a few days’ march away from Fraustadt. In addition to the standard game, there is a “what if” scenario which envisages his arrival on 13 February 1706.


SHS Games

The Seven Hex System (SHS) derives its name from the map which is divided into areas comprised of seven hexes which enables the player to adopt various positions within an area to reflect different tactical formations thereby making it more likely that an attack will succeed or defending units will stand firm. The SHS incorporates several unique features intended to replicate in a simple and intuitive way the options available to a commander (the wargamer) of a large army. So whilst the commander has complete freedom to devise a plan, and a good deal when positioning units which have yet to encounter the enemy, once battle is joined the options become increasingly limited and unforeseen events can play a part in determining the outcome. Nonetheless, even at a tactical level a commander's decisions are crucial in shaping events. The key to success is a sound plan with a margin for error which allows for ill-fortune, the shrewd deployment of units so as to be able to implement that plan, and the timely commitment of reserves.

-description from publisher

name: Frozen Wings
description:
Frozen Wings is the third Volume dedicated to the air struggles between the Italian Regia Aeronautica with its MC200 Saetta and BR20 Cicogna against the Voyenno-Vozdushnye Sily (the Soviet Air Force), with its I-16 and YAK1 in the early stages of the invasion of the Soviet Union.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: Stukas over Malta
description:
The fifth Scenario of the new game The propeller rotates and the engine roars simulating the actions of the Italian Royal Air Force (la Regia Aeronautica) during the II World War.

This Volume is again about the air battles over the sky of Malta but this time the Luftwaffe has arrived! Now the mighty JU87 Stuka will try to bomb the valiant fortress, defended by the first Spitfires... but beware of the Bf109 and the Italian fighters!

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Wargame, World War II

name: London 1980: Operation NIMROD
description:
London 1982 (sic) is a solitaire war game depicting the action, called Operation Nimrod, performed by SAS, one of the first British Special Forces, in the Iranian Embassy in London on May 5th 1980, where a group of terrorists had kept for 6 days several hostages. A daring operation, which was a success with the liberation of the hostages and the elimination of the terrorists, who were linked to the Democratic Revolutionary Front for the Liberation of Arabistan, a Iraqi backed separatist movement of the Khuzestan Iranian area.

81 fantastic counters, a gorgeous A3 map and English rules... you just need two d6!!!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Monster Knights: A 2-Bit Monster Hunting Card Game
description:
The small village of Vonsterwald was once a bustling tourist attraction, but since monsters from the nearby forests began showing up at night they have scared almost everyone away. The ones that remain have called on you and your fellow Monster Knights to rid the countryside of the monsters. Will you survive the night, save their village, and become the 2-bit monster hunter of legend?

In Monster Knights: A 2-Bit Monster Hunting Card Game, players take on the roles of monster hunters who have been tasked by the locals of Vonsterwald to save their village from the nightly attacks by legendary monsters the Swamp Monster, the Wolf Monster, the Vampire Monster, and Frankenmonster. To do that, players must work together to heal the Monster Hunters when they take wounds, to move the Monster Hunters around the village, and to use the Monster Hunters to attack the monsters they encounter with crossbows, silver bullet guns, holy relics, and torches. Each monster has a weakness to a certain weapon, which causes more damage to that particular monster. If a location is destroyed, the players lose. If a Monster Hunter dies, the players lose. Only by getting rid of all the monsters will the players win.

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Point to Point Movement

name: Space Jackers: A 2-Bit Space Western Card Game
description:
In Space Jackers: A 2-Bit Space Western Card Game, players are trying to escape the giant evil space station by making their way through the station and get to their ship, the Centennial Pigeon. To do that, players must draft a team of Rebel cards and use their skills to overcome the various obstacles they encounter to make a path to the ship. The first player to get all 4 of their tokens to the ship wins!

—description from the designer

name: Kooky Mansion
description:
Kooky Mansion is a light-hearted loot collecting/scoring card game for 2-4 players. The goal is very simple: be the first player to score 30 points worth of loot. To do that, players must enter the Kooky Mansion either through the Basement OR through the Roof, move up and down the various floors to collect the loot, and then get out of the mansion with the loot to score points. Sounds easy, right? Be warned, the mansion is guarded by a highly intelligent mad scientist, a highly indestructible robot, and a highly insecure sentient alien tentacle all of which can also be moved up and down floors to capture any intruders they encounter! If the players are caught, they are escorted from the mansion and any loot they had collected is lost (scored loot can never be lost). The mansion is full of secret passages that the players can use to avoid the guards and move more quickly up and down floors. Can you avoid capture, snag the loot, and escape the mansion to become the first player to score 30 points?

-description from designer

name: Folding Space: Gathering of Friends Infinity Board Promo
description: Each player has a unique folding infinity board. This is an additional board to use as a substitute for one the standard boards in the game.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Pirates, Science Fiction
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Modular Board, Set Collection, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Mad Dog
description:
Steal his bones, if you dare! Draw a card to find out how many bones you have to steal from Mad Dog. Carefully take the bones from his bowl as he sleeps - listen for his snores and don’t wake him up! If you get caught, he’ll get MAD! You lose if you get caught!

—description from the publisher

name: Matching Tails
description:
The players switch the cards and observe, to unit the animals with its correct rear end. In the second game version the players will nead a good understanding of the number range 1-10 and match everything correctly.

—description from the designer
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Math

name: Star Gazers
description:
Spot stars in the night sky and work to create constellations on your board using rubber bands and star pieces before other star gazers do.

—description from the designer

name: Touchdown a Scientific Football Game
description:
The board depicts a football field. It has a sliding marker for the ball, and another for the ten yards. Also included on the board are charts that show outcomes based on the throw of three dice. The offensive player calls a play, rolls the dice, and then refers to the chart for the outcome. In some cases there is another dice roll: if a pass is complete, another roll shows the yardage gained. If the play is a punt, the other player rolls the dice to see how many yards back they run, and so on. The outcomes were designed to be statistically similar to the games of the time.

—user summary

name: TV Show: Nadine Seul promo character
description:
This card is offered with the magazine Asmomag (#2, February 2019). It represents Nadine Seul, commissioner of the Festival international des jeux (FIJ, Cannes) for more than thirty years, until 2019.
Works like any other card and is just added to the other characters.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Elemental Conflux: Spirit Expansion
description:
Elemental Conflux's first Expansion, Spirit adds 13 new creature cards and 2 new spell cards to your deck.

Adding the SPIRIT expansion to your games is easy. Simply shuffle the new creatures into your creature deck, and shuffle the new spell cards into the spell deck.

The Spirit Expansion is a powerful new set of cards, as the SPIRIT element does not have an opposition, and the creatures of SPIRIT only account for a fifth of the entire creatures deck.

Be aware that all of the new creatures (yes, ALL!) have a special ability, and you should read the creature cards carefully when they are revealed in combat.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Elemental Conflux: BRIMLEY Promo card
description:
Brimley, Pointy Hat Games' adorable mascot, has his very own creature card for Elemental Conflux!

Brimley is given life by the spirits of long-dead wizards that have worn him, and in battle he'll pass those powerful abilities on to whomever wears him.

This is a promotional card that comes with the purchase of the BRIMLEY plush toy.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy

name: Leaving Ground
description:
Say goodbye to Earth. The race is on to colonize Venus.

Inspired on the one hit wonder song The Final Countdown by Europe.

In our third month of one hit wonders, we have a game inspired by The Final Countdown, which 100% makes me think of Gob Bluth from Arrested Development. In this game, you will try to get all cards from 10-A then claim "It's the final countdown!" to win. There's a little press your luck, and some fun face-card powers, as well as the ongoing tradition of great starting player rules.

—description from the publisher


Leaving Ground is a trick-taking game played with a regular deck of cards, in which players attempt to complete a countdown to launch their rockets by assembling a run from 10 to A (of any suit); winning a trick doesn't award all cards played, but gives a powerful bonus that can give an edge over your competition. Face cards, while not contributing to your countdown, have special abilities that can be used to affect gameplay -- perhaps just what you need to eke out a win!

—description from the publisher


Delivered on Board Game of the Month Club March 2017 package.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play, Science Fiction

name: Connais-tu ton corps?
description:
A game to learn to say and identify all part of human body.

A player draws a word card of his choice and places a token on the body part indicated by the card and keeps the card. The following players do the same. Continue until all the chips are placed. When all the chips are placed on the right part of the body. Each well placed token is worth 1 point. The game continues until the word cards are exhausted. The winner is the one with the most points.

—user summary

name: The Drowned Earth: The Militia Fraction Starter Set
description:
In a world full of terrifying dangers, independent settlements are particularly vulnerable to attack. Without any sort of formal defence force it often falls on communities to organise protection amongst themselves. The bravest and most proficient citizens form a volunteer force of enthusiastic amateurs, who serve as much time as they can, protecting others against the many dangers which their community face. 

These are the Militias: patrolling the nearby countryside, maintaining fortifications and defending their way of life against all those who threaten them.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Dice, Fighting, Miniatures, Prehistoric, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Simulation, Storytelling

name: Alsace and co
description:
Alsace & co is a game of general culture. The players progress on the board and can fall on 3 different types of boxes. These boxes will allow them to answer a question about the Alsace region, take up a challenge or undergo an event. At each success, the player progresses. Whoever reaches the end of the course first wins.

—user summary

name: Wilde Tiere
description:
Wilde Tiere is a simple game for the little ones. Each player chooses an animal composed of 6 pieces of cardboard. In turn, each player will roll the dice and choose the piece of his animal that matches the number of the die. If the piece has already been chosen, it passes its turn. The player assembles as and when the cardboard pieces. The first to finish assembling his animal in 3D wins.

—user summary

name: Yu Yu Hakusho: Ghost Files CCG
description: The Yu Yu Hakusho: Ghost Files CCG is based on the Yu Yu Hakusho anime and part of Jasco Games' UFS game system.

name: The REDeX Trial Game
description:
Roll-and-move game played on a 100-space track around the perimeter of a map of Australia. Some spaces have bonuses or penalties for landing on them. Rules are printed on the mounted folding gameboard. Gameboard features red, white and black cartoon artwork. The game commemorates the 16,000km round-Australia Redex Reliability Trial automobile races of 1953, 1954 & 1955, sponsored by the REDeX brand of oil additive.

—description from the publisher

name: Phinacci
description:
Nature’s Card Game: The magic of nature’s patterns can be written in the language of numbers. The Phinacci game has taken that numbering pattern and made a card game out of it.

How to Play: You have two teams, four players, 53 cards, and 144 points needed to win the game. The object is to be the first team to reach 144 points. Each card taken in a pile counts as one point. Teams capture cards in a pile by matching the pile value with the card they throw down onto the pile. There are two groups of cards; colored cards with black numbers and black cards with white numbers. The colored cards are used only in subtracting the number that is on the card from the value of the pile, and the black cards can be used to either add or subtract the number on the card from the pile. If a player does not match the value on the pile then players continue going clockwise to lay down a card until the value is matched. The pile value changes each time a card is placed on the pile. The team (lead team) who lays down the first card of the hand has the advantage of either matching or exceeding the number value on the pile to take it, where as the other team must match the pile value exactly. If neither team has the cards to match or go over (lead team) the value on the pile then the cards go to the (non-lead team), and they become the lead team on the next round. There will be times when a player is unable to place a card and they are skipped to the next player. There will also be times when a player will run out of cards before the other players do.

An example of play: The deck is shuffled and dealt to all four players with one extra card going into the middle face up.Let’s say the extra card is a colored ‘1’. Team A (lead team) easily takes it by throwing a ‘colored 1’ card on top of it. Any card they throw down will take it because all they have to do is match or exceed the pile value. Because there were two cards in the pile they receive two points for their team. The player that takes the pile gets to lead out. Now let’s say the player who took the pile leads out with an ‘8’ card. The player on the left, Team B (non-lead team) member can place an 8 down if they have one and take the pile of two cards to collect two points, or let’s say they choose to throw down a ‘colored 1’ card which subtracts from the existing ‘8’ making the pile value 7. The next person on the left is a member of Team A cannot match that pile number, because there are no ‘7’ in the deck, but because they are the Lead Team they can use an ‘8’ or larger card to take the pile, but it would only be three cards. Let’s say instead they decide to throw down a colored ‘1’ card. Now the pile value is 6 with four cards in the pile. Now let’s say Team B throws down a colored ‘2’ to bring it down to a value of 4. Again there are no ‘4’ cards and the lead team has to either use a ‘5’ card or larger to take it. Let’s say Team A throws down a black ‘5’ and chooses to use that ‘5’ to add to the pile instead of subtracting. Now the pile value is 9 and again there are no ‘9’ cards in the deck, so Team B will be unable to take the pile at this point. Let’s say they throw down an ‘8’ card bringing the pile value to 1. Team A decides to take the pile with a colored ‘1’, thus gaining 7 more point from this pile.. The hand will continued to be played until either all the cards are used up, or nobody is able to play a card. At that point the cards are reshuffled and dealt out with the team taking the last pile leading off. Team B’s strategy is to keep the pile value so high that the other team will not be able to match or exceed its value, thus giving them the pile and becoming the lead team for the next round.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Pattern Recognition, Team-Based Game

name: War Cans
description:
Wars Cans is a multidimensional strategy game where your pieces move based on their composition. Whoever is at the top of a stack controls the entire stack. The game is over when only one player is able to move. Each game is unique as the board layout is randomized and evolves as the game goes on.

Objective: To keep your opponent from moving.

Setup: Each player starts with 8 pieces placed on the board as shown below.

Board: The board is made up of 40 black squares overlaid with 40 green tile squares as shown above. Pieces can move across black squares, but can never land on them. Green tiles are removed from the board when a piece or stack of pieces moves off the green tile. A black square is exposed when a green tile is removed. Each black square counts as a move when passing over the square. Below are two examples of green tiles that have been removed in some opening moves.

Pieces: A single piece can move one space in any direction,as long as it doesn’t land on a black square. Pieces can land on other pieces, both their own and their opponent’s. When one piece combines with another piece, whether it be their own, or an opponent’s piece it gains the ability to move another space in any direction. Every piece in a stack enables the stack to move that number of spaces. For instance, if a stack has 3 pieces it can move 3 spaces as shown in the figure below. Pieces must always move in a straight line.

Capturing and Releasing: When a piece is placed on top of an opponent’s piece or stack that piece, or stack belongs to the one with their piece on top of the stack. If a the top piece of a stack is moved from the stack and the piece on the top of the remaining stack is the opponent’s then the stack goes to the opponent. Below are two showing a before and after example of a player capturing another player’s pieces.

Winning: When a player is unable to move the game is over and the one who made the last move wins. Below is an example of a game played out with black winning.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Pattern Recognition, Take That

name: Wrestling Cubes
description:
Last Move Wins!

Making the last move is how you win this game. Each player has six cubes that can slide, push and spin. Each cube starts out with the ability to move in three different directions; horizontally, vertically or diagonally. All 12 cubes will remain on the board throughout the game whether they are able to move or not. Cubes must always move in a straight line and cannot pass another cube diagonally if that cube’s side comes in contact. A cube may not jump over another cube, or land on top of another cube. A cube loses a direction of movement as indicated by colored triangle when a cube from the other player is pushed into it. It is possible to engage more than one cube at a time. Cubes without colored triangles are considered dead and are unable to move on their own, though it can be pushed by other cubes. Cubes can push other cubes, both their own or their opponent, but for this to happen there must be more triangles pointing in the direction of the push than there are triangles opposed to the push. If two cubes have opposing triangles that point into each other, they cancel each other out and there is no push either way. Cubes may not pull another cube. Cubes can only move forward in the direction of the 90 degree triangles. Triangles can turn a round when they reach the three gray squares at each end, and can move back and forth from those gray squares. When a player runs out of moves the game is over.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement

name: King's Traverse
description:
Object of the game:
The object is to capture your opponent’s four kings. What might feel like an advanced form of checkers will surprise you in its complexity of moves and strategy. It requires a nimble mind and the forward thinking of a chess player. Be alert because the balance of power can shift very quickly in this game.

Game basics:
Each player starts out with 4 kings and 13 squires. Kings must always stay on white squares and squires must always stay on brown squares. Only squires can capture kings and only kings can capture squires. Capture happens when a king or squire moves into an adjacent space that shares the same sides. Both kings and squires can jump forward if they have a piece to jump over. They can jump over their own pieces or their opponent’s pieces, or a combination of both. When a player’s king or squire reaches the opponent’s side of the board their king changes into an emperor or their squire changes into a knight. These changes give the pieces enhanced abilities to move. It is possible to reach the opposite side of the board in one jump, or a combination of multiple jumps in a single turn.

Examples of moves:

A silver squire moves into an adjacent space to capture an emperor. Squires must always move a forward motion and cannot move sideways.
A silver squire jumps over an opponent’s squire and king to capture the king. Bridges can be formed from both a players pieces and an opponent’s pieces.
A silver king makes multiple jumps to reach the opponent’s side and change into an emperor and capture two silver squires. Capture only happens at the final resting point and not at each junction where a piece launches from one jumping point to the next.
A silver king traverses across two spaces to capture four gold squires. Kings, emperors and knights can traverse (go sideways) as long as there is not another piece blocking its path. A piece cannot jump over or go around pieces when traversing.
A gold squire makes two jumps to become a knight and capture two silver kings.
A silver knight traverses three spaces to capture two gold kings. When a squires changes into a knight it gains the ability to traverse and move forward or backwards. When a king changes into an emperor it can also move forward or backwards, but it also has the ability to jump to the next row of white spaces without needing a bridge.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement

name: MillennialToons
description:
MillennialToons can be described as a nostalgic charades infused with some aspects of Taboo. Players take turns describing a movie or TV show on a drawn card to their partners without using the words or phrases on the card. Players must first draw a white challenge card to set the rules for the round. The opposing partners watch a timer to stop the game and switch players. Cards are disqualified if a player uses the words on the drawn black card. The describing team gets a point for each card they guess successfully and the opposing team gets a point for each card they pass on. An excellent party game for nostalgic Toonheads!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia, Word Game

name: Forsaken Gods
description:
The Old Gods have been vanquished. The kingdom is in utter turmoil. Without them, there are no laws, no balance in the world... no protection from evil.

The Forsaken Gods were banished thousands of years ago - they sat in isolation, in darkness, just waiting for a chance to break free.

That time has finally come.

Forsaken Gods is an expandable card game which is set in an apocalyptic fantasy world. In Forsaken Gods, you control three distinct Kingdoms, known as "Lanes". Each God demands it's own unique tribute, so you must choose which God's "Shrine" to build in each of your Lanes on each of your turns.

Devotion doesn't go unnoticed - each God has a unique "God Power" that players can activate each turn should they have the correct devotion.

The first player to win two out of three of their lanes by reducing their opponent's life to zero wins the game!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Storm Over Europe
description:
Storm Over Europe is a grand strategic game, that recreates the entire European conflict during the Second World War. Designed with wooden pieces are used to depict resources, that depending on placement, represent air, land, and sea units.

Play the entire war, starting from January 1939 to the bitter end of Spring 1945 or later, can be played in 4-6 hours for a scenario and 10-15 hours for a the full campaign. No hexes, no counters, and low luck.

The map board employs area movement over land regions but the low unit density allows players to realize the full impact of mobile warfare and appreciate the daunting size of Mother Russia without slowing gameplay unnecessarily. A unique front-reserve combat system allows for operational level details like blitzes, assaults, encirclements, feints, static defense, and defense in depth which are normally lost in grand-strategic simulations.

Units are rated by movement, but attrition, assault, and blitz strength. Elite units are created by combat experience, events, and tech research - introducing an extra dimension as units are upgraded and downgraded throughout the war, reflecting varying levels of experience, training, leadership, and technology.

Production: Storm Over Europe goes beyond the standard model of linking military production to a GDP estimate. Nations must mobilize to achieve full wartime production but it takes much more to wage war than just massive production lines. Manpower, oil, steel, and even trained pilots are all tracked without ANY bookkeeping through an innovative system of collecting resources as strategy cards are played. Resources are consumed by prolonged offensives so logistics plays just as much a factor as unit strength.

Strategy Cards: Storm Over Europe is a card driven game (i.e. Paths of Glory). Events introduce historical and political events in a realistic fashion while eliminating scripting and "look up" rules. There is a tangible cause-effect relationship to every event and nothing occurs in a seemingly random or ahistorical manner. Players play the cards - the cards don't play the players. Most importantly, the core mechanic of tough gut wrenching decisions which make CDGs so fun is still preserved.

—description from the publisher

name: Kinder im Straßenverkehr
description:
The players start at their houses and have to visit certain destinations while minding the traffic rules, before returning home. The first player back home wins the game. Movement is determined by a die. After each players turn, the turntable under the game board is moved one step to create new traffic situations and to change the traffic Lights. If the meeple of a player gets on a black dot, the player has to draw an event card and follow the instructions printed on it.

The game was published in the 1970s.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Harry's Place
description:
You are a lead server working at Harry's Place and the restaurant is packed with Monstomers! Over the course of your shift you'll dispatch a team of servers to the different food stations, gathering the items needed, to complete your Monstomers' orders.

As you serve the Monstomers they will give you tips in the form of chocolate chip cookies based on their happiness level. However, with each passing round, the Monstomers get more and more frustrated waiting for their food and will leave smaller tips. Eventually, they’ll leave the restaurant if they are not served fast enough. If that happens, plan on giving Harry some of your cookies. Harry doesn't like to lose Monstomers.

Sounds simple, right? Not so fast, because you’re not the only lead server working tonight. You'll be competing with other players who are trying to serve their Monstomers as well. Spaces are limited. The orders are piling up. It may be wise to share some of your cookies with the chefs, so you get the food you need first. If all goes well at the end of the night, you'll be the player with the most cookies to win the game.

name: Shake-a-round
description:
The box contains five specialty dice: one white die called “tee-ball” and four green dice called “the strokes”, a dice cup, two scorepads, and one rules sheet. The players note the par score for the hole they are playing and roll one fewer green die than par. The players will always roll the tee-ball die. The result of the roll is the player’s score for the hole. As in the sport, the low score is the winner at the end of the tournament no matter how many holes the participants have decided to play.

—user summary

name: Pavillon Noir!: A l'abordage !
description:
This is an expansion for Pavillon Noir ! Published in Vae Victis #33

Pavillon Noir ! *Règles d'escarmouche pour Flibustiers* is a pirate skirmish miniature wargame.

The game uses a simple activation system between players. This extension adds 3 chapters, boarding parties, on the bridge and a few more weapons, as well as a scenario *Que le Grand Cric me Croque !*

Scale: 1 mini = 1 man, 1 cm = 1 m, a turn sequence = a few seconds

Published in French in Vae Victis magazine.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Pirates, Wargame

name: Le casse du siècle
description:
The goal of the game is to find the 4 digits of the secret combination of the box.
At the beginning of the game each player takes a keychain consisting of 4 keys and memorizes the numbers written on the keys.
In turn, the player places on the board, face up, all the keys he can place on one or more doors by respecting the number and the letter written on each lock. He rejects, face down, the keys he could not place and place them on incomplete trousseaux. When all the locks of a door are put, the player who places the key will have the right to look at one of the gears. The first player to discover the 4-digit combination wins.

—user summary

name: La route enchantée
description:
It is a game of course and road safety. The players leave box 1 and must join box 123 where the castle is located. Players drive on roads and must respect the rules of the road. During the game, players must watch their opponents and report infractions before the next player rolls the die. The first player to reach the castle with both cars won.

—user summary

name: Exactly As Planned
description:
Exactly As Planned is a five-minute cooperative game played in real time. Players race against the clock in the last few minutes of their complex heist.

Each player will gather the tools necessary to satisfy their collection of jobs. Tools are not used up, so the same tool can help to complete multiple jobs at the same time. More efficient combinations of tools and jobs divided between players will allow the team to successfully complete one of several heist scenarios before the time is up and the thieves are discovered.

Once the team masters the fundamental elements of the game, communication restrictions are introduced. A member of the heist crawling through the ducts is unable to communicate as freely as the computer specialist in the van. One team member might be speaking only in questions, a second might have to stare at the ceiling, and a third might be restricted to saying only "yes" or "no".

If the players are lucky, everything will go, well, you know...

—description from the designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Real-Time, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Long Fen Dao
description:
The Dragons of Phoenix Island

You are rival dragons vying for the riches of the Phoenix Islands! Players will send workers to various islands, where they will claim dominance or return with treasures. Careful management of worker placement and treasure gathering, as well as tile placement to build archipelago itself, will lead to victory!

Players take turns placing tiles and doing a disciple action, including place, move and plunder. Disciples can be left to occupy islands, bringing occupation points. Alternatively, they may plunder riches on the island, returning with these to the dragons for set collection points. But this will allow other players to dominate the islands. Then there are the all important shipping lanes. With a tight worker-management mechanism, players must contemplate the value of their limited actions with care.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Modular Board, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Hunter's Gyre
description:
This game follows the souls of two to four hunters as they compete in life, journey through the afterlife and on to resurrection.

The game is driven by the Hunter's Field, based on a simple Mongolian capture game called Wolf and Deer. The journey progresses to the Garden of Souls, where players can worship their ancestors to score for each soul present, then on to the Trial of Bridges, which scores in a simple row/column area control at the end of each round. Pieces can then pass on to the Wheel Of Joy, from which they can be resurrected to the Hunter's Field.

—description from the designer

name: Paragon
description:
Have you ever wondered who the most interesting person at the table is? Wonder no longer! We’ve made a fun game to help you discover all the interesting things your friends and fellow players have been up to. With questions like “Who has climbed to the highest elevation?” “Who is most likely to have a secret underground lair?” and “We’re in a prison cell, who picks the lock from the inside?” you’re bound to learn some interesting things about your friends and yourself with a game of Paragon. This is another quick game that can be played to fill a little time or be played multiple times to keep the party going.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Print & Play

name: Hastur Horta Hodor Mordor
description:
Hastur Horta Hodor Mordor is a mix between a memory game and tongue twister. Each card in the game starts you off with an interesting collection of words, like Hastur, Horta, Hodor, and Mordor. The first player begins the round of reading the first word. The next player recites the next word, and so on, adding words of their choice as they go. The goal is to choose words that are similar to the last word in the group, and never forget a word in the sequence. Hopefully, you have better memories and tongue agility than your opponents. You can take as little as a few minutes or an hour to enjoy mind-bending tongue twisters.

—description from the publisher

name: Epic Vs. Awesome
description:
THE EPICEST, AWESOMEST GAME SINCE THE DAWN OF TIME EVER!!!! One player is the Overlord, who rules over the game with an iron fist. The other players are competing to be the most epic, the awesome people in the Overlord’s domain. Roll the giant Boulder of Destiny, present a category, and bring the most persuasive arguments for the chosen words and answers! This is the very rare “Bootleg Edition,” which has been swiped from our hard drives in the dark of night. Make your own Boulder of Destiny and get ready to rule the world!

—description from the publisher

name: Lunar Outpost
description:
It's the future. People communicate using an interconnected computer network and industrial techno is the only remaining musical genre. Mankind has mastered technology and is finally about to cross the final frontier, leaving Earth and colonizing space.

Since the recent discovery of vast resource deposits below the Moon's surface, four of the most wealthy and prominent nations have taken aim at establishing lunar outposts.

In Lunar Outpost, the players take on the roles as the supreme and beloved leaders of the four nations. Lead your nation to glory and you will be forever remembered in the history books. Lead your nation to defeat and your entire nation will be forgotten as a parenthesis in history.

Welcome to the space age.



In Lunar Outpost, 2-4 players compete over a precious but limited resource. They do so through drawing and placing hexagonal terrain tiles depicting the barren surface of the moon.

Most tiles feature a location suitable for constructing a building and a few tiles feature resource deposits. Each tile may connect to some, none or all of its neighbors through its edges. Tiles only connect when the terrain of the shared edge is passable.

Each player starts out with a single building next to a small resource deposit and is only allowed to expand their outpost to connected tiles that are unclaimed by other players. This must be done as the total number of resources that may be extracted from the resource deposit is limited.

Throughout the game, new resource deposits will be discovered. In order to obtain the valuable resources, players must construct buildings capable of harvesting the resource in the direct proximity of the resource deposit.

The game features several different building types that may be constructed, each with their own perks and granting a certain number of victory points. Resources are consumed when buildings are constructed so players will have to form a strategy and adapt depending on how the game develops.

Agressive players may construct buildings capable of recruiting troops and attack other players' buildings and/or troops. Defensive players may construct defensive structures to prevent agressive players from reaching their resource producing buildings. Terrain can also be used as an advantage.

A player may be heavily decimated from the attack of another player. It is even possible for players to coordinate their attacks against a stronger opponent and prevent them from dominating the game. Although rare, players can even be completely eliminated from the game.

The game ends in the turn where the last tile is placed. Players compute the total number of victory points awarded from each of their buildings left standing and the player with the most points wins the game!

—description from the designer
categories: City Building, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Territory Building, Wargame
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Grid Movement, Player Elimination, Tile Placement

name: Stairway to Heaven
description:
If you had the opportunity to change your eternal fate, would you rather be good or evil? In this game, you take the role of a spirit, wandering in the afterlife on its last journey, the final steps between our world and beyond. But you're not alone, Devils & Angels shall guide through your way. so you can decide to join their team and end up doing good deeds and help other spirits or be the ultimate devil and ruin their lives. the choice is yours...

Throughout this game, you have to roll a dice, move up the stairs, pick different cards and most importantly, bring chaos to the world by making life and death decisions! once you pick a side and join the good or evil force, you can even use the help of real angels and demons and summon them upon your needs.

The goal of this game is simple, collect as many Soul points as you can and be the best Devil or Angel in the afterlife. remember that either one of the sides can win the game, all that matters is that you play your character in the best possible way.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Auf die Krone
description:
The knights of the round table are picking their new leader. All the players raise their swords. But be careful – not everyone is loyal to the kingdom. You need to guess how many players are friendly to the crown. Correct predictions are rewarded with gemstones. The player with the most valuable collection of gemstones is the winner.

—description from the publisher

Short game instructions:
1. Put the crown and the tiles face down in the center of the table. Have the pouch of gemstones ready. Everyone takes a sword.
2. Play turns in a clockwise direction.
3. The player whose turn it is secretly looks at two shield tiles. Swing swords: On command, everyone simultaneously extends their sword either to the crown or into the air. Does the number on one of the two shield tiles match the number of swords pointing at the crown? Then take a gemstone from the pouch! Otherwise, carry on empty-handed. Then it’s the next player’s turn.
4. As soon as someone has collected 2 gemstones of the same color or 4 in different colors they are the winner!

name: Hat-Trick: Borussia Dortmund
description: This promotional team card adds the German team Borussia Dortmund as team card to the game.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Sports
mechanics: Grid Movement, Hand Management, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Scouting Nederland Spel
description:
The game is introduced in 1978 on the "Scout In" event in the Netherlands. It introduces the new Scouting play areas and new uniforms in a game based on "Game of Goose".

As the players move around the board they have to do different actions ranging from more traditional "move to the next tile" actions to typically Scouting "sing the Jungle song" actions or answering Scouting questions.

The goal is to be the first to cross the finish and also to learn a lot more about the different play areas of Dutch Scouting.

—user summary

name: Duck Da Bomb
description:
Learn unplugged with ducks and cards! They’re designed for your kids to learn progressively while keeping them amused. The strategic play involved allows kids to take in tactics, leading them to be creative coders in the process.

Forget gadgets and computers, you won’t be needing them. In Duck Da Bomb, all you need to get started are cards, tokens, and a board! Lead the ducks to the flags while avoiding the bombs using commands. Stack them up strategically (resembling the command line in coding) and get the ducks swimming for victory!

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math
mechanics: Action Queue, Open Drafting, Paper-and-Pencil, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Mathematic-roll
description:
Mathematic-roll is a roll & write game about number manipulation and elementary mathematics, perfect for students practicing their addition, subtraction, and multiplication skills while also providing the fun and challenging decision making of a classic competitive roll & write! The game plays over 7 rounds where players roll dice and combine the values with simple math operations to fill in sections of a multiplication table.

Players score points by completing rows and columns in the table, and by cleverly using the values they have to make high-value numbers and patterns. Players can also take advantage of special abilities (functions) to manipulate their rolls, and saving rolls for later rounds to build towards crafting more complicated equations and score higher-value numbers.

—description from the publisher

name: DeathRace CyberGlobe
description:
Story
In the near future, a multinational company called "Cyber ​​Technologies" has distinguished itself and established itself in the life of modern man thanks to its BOTs; cybernetic organisms able to physically support or completely replace the human figure. After the use of these technologies in the military field and a devastating war, civilization finds itself on the margins of survival. In this climate of tension between the population of the lower social class and the political ruling class, the DeathRace CyberGlobe sport is consolidated. A violent race of BOTs driven by humans for the conquest of fame and economic power. The DeathRace CyberGlobe has become the dream of turning life but also an outlet for the population that is being overwhelmed by this "format" as a dogma and only pastime. The teams take part in the races putting their lives at risk, even knowing that they have very few chances to win, since the Tracks are full of traps and in the race BOT automata are introduced to make the competitions even more lethal and spectacular.

The game:
The game is recommended for players over 10 years old, not because of the complexity, but because of some violent terms in it (although I believe that on TV there are certainly worse contents in the protected area). and some small component. Structured to play it from 1 to 4 players with a small and simple AI that controls the BOT automata. There are three categories that vary the difficulty and time of a game (between 30-90 minutes).
The BasicLine: the simplest category that helps the player to understand the mechanics of the game.
TeamRacer: The category dedicated to teams, where each player can compete with a team of 4 maximum BOTs.
DeathRace: The most destructive category thanks to the additional weapons that BOTs can equip.

—description from the designer
categories: Dice, Fighting, Industry / Manufacturing, Miniatures, Racing, Sports
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: World Safari Premium
description:
From Publisher site:
Description
"WORLD SAFARI-Premium" The board game has a world map, a built in Spinner showing names of 50 important countries and a colourful path to move around the map. Spin the spinner, read the country name, and try to find the country on the map. If successful, you get to advance the given number of spaces on the play path. Most of spaces show show different symbols representing Continents and Countries, Physical Features, People and Places, General and Visual Questions. If the Play Piece lands on one of these spaces the next player picks a card from the pile of cards and asks the question against the symbol on which the player has landed. If the answer is correct the player moves forward and takes another turn. By playing with interactive Country and Information cards children will

Match the Country map card with its Information card,
Play Memory game,
Play Who Am I? game,
Play Category Quiz games and
Sorting game.


—description from the publisher

name: World Safari Junior
description:
"World Safari- Junior" The Play Board has a pictorial World map showing physical features, important landmarks and path to move and three types of cards. Spin the Spinner, pick the card from the corresponding Cards pile, if it is a "Find" card look for that feature on the map, if it is a "Tell " card look carefully at that feature/ map given on the card and answer correctly and if the spinner has landed on " ? "space, answer the question given on that card. If you have answered correctly move forward and take another turn. First player to reach the Finish square wins the game. To reinforce the knowledge and practice map skills fill and colour the blank maps with the help of maps given on the opposite page of every map.

—description from the publisher

name: Cardwords
description:
Cardwords is a word card game where each card has a letter and players spell words with them. Both double deck and single deck versions have been published.

Each deck has two copies of each letter of the alphabet, along with a point value of 1-4 points. In all of the games playable with these decks, a duplicate letter can be used as a wild card standing for any letter, e.g. in "FFGHT", since there are two 'F's one can be considered an 'I', spelling "FIGHT".

Rules are included for seven games:

1: A fishing game like Logomachy (which is like Scopa), where a card played either combines with cards on the table to make a word, or is left on the table.
2: Poker using words, either 5-card stud, 7-card stud or 5-card draw.
3: Bingo, each player having a 3x3 array of cards, turning cards one at a time in any order (except the middle card last), with the first 3-letter word formed winning.
4: Rummy, where players draw but never discard, laying down words from their hand or adding to words on the table, and the first player to play all their hand wins.
5: Rummy, like #4 except a card is discarded at the end of each turn.
6: Rummy, like #5 except that adding letters to a word lets you steal the word.
7: Players start with 13-card hands, all players simultaneously pass a card to the left until one player announces having a word worth 15+ points and claims the pot. Then the player with the word gives one-word clues to their word until another player guesses their word, and the two split the second pot.


Each game uses chips, with players adding chips to the pot during play, and the winner claiming the pot. Chips are not provided in the game.

—user summary

name: Word-Opsy
description:
Word-Opsy is a game of forming words from individual letters on cards. It has two decks, each of which 4 of each vowel (1 of the 4 having a star), 2 of each common consonant, and 1 each for the six rarer consonants. There are rules for three games:

In Word-Opsy, in each turn a player lays down a word from the hand, or adds cards to one of their existing words (in either case refilling the hand back up to 6 cards), or draws a card and passes. After the last card is drawn and everyone gets an extra turn, each word scores the square of its length, with every star in it adding the word's value again.

Word-Rummy plays like Word-Opsy except that players discard a card at the end of their turn, and do not draw if they pass. The games ends when one player plays all the cards from their hand. Scoring is as in Word-Opsy with the player going out getting a 25-point bonus.

Word-Cassino plays like Casino, where a turn is taking a card from the hand and either: making a word with it and cards on the table to claim those cards; adding it to cards on the table and announcing a word to be finished later in the round; or adding it to the table cards. After the deck is played out, the player with the most cards gets 3 points, the most vowels gets 1 point, and 1 point for each Q, Z, or star card. Hands are played until a player has 21 points or more.

—user summary

name: Raid Area 51 the Game
description:
A modular board game about the cultural phenomenon that is "Raid Area 51."

Free the Aliens!
Be a part of this monumental event in American history! Do you wish you could be one of the daring souls prepared to lay down their lives in an effort to free our alien comrades from the clutches of Area 51? Now you can, though, very indirectly.

We want to capture the hype and paranoia surrounding Area 51 and the heroes who seek to uncover its secrets. This game will be an easy to play, Rouge-like, modular board game set to the backdrop of the blistering Nevada desert.

We are hoping to raise enough funds to create an immersive, quick paced game which can be expanded upon with later additions.

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Exploration, Party Game, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Tile Placement

name: Ortho
description:
Ortho is a game where players form words from letters on cards. The Ortho deck has 52 cards, each with a letter at either end; the two letters may be the same or different, and if different the player chooses which letter is used. There are also two "Chief" cards that are wild and can stand for any letter.

Players start with seven cards each. In a turn a player draws the top of the deck or discard pile, and if possible either plays a word onto the table, or adds cards to a word on the table to make another word. In either case a word of 2 letters scores 1 point, and doubling for each additional letter (e.g. 3 letters 2 points, 4 letters 4 points, 5 letters 8 points, etc.). 32 points is the maximum allowed for any word.

The hand ends when a player uses all their cards in play, calling "Ortho!" and also earning from each player one point per card left in their hand. (Presumably a hand also ends when the deck is gone.) A player wins by either Ortho'ing with a total of 104+ points, or ending a hand with 128+ points.

—user summary

name: Assault from the Sky: Battle for Crete 1941
description:
Assault from the Sky - Battle for Crete 1941 portrays the fascinating German airborne operations on Crete in May 1941. The game is playable in 1 to 2 hours maximum. Assault from the Sky - Battle for Crete is a new edition in the Battle Command Series. The game is a quick-playing game with large 3/4 rounded counters, a map board, rules, and dice. Units are rated for their strength and movement, as well an endurance rating that reflects how much damage a unit can sustain in combat.

—description from the publisher

name: A Matter of Bridges: Operation Market Garden 1944
description:
Market-Garden: Race for the Rhine is a two-player game that simulates the first ten days of Operation Market-Garden, the airborne invasion of Holland, September 17 to September 26, 1944.

Each turn represents one day of combat, and each hex is about 8 miles across. One player commands the defending German forces and the other player commands the invading Allied forces.

—description from the publisher

name: Battle of the Gustav Line: Cassino 1944
description:
Battle of the Gustav Line - Cassino 1944 is a two-player game that simulates the first and second Allied offensives against the Monte Cassino portion of the German Gustav Line, January 22 to February 20, 1944.

Each turn represents five days of combat, and each hex is about 1 mile across. One player commands the Allied forces and the other player commands the German forces.

—description from the publisher

name: Road to Rome: Anzio 1944
description:
Road to Rome - Anzio 1944 is a two-player game that simulates the opening weeks of Operation Shingle, January 22 to February 20, 1944. Each turn represents five days of combat, and each hex is about 1 mile across. One player commands the Allied forces and the other player commands the German forces.

—description from the publisher

name: BD Défi
description:
BD Défi is a quiz game in which you will answer to question about comic strip. You pick a card, you roll a dice, then you answer the right question.

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Party Game, Trivia

name: Gin-A-Word
description:
Gin Rummy using letters to make words. There are two decks of 52 cards with a letter and point value on each, plus a wild card. One deck is used for 2-3 players, two decks for 4 or more.

Each player starts with a 10-card hand, and each turn consists of drawing a card and discarding a card. Once a player can use their 10 cards to make 2-3 words during their turn, they call "Gin-A-Word" and win the hand. Everyone then show their hand formed into words; the player who went out earns 25 points plus all the points in their hand, plus the value of the cards not used in words in all other players' hands. Multiple hands are played; a total of 150 points wins the game.

The plastic box the game comes in also includes a tray for the draw and discard piles.

—user summary

name: Injury or Illness
description:
Injury or Illness is a delicious mix of misadventure, maladies and misfortunes. An infectiously entertaining game that will leave you in stitches that eventually become infected and require surgery. An absurd game of sick, dark humor that is toxically funny.

—description from the back of the box

name: MACE: Martial Arts Card Engine
description:
MACE is a game for 2 – 4 players. MACE simulates the fantastic martial arts battles common to fighting games and anime. Each player is represented by a Fighter, a master of the martial arts complete with vicious Strikes and powerful Blasts of energy. The goal is to Knock Out all other players Fighters, with the last one standing the winner.

MACE uses a deck of playing cards, a hex sheet and some tokens, so is easy to play and requires no book keeping. MACE also features a unique order mechanic called Momentum, which allows you to choose when you act.

If you are interested in anything anime or martial arts and like a fun simple system, then check out MACE!

Place one deck of playing cards in centre of play area. When a player plays a card from their hand, draw a card to replace it. All cards played are discarded to the discard pile next to the deck. If a player cannot draw a card because the deck is empty, shuffle discard pile and place as new deck.

—description from the publisher

name: hackd
description:
“there are only two kinds of companies: those that have been hacked, and those that will be.” - kimmy johnny one

hackd is a playful way to build security awareness in any setting. if you consider yourself a security expert, take this opportunity to train your grandma, friends or clients.

a ceo and his team are trying to protect their organization from an active threat that is locking down critical machines for ransom.

they have to make several tough choices with limited resources - securing their machines, holding back the hackers, identifying malicious employees. they can't do it all. how can they avoid getting hackd?

—description from the designer
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Deduction, Modular Board, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Charge!: Rules for Starship Fleet Miniatures
description:
Charge! is a tactical game designed for Space Fleet battles on a hexagon map.

The game is arranged round different ships sizes that have different power and speed. They have a common set of weapons, so it comes down to tactics who will win. There is a maximum of choices and a minimum of luck involved.
Players can design their own fleets using the points cost system.
The game is fast-paces and has minimum book keeping, so playing with large fleets is possible.
The designer has created 3D printable ships for the game.

—description from the designer

name: Guinea Pig Bridge
description:
A family fun strategy card game to race your guinea pigs to safety!

Build a bridge at least 5 cards long and move your guinea pig tokens across it. Slow down your competitors by distracting their guinea pigs.

name: Reise ins Licht
description:
Funny, exciting and meditative tasks are to be shared alone or with others.
The active player rolls the die and must move forward as many spaces as shown. Then he draws a task card. When he solved the task is , he can move forward as many spaces as indicated on the task card. If the task is not solved, the player rolls the dice again and must move backwards so many spaces spaces.
The first player to reach field 64 is the winner.

—user summary

name: Das Gleis ist heiss
description:
Drive as fast as possible from the specified start stop to the destination stop. Take a bus, tram, train or a ship of "Weiße Flotte". The goal is to arrive first, each of which can put obstacles in the way, e.g. event rings or construction workers.

—user summary

name: Blanche Neige
description:
A french card game in Snow White world, where players should associate dwarf cards by color or number.

The first player to discard all cards wins.

name: Boucle d'Or
description:
A French card game in goldilocks world where players should quickly identify similar symbols on cards.

Player who acquired most of the cards win the game

name: Advanced Virtus
description:
A set of "Fast & Furious" ancient miniatures battle rules. Units continue doing whatever they're doing from turn to turn unless successfully ordered to do something else.

The game should be compatible with almost any basing scheme. Each figure represents 15 to 20 men, the ground scale is set by the players choosing a length of the "Distance Unit" that suits their figures and basing.

name: Monster Faire Card Game
description:
In Monster Faire Card Game, the players take on the roles of Mad Scientists. They live in crumbling old manors near the town of Beastly Vale, and compete in building Monsters from parts of dead bodies and bringing them to life. Requires two standard decks of playing cards, and recommended for three to six players. While not a true role-playing game as such, possession of role-playing skills will enhance the play experience.
- Publisher's blurb

Beastly Vale

The town of Beastly Vale lies in a forested valley. It is a simple rural woodland town that never has anything interesting or important happen to it – or so they say. For there are plenty of dark and scary stories told around town about the Mad Scientists who live in manors outside of town, and nobody likes to be caught outside after nightfall.

Mad Scientists

A number of Mad Scientists live near Beastly Vale, experimenting in their manors and not keeping healthy hours. Strange lights are seen at night, and paths leading from the manors to the local graveyard are kept in suspiciously good repair. Oh, whatever could they be up to?

The Monster Faire

Being in correspondence with each other, as members of the New Prometheus Society, the Mad Scientists have decided to hold a Monster Faire. They are going to compete in creating hideous new life! Whoever’s monster is the last one standing wins. If their monster is especially fearsome, they may even win the Promethean Scholarship.

—description from the designer

The rules for the game are distributed as a free, print-and-play file.

—user summary

name: The Calling: A Cthulean Social Deduction Game
description:
The Calling is a Social Deduction game where players are Investigators in the FBI, following up with reports of insanity and murders by the local docks. Soon after, the same symptoms begin to rise within the Precinct causing the Investigators to suspect the work of a Cultist of the whispered Cthulhu, acting as an Investigator by day, and doing the Profane work of the Deep one by night.
The Calling plays similarly to most Social Deduction games with a day phase and a night phase, but the distinctive difference is that it is moderatorless, and part of completing a night action, players wake up the next person. The Calling also uses a "Murder Party" mechanic, where during the day any three players can band together to instantly kill a player, Dead players can also instigate or contribute to murder parties, allowing them a lot of power as the balance of alive and dead players tips towards final day. Finally All dead players become evil once dead, as the Cultist assembles an ever growing army of the dead, to help defeat the astute investigators.

—description from the publisher

name: Mistborn: House War – Rabble Rouser Promo Card
description:
First available at Gen Con 2019. The card states:

"Lasting. Play face up on your turn in front of another player. Stays in play.

At the beginning of each of this player's turns, they gain 1 Disgrace."
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Negotiation, Novel-based
mechanics: Hand Management, Take That, Variable Player Powers

name: Bergsteigerspiel
description:
The players start at a town at the banks of the river Elbe. Movement is determined by a die. Some spaces hinder or benefit the players. On some spaces the player may chose to try a jump over a chasm to shorten his way. The first player to reach the peak of the third cliff wins the game.

This game seems to be from the 1930s.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: I Cavalieri dell'Aria
description:
I Cavalieri dell’Aria, or Knights of the Air. 2/10 players fantasy air combat game. Knights of two factions fly a fire-breathing beast, armed by a bow, a sword and a heavy crossbow. Pre-planned movement, then secret choice of actions. Appeared on E Giochi magazine, issue of November 1992. Later appeared again on Kaos magazine by Nexus Editrice, future publisher of Wings of War. Triangular grid the map, counters occupying 6 of them as if they were an hex. Firing cones come very natural. All rules, optional included, were on an A3 page of the magazine.

—description from the designer
categories: Aviation / Flight, Bluffing, Dice, Fantasy, Fighting, Wargame
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Player Elimination, Point to Point Movement, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Boris, Bees and Boomerangs
description:
Boris, Bees and Boomerangs is a light-hearted, fast-paced, real-time roll and write game. Every player gets a Boris card and places it on their player sheet. Players simultaneously roll their seven to eight custom dice in real-time and note their results on their player sheets. Players try to surround their Boris with Bees as fast as possible. At the same time, you have to watch out for the other players! They can hurl Boomerangs that destroy parts of your player sheet or even worse, disperse your bees and unleash the wrath of Boris upon you. However, Boomerangs are dangerous and might backfire.

The winner is whoever manages to surround Boris with Bees or the last player not killed by their own Boris.

—description from the designer

name: Pier Pressure
description:
You’ve inherited a shop on an once world renowned entertainment pier from a long lost family member. The city council has big plans to remodel the pier so it can once again regain it’s illustrious place on the world stage. They’ve invited you and a few other wealthy heirs to re-open the long closed shops and rebuild this once stunning tourist attraction - the catch: You’ve only got one summer to pull this off.

Amass influence and profit in this worker placement, area control game. You’ve only got one summer to become the king/queen of the pier.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Open Drafting, Tile Placement, Worker Placement

name: Die magische Tausend
description: You roll combinations with dice and whoever scores a thousand points has won.

name: The Fire Smart Kids
description:
This is a roll-and-move game intended to teach children about fire safety.

On your turn, you roll the die and move your player piece the corresponding number of spots on the board. If the spot you land on has an action, you must take that action. Actions include: Lose a Turn, Go Back, Go Ahead, and Fire Smart Cards. When you land on a Fire Smart Cards space, you take a card from the deck and follow its instructions; each card also contains a piece of fire safety information.

The first player to cross the finish line, by exact count of the dice, wins the game. However, the game does not finish until every player crosses the finish line.

—user summary

name: Florafiora: The Open Worlds
description:
The worlds of Florafiora are in peril! You, a seedizen of the Spring, Summer, Fall or Winter realms must save it. 1-4 players cooperatively or competitively explore, nurture and defend this universe's tiny planets by freely moving and collecting a pool of magic dice.

Each die adds to your resource gathering and combat abilities, allowing you to regrow wilted planets, recruit companions and tame eons-old beings.

Time is running out though, as usurper queen Lillith has placed herself in the center of the universe and is draining it of all life and beauty. Stop her by building four legendary towers, awakening the sleeping queen and defeating her face-to-face. Can you save Florafiora?

—description from the publisher

name: Afrika Army Korps II: Torch
description:
Afrika Army Korps II: Torch covers part of the battle for North Africa using the DAMOS rule-set and provides a solid way to experience the game under conditions radically changed from the Barbarossa series. Without having to worry about bogs, swamps and unreliable steppe, the desert becomes a tankers paradise.

Exclusive rules for movement, sea transport, logistics and more allow players to combine the Afrika Army Korps games with any other games in the DAMOS series in order to create either a mini-monster or linked campaign game. Using the classic AH Afrika Korps as inspiration, AFRIKA ARMY KORPS series offers a brand new take on the campaign at the strategic scale hex-size of 25 miles per hex. Combat is in hex and opportunities for encirclement abound for both sides.

Players can combine AAK, AAK II TORCH, and AAK III TUNISIA to simulate the entire North African campaign.

WEIGHT: 6/10

SOLITAIRE: 7/10

PLAYERS: 1-2

—description from the publisher

name: Afrika Army Korps III: Tunisia
description:
Afrika Army Korps III: Tunisia covers part of the battle for North Africa using the DAMOS rule-set and provides a solid way to experience the game under conditions radically changed from the Barbarossa series. Without having to worry about bogs, swamps and unreliable steppe, the desert becomes a tankers paradise.

Exclusive rules for movement, sea transport, logistics and more allow players to combine the Afrika Army Korps games with any other games in the DAMOS series in order to create either a mini-monster or linked campaign game. Using the classic AH Afrika Korps as inspiration, AFRIKA ARMY KORPS series offers a brand new take on the campaign at the strategic scale hex-size of 25 miles per hex. Combat is in hex and opportunities for encirclement abound for both sides.

Players can combine AAK, AAK II TORCH, and AAK III TUNISIA to simulate the entire North African campaign.

WEIGHT: 6/10

SOLITAIRE: 7/10

—description from the publisher

name: Earth As Their Memorial: The Peloponnesian War (431-404 BC)
description:
The Earth As Their Memorial is a hybrid strategic/operational scale game what covers the 30 year brutal campaign of attrition waged between Sparta, Athens and their respective allies, bringing a violent and destructive end to the golden age of Greece along with Athenian hedgemony in Hellas (Greece).

Players will elect leaders and plan operations during the Assembly Phase, and then randomly pull those operations performing them in the drawn order during a joint Action Phase. Leaders can either retain their commands, be removed, or even be exiled. Different operations include Land Campaign, Naval Campaign, Combined Operations, Mobilization, Fortification and more.

WEIGHT: 5/10

SOLITAIRE: 9/10

Each turn is approximately 1 year and players can either play through the whole war, or the individual phases. The game should also play relatively well solo given the method of activation. No CRT is used, instead a system similar to 1870 is used where SP ratios determine Die Roll Modifiers, and then die results will determine the scope of results between 2 forces. Both players will have to manage the unique challenges of commanding citizen hoplites, slaves and mercenary forces in order to force their opponent into surrender.

—description from the publisher

name: Trim the Tree
description:
Trim the tree with your elf patrol, trying to get the garland on before any ornaments get dropped.

Players take control of a Team of Elves, trying to put the garland on the Christmas tree in someone's house. A pesky squirrel is making this harder than it should be. The ornaments fall as the squirrel knocks them off the tree. If any ornament falls completely off the tree, the owner awakes and the game is over, and the players lose. During the game, the players will place ornaments on the tree, and with enough help, they can place the garland around each level on the tree.
